That's the way writing has to be done now, I guess, though I still do my first story drafts in longhand. They say, and I'm sure it's true, that using a computer will make writing easier what with re-writing paragraphs and moving them around in the story. That's the reason that me replacing him is such a question. I feel like I can play and do the job. I feel like there are some things I can do pretty well, I guess, and some things he can do better. Times News Service No. 1661 Tue. July 25 (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN  ``This is a sad story: Hall of Famers Duke Snyder and Willie McCovey pleaded guilty to income tax evasion. They each face up to six months in prison -- or one season with the Yankees.''  ``LaToya Jackson announced today that she's filing for bankruptcy. It's so bad she says she may have to embark on a second career. I think this raises an interesting question: What was her first career?'' .  ``Welcome to the program. I'm Dave Letterman, the inspiration for the motion picture `Clueless.''' .  ``According to a new health survey, smoking among 8th graders is increasing at an alarming rate. I can kind of understand it. What the hell are you supposed to do after sex, homework?'' .  ``Yesterday, Illinois congressman Mel Reynolds went on trial for allegedly having sex with teen-age campaign workers. Ladies and gentlemen, this man should not be a congressman. This man should be a senator.'' .  ``Out there in Los Angeles, the Emmy nominations were announced. Here at the `Late Show,' we were lucky enough to be nominated for five. I don't know how good our chances are in this one category. We're up against the Kennedy Center Honors, the Barbra Streisand concert and the three-hour Bronco chase.''  ``Orlando Magic all-star Anfernee Hardaway yesterday turned 23. That's right, it was his birf-day.''  ``Boris Yeltsin is apparently feeling better. They had him on Russian television yesterday from his hospital bed to show the world that he was doing better. He was in the hospital for minor surgery. They removed his head from a mini-bar.''  ``You folks are here on a good night. It's the final stop of the `Hugh Grant Apology Tour.'''  ``In the last week and a half, Hugh Grant has apologized 200 times. If tonight, on this show, he apologizes just two times more he will break the record that I set after the Academy Awards.''  ``Over the weekend, Hugh Grant's new film, `Nine Months,' opened big at the box office _ $13 million dollars. That's excellent considering he only spent 60 bucks on advertising.''  ``Carol Shaya, the New York City police officer who was tossed off the force because she posed naked in Playboy, says she'd like to get back on the force. I say absolutely; let's at least have one New York City cop who looks good naked.'' .  ``O.J.'s exercise video was produced by Playboy. And they're also producing another video to come out of the O.J. Simpson trial. I believe it's called `Rosa Lopez: Wet and Wild in El Salvador.''' .  ``According to a new survey by the American Medical Association, 84% of men fantasize about being in bed with two women at the same time. Hell, I fantasize about being in bed with two women in the same year.'' .  ``Yesterday, two Americans who had been held captive in an Iraqi prison for the last four months were released unharmed. It's interesting, the first question these two gentlemen were asked was, `Hey, how'd the O.J. trial end up?'''  ``President Clinton says that he is opposed to mandatory school prayer. However, he is encouraging kids to pray on their own. In fact, the President is encouraging everyone to pray Bob Dole gets caught with a hooker before November `96.''  CITY STREETS  Hand-lettered cardboard sign seen by Jeffrey C. Loeser in the window of a deli in Brooklyn:  FROZEN MILKY WAYS _ FIRST OF THE SEASON  Sign spotted by Lori Vogel in the window of a Greenwich Village restaurant:  NOTICE _ CLOSED BY ORDER OF COMMISSIONER OF HEALTH  Name of the establishment? ``Eat Healthy.''  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S ``THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO''  ``A new study reports that by the year 2005, Los Angeles will have more people than any other city in America. Actually, that's pretty good timing because that's about when we should be picking a new jury for the O.J. retrial.''  ``Those O.J. workout tapes have been selling like hotcakes this week. O.J. recommends this `power walking.' Have you heard about this theory? Power walking: This is where you commit a crime and hire a bunch of power attorneys and then you walk!''  ``The school district of Niskayuna, New York, has banned students from kissing and holding hands. We give them free condoms, but they can't kiss or hold hands. All we are doing is banning foreplay. No wonder why men are such bad lovers!''  ``This is something you might not know about if you are from out of town. This is an amazing city because nobody walks here. Nobody walks, unless, of course, you have six lawyers and seven alibis.''  ``Washington Governor Mike Lawlyer apparently has agreed to pay $97,000 to settle a sexual-harassment suit by a former assistant. Even more embarrassing, I guess, when he was reaching out to grab her, he bumped into (Bob) Packwood's hand coming the other way.''  ``Doctors in Italy have perfected an operation to increase the size of a woman's buttocks. If you feel your buttocks are not big enough, you pay $6,000 and they can make them almost twice as big. I think Chef Boyaredee has been doing this for years.''  ``The State of Florida has suspended the license of a doctor who cut off the big toe of a patient without prior examination. This is the same doctor who amputated the wrong leg of another patient. The doctor said, `The big toe just fell off.' Isn't that the same defense Lorena Bobbitt used?''  ``President Clinton announced today that he is for affirmative action for women. He said if any women offers him action, he will answer `affirmative.'''  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  A new survey shows 25 percent of Americans often fall asleep in front of their TVs. Watching which network? NBZzzzz?  The congressional Waco hearings are due to run through Monday. Unless, of course, either Johnnie Cochran or Marcia Clark somehow gets involved.  There are indications the O.J. Simpson trial may wrap up in August. It's been long, but not yet as long as most pro sports seasons.  John Daly winning the British Open seemed like Prince Charles winning top cowboy honors at the National Finals Rodeo.  A new study says many Americans won't have enough money for a comfortable retirement. Probably we should worry less about making those years golden and more about making them greenish.  Speaking of retirement, it looks as if a nice symmetry awaits retired writers. We should get a pen-shun pension.  Because of drought, Russia expects its worst grain harvest in 20 years, it's reported. Hope folks there know how to make half-wheat bread.  Boris Yeltsin has been released from the hospital but has checked into a sanitarium to recuperate. This is progress. Under the old regime, we'd have been told his cold has improved to sniffles.  Another political scandal has hit China. Who says Beijing isn't adopting Western culture?  George Bush says he's worried ``about a new, selfish isolationism in some quarters of America.'' Doesn't it also happen to dimes and nickels?  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) "29134"	"I"	"guess"	" Shipments of Camel cigarettes, for example, were up 14 percent in the United States. ``Cigarette shipments were down 2 percent over all,'' Burry said, ``but they maintained their market share.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950725.0476 type=other > <DATELINE>  (BC-NYLITE(SMILE)-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> c.1995 N.Y. I'm Dave Letterman, the inspiration for the motion picture `Clueless.''' .  ``According to a new health survey, smoking among 8th graders is increasing at an alarming rate. I can kind of understand it. What the hell are you supposed to do after sex, homework?'' .  ``Yesterday, Illinois congressman Mel Reynolds went on trial for allegedly having sex with teen-age campaign workers. Ladies and gentlemen, this man should not be a congressman. This man should be a senator.'' .  ``Out there in Los Angeles, the Emmy nominations were announced. Here at the `Late Show,' we were lucky enough to be nominated for five. I don't know how good our chances are in this one category. We're up against the Kennedy Center Honors, the Barbra Streisand concert and the three-hour Bronco chase.''  ``Orlando Magic all-star Anfernee Hardaway yesterday turned 23. That's right, it was his birf-day.''  ``Boris Yeltsin is apparently feeling better. They had him on Russian television yesterday from his hospital bed to show the world that he was doing better. He was in the hospital for minor surgery. They removed his head from a mini-bar.''  ``You folks are here on a good night. It's the final stop of the `Hugh Grant Apology Tour.'''  ``In the last week and a half, Hugh Grant has apologized 200 times. If tonight, on this show, he apologizes just two times more he will break the record that I set after the Academy Awards.''  ``Over the weekend, Hugh Grant's new film, `Nine Months,' opened big at the box office _ $13 million dollars. That's excellent considering he only spent 60 bucks on advertising.''  ``Carol Shaya, the New York City police officer who was tossed off the force because she posed naked in Playboy, says she'd like to get back on the force. I say absolutely; let's at least have one New York City cop who looks good naked.'' .  ``O.J.'s exercise video was produced by Playboy. And they're also producing another video to come out of the O.J. Simpson trial. I believe it's called `Rosa Lopez: Wet and Wild in El Salvador.''' .  ``According to a new survey by the American Medical Association, 84% of men fantasize about being in bed with two women at the same time. Hell, I fantasize about being in bed with two women in the same year.'' .  ``Yesterday, two Americans who had been held captive in an Iraqi prison for the last four months were released unharmed. It's interesting, the first question these two gentlemen were asked was, `Hey, how'd the O.J. trial end up?'''  ``President Clinton says that he is opposed to mandatory school prayer. However, he is encouraging kids to pray on their own. In fact, the President is encouraging everyone to pray Bob Dole gets caught with a hooker before November `96.''  CITY STREETS  Hand-lettered cardboard sign seen by Jeffrey C. Loeser in the window of a deli in Brooklyn:  FROZEN MILKY WAYS _ FIRST OF THE SEASON  Sign spotted by Lori Vogel in the window of a Greenwich Village restaurant:  NOTICE _ CLOSED BY ORDER OF COMMISSIONER OF HEALTH  Name of the establishment? ``Eat Healthy.''  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S ``THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO''  ``A new study reports that by the year 2005, Los Angeles will have more people than any other city in America. Actually, that's pretty good timing because that's about when we should be picking a new jury for the O.J. retrial.''  ``Those O.J. workout tapes have been selling like hotcakes this week. O.J. recommends this `power walking.' Have you heard about this theory? Power walking: This is where you commit a crime and hire a bunch of power attorneys and then you walk!''  ``The school district of Niskayuna, New York, has banned students from kissing and holding hands. We give them free condoms, but they can't kiss or hold hands. All we are doing is banning foreplay. No wonder why men are such bad lovers!''  ``This is something you might not know about if you are from out of town. This is an amazing city because nobody walks here. Nobody walks, unless, of course, you have six lawyers and seven alibis.''  ``Washington Governor Mike Lawlyer apparently has agreed to pay $97,000 to settle a sexual-harassment suit by a former assistant. Even more embarrassing, I guess, when he was reaching out to grab her, he bumped into (Bob) Packwood's hand coming the other way.''  ``Doctors in Italy have perfected an operation to increase the size of a woman's buttocks. If you feel your buttocks are not big enough, you pay $6,000 and they can make them almost twice as big. I think Chef Boyaredee has been doing this for years.''  ``The State of Florida has suspended the license of a doctor who cut off the big toe of a patient without prior examination. This is the same doctor who amputated the wrong leg of another patient. The doctor said, `The big toe just fell off.' Isn't that the same defense Lorena Bobbitt used?''  ``President Clinton announced today that he is for affirmative action for women. He said if any women offers him action, he will answer `affirmative.'''  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  A new survey shows 25 percent of Americans often fall asleep in front of their TVs. Watching which network? NBZzzzz?  The congressional Waco hearings are due to run through Monday. Unless, of course, either Johnnie Cochran or Marcia Clark somehow gets involved.  There are indications the O.J. Simpson trial may wrap up in August. It's been long, but not yet as long as most pro sports seasons.  John Daly winning the British Open seemed like Prince Charles winning top cowboy honors at the National Finals Rodeo.  A new study says many Americans won't have enough money for a comfortable retirement. Probably we should worry less about making those years golden and more about making them greenish.  Speaking of retirement, it looks as if a nice symmetry awaits retired writers. We should get a pen-shun pension.  Because of drought, Russia expects its worst grain harvest in 20 years, it's reported. Hope folks there know how to make half-wheat bread.  Boris Yeltsin has been released from the hospital but has checked into a sanitarium to recuperate. This is progress. Under the old regime, we'd have been told his cold has improved to sniffles.  Another political scandal has hit China. Who says Beijing isn't adopting Western culture?  George Bush says he's worried ``about a new, selfish isolationism in some quarters of America.'' Doesn't it also happen to dimes and nickels?  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!) OPENING REMARKS FROM THE LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN  ``This is a sad story: Hall of Famers Duke Snyder and Willie McCovey pleaded guilty to income tax evasion. They each face up to six months in prison -- or one season with the Yankees.''  ``LaToya Jackson announced today that she's filing for bankruptcy. It's so bad she says she may have to embark on a second career. I think this raises an interesting question: What was her first career?'' .  ``Welcome to the program. I'm Dave Letterman, the inspiration for the motion picture `Clueless.''' .  ``According to a new health survey, smoking among 8th graders is increasing at an alarming rate. I can kind of understand it. What the hell are you supposed to do after sex, homework?'' .  ``Yesterday, Illinois congressman Mel Reynolds went on trial for allegedly having sex with teen-age campaign workers. Ladies and gentlemen, this man should not be a congressman. This man should be a senator.'' .  ``Out there in Los Angeles, the Emmy nominations were announced. Here at the `Late Show,' we were lucky enough to be nominated for five. I don't know how good our chances are in this one category. We're up against the Kennedy Center Honors, the Barbra Streisand concert and the three-hour Bronco chase.''  ``Orlando Magic all-star Anfernee Hardaway yesterday turned 23. That's right, it was his birf-day.''  ``Boris Yeltsin is apparently feeling better. They had him on Russian television yesterday from his hospital bed to show the world that he was doing better. He was in the hospital for minor surgery. They removed his head from a mini-bar.''  ``You folks are here on a good night. It's the final stop of the `Hugh Grant Apology Tour.'''  ``In the last week and a half, Hugh Grant has apologized 200 times. If tonight, on this show, he apologizes just two times more he will break the record that I set after the Academy Awards.''  ``Over the weekend, Hugh Grant's new film, `Nine Months,' opened big at the box office _ $13 million dollars. That's excellent considering he only spent 60 bucks on advertising.''  ``Carol Shaya, the New York City police officer who was tossed off the force because she posed naked in Playboy, says she'd like to get back on the force. I say absolutely; let's at least have one New York City cop who looks good naked.'' .  ``O.J.'s exercise video was produced by Playboy. And they're also producing another video to come out of the O.J. Simpson trial. I believe it's called `Rosa Lopez: Wet and Wild in El Salvador.''' .  ``According to a new survey by the American Medical Association, 84% of men fantasize about being in bed with two women at the same time. Hell, I fantasize about being in bed with two women in the same year.'' .  ``Yesterday, two Americans who had been held captive in an Iraqi prison for the last four months were released unharmed. It's interesting, the first question these two gentlemen were asked was, `Hey, how'd the O.J. trial end up?'''  ``President Clinton says that he is opposed to mandatory school prayer. However, he is encouraging kids to pray on their own. In fact, the President is encouraging everyone to pray Bob Dole gets caught with a hooker before November `96.'' "47015"	"I"	"guess"	" ``Black adolescents have to constantly confront those images and say, `That is not me. I am black and I am all the things I want to be.''' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960129.0474 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-PROUD-TO-BE-INEPT-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> HOW TO BE INEFFECTIVE By LEE GREEN c.1995 American Way magazine (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  Are you a poor listener? Negative thinker? Disorganized?  If so, you too may have what it takes to be highly ineffective.  Since its publication, Stephen R. Covey's ``The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People'' (Simon &AMP; Schuster, 1989) has been among the best-selling books on the market.  People like reading about success, I guess, but it seems to me that more people can identify with failure. For the masses, then, here are ``The 7 Habits of Highly Ineffective People.'' -0- 1. POOR LISTENING  A cornerstone of true ineffectiveness is poor listening.  Church is a bastion of poor listening. Why listen to remedies for your soul when you can daydream about catching a large trout? God Himself could be delivering the guest sermon, and half the congregation would be thinking about Egg McMuffins.  As M. Scott Peck says, listening is very hard work _ though nowhere near as hard as jackhammering. Many people feign interest, so it's not always easy to know if they're actually listening. It's a bad sign if they're humming show tunes. 2. NEGATIVE THINKING  All highly ineffective people share this trait. Not only do they see the glass as half-empty, they see it as one more thing to wash.  Not to be negative, but negativity can be a very negative thing. Especially interminable negativity which lasts a negative eon.  There are, of course, plenty of perfectly good reasons to be negative: pestilence, famine, supermarket tomatoes.  And who among us isn't daunted by the Big Questions: Where did we come from? Why are we here? And, if there is an afterlife, do they validate parking?  Negative people go through life saying, ``I'm not good enough,'' ``I can't do it'' and, inexplicably, ``The rain in Spain stays mainly on the plain.'' Fortunately, they rarely say these things aloud. 3. DISORGANIZATION  Effective people are organized. They have their ducks in a row.  Unfortunately, I have mine in a column, but let's not get bogged down in waterfowl issues. The point is ... well, I'm not sure what the point is. I had it here in my notes somewhere, but now I can't seem to _ ah, yes, here it is.  The point is, not all organization is good. If all organization were good, we wouldn't have organized crime. Al Capone was organized. Mussolini was organized.  Ants are extremely organized, but they have yet to win a seat in the House of Representatives. They don't even hold much sway in the animal kingdom, though in all fairness it's hard to hold sway when you're holding dead moth parts.  To be sure, a fool and his attempts at organization are soon parted. For example, the best-laid plans do you no good if you place them in your briefcase and then drive off with your briefcase on top of your car.  Sure, disorganization can cause your effectiveness to take a swan dive, but there we go getting bogged down in waterfowl issues again. 4. INAPPROPRIATENESS  There's a time and place for everything, which is why it's always good to carry a watch and a map.  Failures of time-and-place judgment result in all sorts of inappropriate behavior. For example, it's okay to yell ``Fire!'' after ``Ready ... aim ... '' but it's inappropriate to yell it in a crowded theater.  It is also inappropriate to yell ``Avocado!'' in a crowded theater _ not because it would cause a panic, but because it's inappropriate to yell ``Avocado!'' anywhere except at produce auctions.  It is inappropriate to rise for the seventh-inning stretch singing ``Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' when it's the bottom of the fifth and the ball is in play.  Or to hum that catchy little ``Jeopardy'' tune when your dinner date is taking too long with the menu. Or to wear a bunny suit to a funeral, especially if it's your funeral.  Naturally, effective people never commit these honest but harmful gaffes. Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas would never have survived his Senate confirmation hearing had there been even the slightest suggestion he had ever yelled ``Avocado!'' in a crowded theater. 5. DECISIONS BY DEFAULT  In my college days, which lasted two terms _ Johnson's and Nixon's _ I was determined to squander the experience by spending a bare minimum of time on campus.  Thus, I made my course selections not according to academic curiosity, degree requirements, professional goals or any other sane criteria. No, I made my choices strictly for convenience, enrolling only in classes that met during banked hours on Tuesdays and Thursdays.  It was the ``Big Bang'' approach to higher education: Each semester, my class schedule was a hodgepodge that appeared to have resulted from an explosion in the registrar's office. At 9 a.m., ``Intermediate Farsi.'' At 10:30 a.m., ``Abnormal Ornithology.'' At 1 p.m., ``Schopenhauer: Genius or Stand-Up Comic.''  Eventually, university officials decided that my accumulated credits bore a slight resemblance to a political science degree, a conclusion derived largely from the discovery that I had taken several classes ``in or near the political science building.''  It's easy enough to get a degree by default, but to live a whole life that way requires sheer, determined acquiescence _ that is, a willingness to make important decisions by not making them.  Thank God so many people exist by this simple code, allowing inertia to determine where they live, who they live with and even what they do for a living. If the average apple fell farther from the tree, no man would follow his father into sewage treatment or embalming, and then where would we be? 6. RANDOMIZATION  This habit is the opposite of systematization. Quite simply, it is the pursuit of tasks in random order instead of logical sequence.  We all know someone at work who operates this way _ usually the head of planning. Reaping before sowing, leaping before looking, dressing before showering _ these are illogical, inefficient ways to go through life.  In southern California, where I live, we prepare for earthquakes after they strike. This approach has proven highly ineffective, but by now it's tradition and, if I'm not mistaken, required by state law.  Apparently, putting the cart before the horse is normal human behavior, even though carts are getting hard to find these days. The consequences may be greatest where interpersonal relationships are concerned, which is why the divorce rate runs higher than voter turnout. 7. PROCRASTINATION  Interestingly, the beginning and ending of ``procrastination'' are ``pro'' and ``nation.' Someone who is ``pro-nation'' is called a patriot, and every four years can be found at the Olympic wrestling venue waving a flag the size of a fumigation tent.  How, you might ask, does all this relate to the habit we call procrastination? Well, it doesn't, really, but this little linguistic digression has enabled me to put off writing anything meaningful about procrastination, a task I've been dreading.  And that's the true spirit of procrastination, isn't it _ avoiding what we don't want to do? Of course, 90 percent of life is ``what we don't want to do,'' which is why we so diligently devote ourselves to the other 10 percent.  But there's a blessing in all this. Putting off changing the oil in your car, for example, leads to costly repairs, which triggers self-loathing, which results in erratic behavior, marital discord, counseling, divorce-lawyer fees and so forth. A lot of money changes hands, which stimulates the economy, which results in a higher gross national product.  So if you put off changing your motor oil, take heart: You're not just a procrastinator, you're a patriot.  (Lee Green is a Ventura, Calif.-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960129.0475 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-SEXUAL-STRUGGLES-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WHEN SEX STOPS By PEPPER SCHWARTZ c.1995 McCall's magazine (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  One of the main expectations of married life is that a husband and wife will be sexually intimate. And most couples are.  As a researcher, however, I've seen a disturbing trend: A substantial number of married couples _ up to 10 to 15 percent _ have sex only a few times a year, or not at all.  How does this happen? When most couples get married, they are highly romantic, and their desire and attraction for each other are intense. But in some marriages the passion quickly fades; sex may prove unsatisfying _ even physically painful _ and the couples abandon it, although they may preserve the more fulfilling parts of the relationship.  Other sexless couples lose the urge over time, often as the result of conflicts over child care or work being played out in the bedroom. But whatever the reason, most experts agree that when a couple no longer makes love, the marriage is headed for trouble.  THE BIGGEST SEXUAL TURNOFFS: ANGER AND VENGEANCE  It's not easy to guess which couples aren't having sex. Charlotte (names have been changed to protect privacy), a great-looking woman in her mid-30s, hardly seems a likely candidate for the problem.  A former college beauty queen and part-time model, she's been married for the past 11 years to Jim, a dashing politician. When you see them together, you'd assume they have a pretty wonderful sex life.  In fact, Jim and Charlotte haven't had sex for almost a year and a half, and their physical relationship in the preceding two years was minimal at best.  ``We were very passionate back when we were courting,'' Charlotte remembers.  What happened? The reason Charlotte no longer wants to have sex with Jim is that her almost constant anger with him has blocked her feelings of arousal.  ``As it became clear that he wanted me only when it was convenient, I got more and more turned off. He'd reach over to me almost as an afterthought and want sex _ not lovemaking.  Jim is furious with Charlotte for denying him the emotional and physical relief he craves. He doesn't have affairs, but he openly threatens that he might if Charlotte doesn't ``get her act together.''  Still, Jim doubts that they'll ever divorce.  ``I'm not going to leave my kids,'' he insists. ``Besides, Charlotte is a great mother and a wonderful political wife. We really do very well with one another except when we're alone in the bedroom.''  Jim and Charlotte know they have problems, and they've gone to a marriage counselor a few times. It hasn't helped. Jim felt that the sessions resulted in ``Jim bashing'' and, after trying a couple of different therapists, they've given up.  Sadly, this is the most common pattern of sexless marriages _ a relationship where there's a lot of anger and two people who simply don't know how to change their behavior.  WHEN THERE'S LOVE (BUT NOT DESIRE)  Some women with minimal sexual experience get involved with a man without realizing that good chemistry is missing.  Others are seduced by the excitement of knowing someone is attracted to them _ and overlook the fact that what they feel in response is tepid. Later these women can become so turned off by sex with their husband that the best they can do to preserve the marriage is avoid having sex altogether.  That's the case with Juanita, 30, a vibrant beauty who is alternately depressed by her eight-year marriage to Christopher and accepting of it.  When they met in college, he was courtly, polite and absolutely smitten with her. The first man in her life not to pressure her for sex right away, he treated her with respect and made sure her needs and ambitions were given the same serious consideration as his own.  They didn't have sex before their wedding night, but Juanita wasn't a virgin _ her only other lover had broken her heart by having an affair. So Juanita was especially happy to find a man like Christopher, someone who wanted sex between them to be special and sacred.  The first signs of trouble for the couple surfaced on their honeymoon. Christopher had difficulty getting an erection; he also experienced premature ejaculation. Juanita was philosophical at the time. She figured it was just a bad case of first-night jitters.  But things didn't get better. After seeing a marriage counselor and a sex therapist, Christopher went to a medical doctor to see if there was a physical reason for his problems. When the tests indicated there wasn't, Christopher and Juanita gave up hope.  Over time their physical relationship did improve enough for Juanita to get pregnant. But sex in general has remained an unpleasant experience. And after their daughter was born, their sex life dwindled away.  Though not satisfied with the situation, Juanita is resigned to it:  ``I feel that I'm too young to not have sex, but then I'm lucky to have such a fine man, so it's a compromise. I suppose life itself is a compromise.''  I JUST CAN'T STAND THE WAY HE TOUCHES ME  Linda, a flight attendant in her mid-30s, faces a different challenge in her marriage _ she so hates the way her husband, John, makes love that three years ago she said never again.  The problem: John is an insensitive lover.  ``I used to get all black and blue,'' Linda says. ``I'd tell him he had to be gentler, but he never changed. In time, I flinched at his touch _ I was always being manhandled.''  In other ways Linda is satisfied with her marriage. John makes a good living as an attorney and is a caring father. Despite his admirable qualities, though, he's become totally unappealing to her. Unfortunately, though, while time, familiarity and therapy can improve a couple's sex life, basic physical repulsion is difficult to overcome.  As might be expected, Linda's lack of desire for her husband has resulted in arguments and coolness in the relationship. But while Linda has no desire for John, the feeling isn't mutual.  ``I just can't help it. If he went elsewhere for sex, I would really understand, although I pray he doesn't break up the family, because we both really believe in that.''  NOT INTERESTED, THANKS  Of course, there are rare situations when both husband and wife agree that sex is no longer important to them. While more typical among older couples, this can happen to people in their 30s and 40s as well.  Trudy, a computer-industry production worker, and her husband, Bruce, a letter carrier, both of whom are 40, never had much of a sex life, even in the beginning of their 18-year marriage.  Though they made love once or twice a week in their first year as newlyweds, ``I never felt the earth move,'' Trudy admits.  Over the next couple of years sex decreased to perhaps once a month, then more irregularly until they realized at last that they weren't making love at all anymore.  ``At first we were worried,'' Trudy says. ``We went to a marriage counselor, who gave us some exercises that made us feel ridiculous.  I know this isn't politically correct to say, but I think society has made a big deal out of sex, and there are a lot of people afraid to admit it. In fact, if people were honest, many would say they can get by just fine without it.''  THE BOTTOM LINE: CAN SEXLESS MARRIAGES SURVIVE?  Obviously some couples, like Trudy and Bruce, make peace with little or no sex. Generally, however, abstinence takes a high toll on a relationship. The partners become angry and start to think about having affairs or getting divorced.  This is especially true for husbands; little or no sex bothers men much more than women.  In a study I conducted of more than 5,000 American couples, more women than men said they were satisfied with their marriage even when sex had disappeared entirely from the relationship. Men, on the other hand, were much more likely to say they were dissatisfied when sex was disappointing or absent.  Is there hope for couples who aren't having sex? Most will need some kind of therapist or counselor to help rid the marriage of the underlying emotional or relationship issues that are causing their problems. There may even be a sexual dysfunction that needs medical attention.  One thing is certain: Ignoring the situation won't make it go away.  Masters and Johnson, the noted sex therapists, say couples must either ``use it or lose it,'' and they're right. If women don't make love for long periods of time, it becomes harder for them to have an orgasm or to feel uninhibited. Men who abstain from sex often develop arousal problems and other performance anxieties.  The good news is that sex can resume in a marriage. Even women who have avoided it are amazed at the stirrings within them once love and trust are reestablished.  (Pepper Schwartz is a Seattle, Wash.-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960129.0476 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-CELEBRITY-VALENTINES-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> STAR VALENTINES: COUPLES WHO MET ON THE SET (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Warren Beatty and Annette Bening in a scene from ``Love Affair.'' World rights except Chicago. By CINDY PEARLMAN Distributed by New York Times Special Features  Kevin Bacon was on the set of the 1987 PBS movie ``Lemon Sky'' when it happened. He saw this beautiful actress with a tangle of blonde curly hair _ and fell head over heels in love.  ``I kept reminding myself, `Kevin, this is not a good idea. Kevin, stop it,''' he recalls.  But he couldn't stop. He thought about this woman day and night.  ``We had a kissing scene and I was in heaven,'' he says. ``Sometimes it's movie kissing. This was kissing kissing.''  Bacon knew, of course, that relationships that begin on movie sets are usually doomed. But that didn't stop him from asking his lovely co-star, Kyra Sedgwick, for a few dates while they were shooting. What was the harm?  When the dates led to a romantic relationship, Bacon figured it would be over soon.  ``Falling in love on a movie set is like summer camp,'' Bacon explains. ``The rule is that you have to remind yourself that in eight weeks it will be over. It's not real life. There probably won't be a happy ending.''  Famous last words. Bacon and Sedgwick's love affair eventually led them to the altar. They now have two kids and couldn't be happier.  And they aren't the only celebrity couples whose relationships began after they met on the set. Here's a look at some of the other famous lovebirds who will be celebrating Valentine's Day together this year:  THE COUPLE: Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid  THE SET: ``Innerspace'' (1987)  LOVE NOTES: When Meg met Dennis ... it was true terror, she says.  ``I was just beginning my career and thought, `This is very bad. I can't fall in love.'  ``Yet I couldn't stop staring at him. I kept thinking to myself, `He is beautiful. Look how nice he looks in that shirt!'''  The two later married and went on to co-star in 1993's ``Flesh and Bone.''  THE COUPLE: Lauren Holly and Jim Carrey  THE SET: ``Dumb and Dumber'' (1994)  LOVE NOTES: Holly believes she was fated to get together with the man whose face seems to made of Silly Putty.  ``We met when I auditioned for the first `Ace Ventura,''' she says, referring to Carrey's 1994 hit film. ``It's so bizarre. I was in the middle of breaking up with someone and I met Jim during the audition and I thought, `Who is this guy?'  ``I didn't watch (Carrey's TV series) `In Living Color.' I remember thinking to myself, `Wow, he's tall and he's cute.'''  She didn't get the part, but a year later she was cast as Carrey's co-star in ``Dumb and Dumber.''  ``It seems fated that we did `Dumb and Dumber' together and fell in love,'' Holly says. ``Our first date was on the set. I remember we went to a restaurant in Utah and there were peacocks and things wandering around the property. It was very romantic and beautiful until Jim started doing peacock faces.''  THE COUPLE: Warren Beatty and Annette Bening  THE SET: ``Bugsy'' (1991)  LOVE NOTES: Beatty, a confirmed bachelor, wasn't looking to get hitched. Then something unexpected happened.  ``I remember that we needed to cast a very strong actress but weren't happy with anyone we saw,'' Beatty recalls. ``I heard of this Annette Bening and saw a couple of her films. Now this was an actress!  ``So we decided to do something very low-key and go out for a quick pizza dinner to discuss the project. I knew within five minutes that this was a very special woman. She just radiated joy.''  The two fell in love while making that film and later married. They now have two children and, in 1994, they co-starred in the appropriately named ``Love Affair.''  THE COUPLE: Timothy Hutton and Uma Thurman  THE SET: ``Beautiful Girls,'' which is scheduled to be released nationwide Feb. 16  LOVE NOTES: Hutton, who is divorced from actress Debra Winger, says he doesn't believe in love at first sight.  ``I believe in an incredible connection at first sight. Love is something that happens over a period of time.''  He spent a period of time with Thurman on the very cold Minnesota set of ``Beautiful Girls.'' In one scene, in an ice-fishing shack, Hutton's character tries to pick up Thurman's.  ``Our dating does change the irony of that scene now,'' he says. ``Believe me, we really didn't know each other when we shot that scene.''  But he had always wanted to meet her.  ``When I heard they wanted Uma to do this movie, I was so hoping that would happen because I always really liked her as an actress,'' he explains. ``There's just something about her that makes you realize she's smart, interesting and beautiful.  ``When she arrived on the set I said to myself, `This is just great!'''  THE COUPLE: Hugh Grant and Elizabeth Hurley  THE SET: ``Rowing With the Wind,'' a 1986 British film  LOVE NOTES: Grant vividly recalls his first thoughts when he met the now-famous supermodel.  ``I thought that she was acting very ratty to me on the set,'' he says. ``I was acting very ratty to her. We were both being disagreeable, so it must have been true love.''  No wedding yet but no funeral for the relationship _ even after Grant's summer escapade on Los Angeles' Sunset Boulevard. Word is that Grant and Hurley are about to start work on a movie together.  THE COUPLE: John Travolta and Kelly Preston  THE SET: ``The Experts'' (1989)  LOVE NOTES: ``She was married to someone else at the time we met on this set,'' Travolta says. ``So you kind of resist love at first sight when you know these things. What I admired is that she loved being married.  ``After the initial crush, I would say the relationship was an evolution. A few years later, in 1991, I found myself proposing in Switzerland at midnight. It was almost like a movie.''  THE COUPLE: Kate Capshaw and Steven Spielberg  THE SET: ``Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' (1984)  LOVE NOTES: Capshaw had to phone home about this one. She called all her girlfriends to tell them about this dream of a director she had met during an audition.  ``It was like I knew. I just knew,'' Capshaw says with a sigh. ``I remember meeting Steven and thinking, `This is it.' Then, of course, he got married to someone else, which just killed me. But it all worked out in the end.  ``I remember from the first day on that set thinking, `He is so wonderful. I hope this movie never ends.'''  THE COUPLE: Melanie Griffith and Antonio Banderas  THE SET: ``Two Much,'' which is scheduled to be released in March  LOVE NOTES: Banderas plays a man who pretends to be his own twin in order to romance two sisters. In real life, he fell in love with only one woman: Griffith.  ``I cannot probably even describe this love,'' he says. ``Who can describe love? It's like describing life. I just knew there was something inside me that was stronger than myself. You just can't stop it.''  THE COUPLE: Gwyneth Paltrow and Brad Pitt  THE SET: ``Seven'' (1995)  LOVE NOTES: ``It was such a dark movie and Gwyn was like this ray of sunshine,'' Pitt says. ``She's so very special.''  While accepting his Golden Globe award this year, Pitt thanked ``his angel,'' referring to Paltrow as the love of his life.  THE COUPLE: Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman  THE SET: ``Days of Thunder'' (1990)  LOVE NOTES: He played a race-car driver. She was his doctor. The diagnosis: L-O-V-E.  Cruise laughs as he recalls, ``Dustin Hoffman called me after I started dating Nicole and said, `She is beautiful. She's talented. What is she doing with you?'''  Now his wife, Kidman has taught Cruise ``so many things,'' he says.  ``She really is a best friend. She taught me to literally go out and smell the flowers. Nic enjoys gardening and tells me to get out there and start picking weeds. Sometimes I can't believe this woman left her family in Australia to be with me.''  THE COUPLE: Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson  THE SET: ``Volunteers'' (1985)  LOVE NOTES: ``I was this wisenheimer guy and she was this wisenheimer girl,'' Hanks says. ``We went out and had fun together. At first it was just friends and then I had to say, `Whoa! This is better than friends.'''  The two, now married, recently celebrated the birth of their second child.  THE COUPLE: Kim Basinger and Alec Baldwin  THE SET: ``The Marrying Man'' (1991)  LOVE NOTES: So what if tabloids reported that they were prima donnas on the set? So what if the movie flopped? Basinger knew their romance was a big hit.  ``It's amazing that we got together, since Alec is such a people person,'' she says. ``He likes to go out and do lunch and be in a crowd. I like to hide in my house. I'm so shy.  ``But he gave me the courage to explore my fears. It was so liberating and exhilarating.''  The husband-and-wife actors, who also co-starred in ``The Getaway'' (1994), are new parents of a baby girl. -0- SIDEBAR: RELATIONSHIPS THAT FADED TO BLACK  Some couples meet on the set, act out real-life love scenes and then yell, ``Cut!''  These twosomes decided to let their on-set relationships fade to black:  THE COUPLE: Kelly LeBrock and Steven Seagal.  THE SCRIPT: They met on the set of 1990's ``Hard to Kill,'' got married and later divorced.  THE COUPLE: Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder.  THE SCRIPT: They met on the set of 1990's ``Edward Scissorhands,'' began a romance and broke up about two years later.  THE COUPLE: Brad Pitt and Juliette Lewis.  THE SCRIPT: They met on the set of 1993's ``Kalifornia,'' became lovers and then broke up about a year later.  THE COUPLE: John Malkovich and Michelle Pfeiffer  THE SCRIPT: They reportedly began a romance on the set of 1988's ``Dangerous Liaisons'' but broke up a few months later.  THE COUPLE: Jeff Goldblum and Geena Davis  THE SCRIPT: After meeting on the set of 1989's ``Earth Girls Are Easy,'' they married. Then came the divorce.  THE COUPLE: Julia Roberts and Kiefer Sutherland  THE SCRIPT: They met on the set of 1990's ``Flatliners'' and nearly got married before Roberts called it off. (Roberts also had failed romances with Liam Neeson, whom she met on the set of 1988's ``Satisfaction,'' and Dylan McDermott, whom she met on the set of 1989's ``Steel Magnolias.'')  THE COUPLE: Whoopi Goldberg and Ted Danson  THE SCRIPT: They met on the set of 1995's ``Made in America'' and had a much-publicized relationship that eventually ended.  THE COUPLE: Liz Taylor and Richard Burton  THE SCRIPT: They began a relationship on the set of 1963's ``Cleopatra'' _ and we all know how that one turned out. -0- c.1996 Cindy Pearlman  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based free-lance writer.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960129.0477 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-THORN-BIRDS-AMANDA-DONOHOE-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> AMANDA DONOHOE: TV'S NEW `THORN BIRD' (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Amanda Donohoe in a scene from ``The Thorn Birds: The Missing Years.'' By JEANNE WOLF Distributed by New York Times Special Features  Provocative. Outspoken. Feisty. Independent.  Those are just a few of the labels that have been attached to actress Amanda Donohoe.  Never one to shy away from controversy or challenge, she clinched her reputation as a maverick when she began portraying one of prime-time television's first bisexual characters: attorney C.J. Lamb on ``L.A. Law.'' Donohoe caused a national sensation when she planted a kiss on the lips of co-star Michele Greene in one memorable episode.  Now Donohoe is attracting attention again, stepping where other actresses might fear to tread. For the new NBC miniseries ``The Thorn Birds: The Missing Years'' (airing Feb. 11 and 13), Donohoe has taken over the role that made Rachel Ward a household name. She stars as Meggie O'Neal, the woman who fell in love with a priest (played by Richard Chamberlain) in 1983's ``The Thorn Birds.''  While Chamberlain is reprising his portrayal of the conflicted Father Ralph de Bricassart in the four-hour sequel, Ward turned down the offer to step back into the role of his lover. That opened the door for Donohoe, who jumped at the chance to offer viewers her own version of Meggie.  ``I don't know if viewers will be critical of me or not, but I hope they'll at least be curious enough to tune in,'' Donohoe says during an interview in a suite at a Pasadena, Calif., hotel. ```The Thorn Birds' is such a wonderful classic love story, like a `Romeo and Juliet,' that I don't think it makes a difference who plays the main characters. It's the story that's important.''  Interestingly, Donohoe has never seen the original production, which was watched by millions worldwide in the '80s.  ``I didn't watch `The Thorn Birds,' even though it was a huge success in England, where I was living,'' she says. ``In fact, there was a commercial break right after the scene where Father Ralph and Meg make love, and I remember that all over the U.K. there was a huge power surge as people got up from their TV sets and rushed to plug in their electric kettles to make a cup of tea.''  After snaring the role of Meggie, Donohoe purposely avoided watching Ward's performance.  ``You always feel insecure when you take on a new role,'' she says. ``I think to give yourself more insecurity by watching how somebody else played the part would be suicidal.''  One thing that helped Donohoe's performance was the support of Chamberlain.  ``He never once made me feel like I was stepping into someone else's shoes,'' she says. ``Richard is such a sweetie and he has a wonderful sense of humor.''  Both stars needed a sense of humor for the sequences in which Father Ralph and Meggie reignite their passion after a crisis brings him back to her home in the Australian outback.  ``When it came to our love scene,'' Donohoe recalls with a grin, ``we said, `OK, we'll give you the beginning, the middle and the end. You know, a little foreplay, intercourse and then orgasm. ... We just sort of did it in three acts and it was very funny. The hard part was trying to keep a straight face.''  Filming love scenes is always a bit difficult, Donohoe says.  ``Even if you find the guy you're doing it with attractive, it doesn't help. In fact, sometimes it makes it worse. You're simulating sex with a virtual stranger and you can either get embarrassed or you can laugh. I choose to laugh, but sometimes I'm thinking, `What a way to make a living!'''  She may have thought that more than once during her career, which has featured a string of unconventional roles. In one of her earliest films, Nicolas Roeg's ``Castaway'' (1987), she played a woman who answers an ad to spend a year on a desert island with a chauvinistic adventurer. She spent most of her onscreen time naked.  Then, in 1988, she got worldwide attention as the vampirish Lady Sylvia Marsh in Ken Russell's outrageous horror-comedy ``The Lair of the White Worm.''  But it was ``L.A. Law'' that made Donohoe famous.  ``More people saw me play C.J. on television than all the characters I'd played in films,'' she says. ``I certainly hadn't realized the power of prime time. We had an enormous audience.''  And while the viewers in that audience were sometimes shocked by C.J.'s bisexual antics, they enjoyed watching her each week.  ``In spite of her sexual ambiguity, people seemed to love her,'' she says. ``She was funny, accessible and interesting. People used to come up to me and say that C.J. was the sort of person they'd like to have for a best friend. Nobody had ever said that about any other character I'd played.''  For Donohoe, the road to American TV stardom began in her bedroom in the middle-class suburban London home in which she grew up.  ``My imagination was my escape and my survival,'' she says. ``I used to create `Dynasty' and `Dallas' with my dolls. I wasn't an avid reader, but I had a very vivid life in my imagination that was stimulated mostly by movies and television.''  At one point, she wanted to be Vivien Leigh.  ``I watched `Gone With the Wind' about 150 times,'' she says with a smile. ``A lot of the movies that were on TV when I was a kid were from the '30s, '40s and '50s. Women were very strong characters in a lot of those films. I think I grew up with a very strong sense of my femaleness because of those films.''  That strong sense of self helped when she decided to quit school at 16 to study acting. Over the next few years she had a romantic relationship with rock star Adam Ant and became active in anti-establishment causes.  Even when she began to succeed in films, Donohoe maintained her reputation for speaking out forthrightly on subjects ranging from nuclear disarmament to better roles for women in Hollywood.  Donohoe enjoys being independent, even though she feels that trait has contributed to the fact that, at 33, she is single.  ``I've always been very driven, very ambitious,'' she says. ``I think it can be very intimidating when a woman really knows her mind and understands her sexuality. That can be very threatening to men who'd rather have you shut up and go back to the kitchen sink. Men in general are intimidated by strong women and that's unfortunate.''  Though Donohoe is occasionally lonely, she's also ambivalent about the idea of spending the rest of her life with one man.  ``I think I've had a terror of being trapped in a marriage _ with children _ that I didn't want to be in,'' she says. ``There's that fear of making a mistake. I've seen so many divorces and so many dysfunctional families.''  As a single woman, Donohoe is able to commute easily between homes in Santa Monica and London and to work as much as she wants to. Most recently she received respectable reviews for her juicy turn as the crafty lady-in-waiting in the critically acclaimed ``The Madness of King George'' and starred in a sequel to ``Shame'' for the USA cable network, playing a maverick biker/lawyer.  Donohoe admits, however, that she may be mellowing a bit.  ``I surprised myself at some of the things I've done in my career,'' she says. ``I don't think I'm as brave as I used to be. I don't need to stand up on that soapbox and shout about things so much. I don't need to break down the walls anymore, and I've done that in my career.  ``I'm getting happier and happier,'' she continues reflectfully after a long pause. ``It has nothing to do with my work. It has a lot to do with my own process of self-discovery.  ``I said, `Why am I having such awful relationships? Why am I behaving so badly?' It was a rather long and agonizing process, but I think I'm well on the road. It's all a process of discovery.'' c.1996 Jeanne Wolf  (Jeanne Wolf, who is based in Hollywood, reports on the entertainment industry for television, radio and print outlets.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) Another case study in United Nations futility. By Barbara Crossette.  OKINAWA (Tokyo) _ Japanese prosecutors demand 10-year prison terms for three American servicemen accused of the rape of an 12-year-old Okinawan girl. Such a, a crime that sparked nationwide resentment against American military bases in Japan. By Andrew Pollack.  YUGOSLAVIA-BOSNIA (Sarajevo) _ After missing deadline on prisoner exchanges, both sides appear to have caught up and put the implementation of the peace accord back on schedule. By Kit Roane.  RUSSIA-U.S. (Washington) _ Chernomyrdin visits, meets with Gore. By Jere Longman.  NUNS-MURDER (Watervile, Me.) _ Developments in the killing of the two nuns. By Fox Butterfield.  BURY-SETTLE (Undated) _ Settlement is reportedly reached in the O'Keefe/Loewen Group funeral home case. By Richard Bernstein.  CHICAGO-JUVENILE ( Chicago) _ Judge to decide in case of two 12-year-olds who dropped a friend out of a 12-story building because he wouldn't steal for them. Question is whether they should remain in a low-security juvenile facility, where they'll get psychiatric counseling, or whether they need to be in a juvenile lockup.  KERVORKIAN-SUICIDE (Detroit) _ Two weeks before he is to face trial for assisting in two 1993 suicides, Dr. Jack Kevorkian has apparently struck again. The body of a 48-year-old Wisconsin was found outside the medical examiner's office, this time in his battered 1968 Volkswagen van.  NJ-WHITMAN (Trenton, N.J.) _ Gov. Whitman delivers her budget message. By Jennifer Preston. By George James.  MCALARY-LIBEL (New York) _ Judge hears arguments for dismissal in libel case involving columnist Mike McAlary. By Don Van Natta. A group of the unwilling, picked from the unfit, to do the unnecessary.''  _Richard Harkness, The New York Times, 1960.  QUESTIONS WOMEN ASK, AND THE ANSWERS NOT TO GIVE-III  ``Do you love me?''  How NOT to answer:  1. I suppose so.  2. Would it make you feel better If I said yes?''  3. That depends on what you mean by `love.' ''  4. Does it matter?''  5. Who, me?''  CALIFORNIA CLASSIFIED  Friends at the Valley Press in Palmdale, Calif., sent us a copy of the latest in full-service child care. After all, it IS Caliornia.  ``WANTED: TEACHER.  KinderCare _ The first name in quality child-care, has immediate openings for experienced teacher of infant, toddler or school-age children. Enthusiasm, and caring attitude, ability to neuter &AMP; stimulate youngster necessary.  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  If Congress really makes assault weapons legal again, can't an exception be made for most campaign ads?  _(Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star)  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S ``THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO''  ``Here's some good news! The Los Angeles man who was struck by lightening last week is okay. It was one of those freak accidents, I guess, God was aiming for O.J. and missed.''  ``Here is something kind of odd. A Canadian football team ... did you hear what happened? I guess they mistakenly drafted a dead player in the recent college draft. The good news is that they managed to trade him to the New York Jets. So it worked out fine.''  ``Michael Jackson announced that he plans to go into business with a Saudi Arabian prince. Together they are going to open up a chain of Michael Jackson motels. Of course the great thing about Michael Jackson motels -- `Kids stay free'!''  ``They've formed a company they say will promote traditional family values. Oh, yeah. I mean nothing says family values more to me than a middle-aged man in full makeup grabbing his crotch and walking backwards, dressed like a Klingon general.''  ``Before we get started with the regular show I have an announcement from Pacific Edison: Please conserve electricity because they are going to need all the extra volts this spring for the Menendez brothers.''  I got to tell you, when they read that verdict the Menendez brothers did not break down. They didn't even cry. Their Dad would have been so proud.''  ``It looks like old Pat Buchanan lost out. He did not get it. What will he do next? Well, don't feel sorry for Pat. He's got a lot of crosses in the fire.''  ``Buchanan is still campaigning in California. He says that he is looking for a California miracle. Today he got it: a Mexican American said hello to him.''  ``Have you seen this new Amtrak ad? I guess they are really on a big push now. They show this man and a woman riding on Amtrak and the guy says, ``Is this heaven or what?'' If it's not, Amtrak will get you there soon enough.  QUOTABLES FROM ``WEEKEND UPDATE'' ON NBC'S ``SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE''  ``In Los Angeles this week, Lyle and Erik Menendez were found guilty of first degree murder. So, to review California law, it's: killing your wife - legal; killing your parents - illegal.''  ``This week after 50 hours of failed budget talks with Bill Clinton, a frustrated Bob Dole said, `We ought to have a new president,' adding, `and he should be very very old.'''  ``In other political news, Texas billionaire Ross Perot announced this week that if his party wants him to run for president, he will. According to insiders, it's the first step in Perot's plan to waste the last few years of Bob Dole's life.''  ``Yesterday on `Rivera Live,' Kato Kaetlin made the startling admission that he now thinks O.J. Simpson is guilty. Although authorities suspect this may just be part of an attempt by Kato to crash at Fred Goldman's.''  ``In Paris, pop star Michael Jackson has announced a deal with a Saudi Prince to launch an international chain of `virtual-reality wedding chapels.' Making this the most normal thing Michael Jackson has ever done.''  ``Filming has finally begun on the long-awaited life story of Evita Peron, staring pop singer Madonna. According to its producers, the film is 100 percent historically accurate, except for the part where Mrs. Peron has group sex with the Houston Rockets.''  ``This winter the state of Maine had a record 260 snowmobile accidents, most of them caused by drinking and speeding. Although, if you're not drinking and speeding, what's the point of riding a damn snowmobile.''  The following quotes are from ``Saturday Night Live's'' segment ``Spade in America.''  ``Elisabeth Shue is up for best actress. Yeah, right. If hookers really looked this hot, Charlie Sheen would be bankrupt.''  ``Best Actor nominee Massimo Troisi literally lost his life shortly after filming `Il Postino.' Why can't Sylvester Stallone make this sort of commitment?''  ``Brad Pitt is up for best supporting actor. His movie was just released in Italy, under the title `Senor, Getsa Lotsa Poona Tanga.'''  ``After his wedding this month, The Artist Formerly Known as Prince is said to be mulling over another name change. Rumor has it he now wants to be called, `I Can't Believe It's Not Prince.'''  ``The `George and Alana' morning show has been canceled due to low ratings. Network insiders say it simply couldn't compete with the six people who watch `Mike and Maty.'''  ``Woody Allen will not be attending the Oscars this year. Instead, he will be doing the same thing he does every Monday night -- having sex with his stepdaughter.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! VIDEO PROTEST </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> SAN FRANCISCO (BC-OJ-VIDEO-HNS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199603.gz"
"53221"	"I"	"guess"	" Rated: PG-13 _ mature themes, violence, confrontational language </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960325.0645 type=other > <DATELINE>  (BC-NY-NYLITE(SMILE)-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> c.1996 N.Y. Times News ServiceNo. 1792 Thu., March 21, 1996 (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  REAL HEADLINES THAT WERE AND WISH THEY WEREN'T-II  JUVENILE COURT TO TRY SHOOTING DEFENDANT  COLD WAVE LINKED TO TEMPERATURES  KIDS MAKE NUTRITIOUS SNACKS  INCLUDE YOUR CHILDREN WHEN BAKING COOKIES  SOME PIECES OF ROCK HUDSON SOLD AT AUCTION  HOSPITALS ARE SUED BY 7 FOOT DOCTORS  FOOD FOR THOUGHT  ``I am not a vegetarian because I love animals; I am a vegetarian because I hate plants.''  _Unknown  ``What is a committee? A group of the unwilling, picked from the unfit, to do the unnecessary.''  _Richard Harkness, The New York Times, 1960.  QUESTIONS WOMEN ASK, AND THE ANSWERS NOT TO GIVE-III  ``Do you love me?''  How NOT to answer:  1. I suppose so.  2. Would it make you feel better If I said yes?''  3. That depends on what you mean by `love.' ''  4. Does it matter?''  5. Who, me?''  CALIFORNIA CLASSIFIED  Friends at the Valley Press in Palmdale, Calif., sent us a copy of the latest in full-service child care. After all, it IS Caliornia.  ``WANTED: TEACHER.  KinderCare _ The first name in quality child-care, has immediate openings for experienced teacher of infant, toddler or school-age children. Enthusiasm, and caring attitude, ability to neuter &AMP; stimulate youngster necessary.  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  If Congress really makes assault weapons legal again, can't an exception be made for most campaign ads?  _(Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star)  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S ``THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO''  ``Here's some good news! The Los Angeles man who was struck by lightening last week is okay. It was one of those freak accidents, I guess, God was aiming for O.J. and missed.''  ``Here is something kind of odd. A Canadian football team ... did you hear what happened? I guess they mistakenly drafted a dead player in the recent college draft. The good news is that they managed to trade him to the New York Jets. So it worked out fine.''  ``Michael Jackson announced that he plans to go into business with a Saudi Arabian prince. Together they are going to open up a chain of Michael Jackson motels. Of course the great thing about Michael Jackson motels -- `Kids stay free'!''  ``They've formed a company they say will promote traditional family values. Oh, yeah. I mean nothing says family values more to me than a middle-aged man in full makeup grabbing his crotch and walking backwards, dressed like a Klingon general.''  ``Before we get started with the regular show I have an announcement from Pacific Edison: Please conserve electricity because they are going to need all the extra volts this spring for the Menendez brothers.''  I got to tell you, when they read that verdict the Menendez brothers did not break down. They didn't even cry. Their Dad would have been so proud.''  ``It looks like old Pat Buchanan lost out. He did not get it. What will he do next? Well, don't feel sorry for Pat. He's got a lot of crosses in the fire.''  ``Buchanan is still campaigning in California. He says that he is looking for a California miracle. Today he got it: a Mexican American said hello to him.''  ``Have you seen this new Amtrak ad? I guess they are really on a big push now. They show this man and a woman riding on Amtrak and the guy says, ``Is this heaven or what?'' If it's not, Amtrak will get you there soon enough.  QUOTABLES FROM ``WEEKEND UPDATE'' ON NBC'S ``SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE''  ``In Los Angeles this week, Lyle and Erik Menendez were found guilty of first degree murder. So, to review California law, it's: killing your wife - legal; killing your parents - illegal.''  ``This week after 50 hours of failed budget talks with Bill Clinton, a frustrated Bob Dole said, `We ought to have a new president,' adding, `and he should be very very old.'''  ``In other political news, Texas billionaire Ross Perot announced this week that if his party wants him to run for president, he will. According to insiders, it's the first step in Perot's plan to waste the last few years of Bob Dole's life.''  ``Yesterday on `Rivera Live,' Kato Kaetlin made the startling admission that he now thinks O.J. Simpson is guilty. Although authorities suspect this may just be part of an attempt by Kato to crash at Fred Goldman's.''  ``In Paris, pop star Michael Jackson has announced a deal with a Saudi Prince to launch an international chain of `virtual-reality wedding chapels.' Making this the most normal thing Michael Jackson has ever done.''  ``Filming has finally begun on the long-awaited life story of Evita Peron, staring pop singer Madonna. According to its producers, the film is 100 percent historically accurate, except for the part where Mrs. Peron has group sex with the Houston Rockets.''  ``This winter the state of Maine had a record 260 snowmobile accidents, most of them caused by drinking and speeding. Although, if you're not drinking and speeding, what's the point of riding a damn snowmobile.''  The following quotes are from ``Saturday Night Live's'' segment ``Spade in America.''  ``Elisabeth Shue is up for best actress. Yeah, right. If hookers really looked this hot, Charlie Sheen would be bankrupt.''  ``Best Actor nominee Massimo Troisi literally lost his life shortly after filming `Il Postino.' Why can't Sylvester Stallone make this sort of commitment?''  ``Brad Pitt is up for best supporting actor. His movie was just released in Italy, under the title `Senor, Getsa Lotsa Poona Tanga.'''  ``After his wedding this month, The Artist Formerly Known as Prince is said to be mulling over another name change. Rumor has it he now wants to be called, `I Can't Believe It's Not Prince.'''  ``The `George and Alana' morning show has been canceled due to low ratings. Network insiders say it simply couldn't compete with the six people who watch `Mike and Maty.'''  ``Woody Allen will not be attending the Oscars this year. Instead, he will be doing the same thing he does every Monday night -- having sex with his stepdaughter.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!)  Looking for contributors with wit, style, depth, charm and genius with jokes, anecdotes, humorous news items, bonus NYLite offerings, or filler material.  Dr. NYLite will respond with a GENUINE New York Times rolling writer-style pen if your item is used. REAL HEADLINES THAT WERE AND WISH THEY WEREN'T-II  JUVENILE COURT TO TRY SHOOTING DEFENDANT  COLD WAVE LINKED TO TEMPERATURES  KIDS MAKE NUTRITIOUS SNACKS  INCLUDE YOUR CHILDREN WHEN BAKING COOKIES  SOME PIECES OF ROCK HUDSON SOLD AT AUCTION  HOSPITALS ARE SUED BY 7 FOOT DOCTORS  FOOD FOR THOUGHT  ``I am not a vegetarian because I love animals; I am a vegetarian because I hate plants.''  _Unknown  ``What is a committee? A group of the unwilling, picked from the unfit, to do the unnecessary.''  _Richard Harkness, The New York Times, 1960.  QUESTIONS WOMEN ASK, AND THE ANSWERS NOT TO GIVE-III  ``Do you love me?''  How NOT to answer:  1. I suppose so.  2. Would it make you feel better If I said yes?''  3. That depends on what you mean by `love.' ''  4. Does it matter?''  5. Who, me?''  CALIFORNIA CLASSIFIED  Friends at the Valley Press in Palmdale, Calif., sent us a copy of the latest in full-service child care. After all, it IS Caliornia.  ``WANTED: TEACHER.  KinderCare _ The first name in quality child-care, has immediate openings for experienced teacher of infant, toddler or school-age children. Enthusiasm, and caring attitude, ability to neuter &AMP; stimulate youngster necessary.  BILL'S WORLD  By Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  If Congress really makes assault weapons legal again, can't an exception be made for most campaign ads?  _(Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star)  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S ``THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO''  ``Here's some good news! The Los Angeles man who was struck by lightening last week is okay. It was one of those freak accidents, I guess, God was aiming for O.J. and missed.''  ``Here is something kind of odd. A Canadian football team ... did you hear what happened? I guess they mistakenly drafted a dead player in the recent college draft. The good news is that they managed to trade him to the New York Jets. So it worked out fine.''  ``Michael Jackson announced that he plans to go into business with a Saudi Arabian prince. Together they are going to open up a chain of Michael Jackson motels. Of course the great thing about Michael Jackson motels -- `Kids stay free'!''  ``They've formed a company they say will promote traditional family values. Oh, yeah. I mean nothing says family values more to me than a middle-aged man in full makeup grabbing his crotch and walking backwards, dressed like a Klingon general.''  ``Before we get started with the regular show I have an announcement from Pacific Edison: Please conserve electricity because they are going to need all the extra volts this spring for the Menendez brothers.''  I got to tell you, when they read that verdict the Menendez brothers did not break down. They didn't even cry. Their Dad would have been so proud.''  ``It looks like old Pat Buchanan lost out. He did not get it. What will he do next? Well, don't feel sorry for Pat. He's got a lot of crosses in the fire.''  ``Buchanan is still campaigning in California. He says that he is looking for a California miracle. Today he got it: a Mexican American said hello to him.''  ``Have you seen this new Amtrak ad? I guess they are really on a big push now. They show this man and a woman riding on Amtrak and the guy says, ``Is this heaven or what?'' If it's not, Amtrak will get you there soon enough.  QUOTABLES FROM ``WEEKEND UPDATE'' ON NBC'S ``SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE''  ``In Los Angeles this week, Lyle and Erik Menendez were found guilty of first degree murder. So, to review California law, it's: killing your wife - legal; killing your parents - illegal.''  ``This week after 50 hours of failed budget talks with Bill Clinton, a frustrated Bob Dole said, `We ought to have a new president,' adding, `and he should be very very old.'''  ``In other political news, Texas billionaire Ross Perot announced this week that if his party wants him to run for president, he will. According to insiders, it's the first step in Perot's plan to waste the last few years of Bob Dole's life.''  ``Yesterday on `Rivera Live,' Kato Kaetlin made the startling admission that he now thinks O.J. Simpson is guilty. Although authorities suspect this may just be part of an attempt by Kato to crash at Fred Goldman's.''  ``In Paris, pop star Michael Jackson has announced a deal with a Saudi Prince to launch an international chain of `virtual-reality wedding chapels.' Making this the most normal thing Michael Jackson has ever done.''  ``Filming has finally begun on the long-awaited life story of Evita Peron, staring pop singer Madonna. According to its producers, the film is 100 percent historically accurate, except for the part where Mrs. Peron has group sex with the Houston Rockets.''  ``This winter the state of Maine had a record 260 snowmobile accidents, most of them caused by drinking and speeding. Although, if you're not drinking and speeding, what's the point of riding a damn snowmobile.''  The following quotes are from ``Saturday Night Live's'' segment ``Spade in America.''  ``Elisabeth Shue is up for best actress. Yeah, right. If hookers really looked this hot, Charlie Sheen would be bankrupt.''  ``Best Actor nominee Massimo Troisi literally lost his life shortly after filming `Il Postino.' Why can't Sylvester Stallone make this sort of commitment?''  ``Brad Pitt is up for best supporting actor. His movie was just released in Italy, under the title `Senor, Getsa Lotsa Poona Tanga.'''  ``After his wedding this month, The Artist Formerly Known as Prince is said to be mulling over another name change. Rumor has it he now wants to be called, `I Can't Believe It's Not Prince.'''  ``The `George and Alana' morning show has been canceled due to low ratings. Network insiders say it simply couldn't compete with the six people who watch `Mike and Maty.'''  ``Woody Allen will not be attending the Oscars this year. Instead, he will be doing the same thing he does every Monday night -- having sex with his stepdaughter.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! POLITICS (p)  PRIMARY-CALIFORNIA (Los Angeles) _ Bob Dole is expected to clamp a lock on the GOP nomination by trouncing his sole remaining competitor, columnist Patrick Buchanan. By Adam Pertman. 750 words.  PRIMARY-DOLE (Russell, Kan.) _ Bob Dole goes home to Russell, Kan., and his roots for a victory celebration. By Jill Zuckman. 600 words.  w/  DOLE-ABORTION (Washington) _ National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League holds news conference to discuss Sen. Robert Dole's record on abortion. By Ann Scales. 600 words.  LABOR-ENDORSE (Washington) _ Delegates from the AFL-CIO's 78 unions decide whether to endorse President Clinton for re-election. By John A. Farrell. 750 words.  NATIONAL (a)  CANCER-CYBER KNIFE (San Francisco) _ Stanford researchers test ``cyber knife'' that delivers radiation to tumors more precisely than previously. By Richard Saltus. 600 words.  AVALANCHE-DEATHS (Undated) _ Investigators identify victims of Pinkham Notch avalanche. By Kate Zernike. 900 words.  SHOOTOUT-ARREST (Undated) _ Man wounded a year ago when he and two accomplices attempted to rob a Brinks armored truck gives up. By Judy Rakowsky. 700 words.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e)  TV-CARVEY (Undated) _ Face it: Dana Carvey's show is burning out so quickly that Carvey should consider new sponsorship. ``The Comet Hyakutake Dana Carvey Show,'' anyone? By Frederic M. Biddle.  FINANCIAL (f)  GENYZME-FDA (Undated) _ Genzyme awaits ruling by FDA advisory panel on whether its Seprafilm product should be approved for abdominal and pelvic surgeries. By Ronald Rosenberg. 600 words.  HYDE-JONES (Undated) _ Hyde Athletic Industries receives a preliminary injunction to prevent triathlete Michellie Jones from promoting Reebok International Ltd.'s sneakers and apparel. By David Halbfinger.  SPORTS (s)  BKC-KENTUCKY (Lexington, Ky.) _ Kentucky's most fearsome tactic is its overpowering, all encompassing, mind-boggling press. By Mark Blaudschun.  w/  BKC-UMASS (Lexington, Ky.) _ By Joe Burris.  w/  RYAN-COLUMN (Undated) _ For George G. (Trigger) Burke, being the No. 1 UMass Basketball Fan is a title he guards fiercely. By Bob Ryan.  HKC-NCAA-FOUR (East Lansing, Mich.) _ Neither coaches nor players have ever seen anything like The Shot Heard 'Round the Hockey World. By Allen Lessels.  BBA-REDSOX (Clearwater, Fla.) _ Alex Delgado is talking about wearing No. 77 in the big leagues one day. By Nick Cafardo.  BKN-CELTICS (Boston) _ Three successive losing seasons as a Celtic is not what Rick Fox had in mind when he joined the franchise. By Frank Dell'Apa  SKATE-GALINDO (Undated) _ Rudy Galindo understands that politics and personalities undeniably affect the judging, but the people who skate best usually win. By John Powers.  RUN-BOSTON (Boston) _ The countdown to the 100th Boston Marathon that begins on April 15 at High Noon by the Village Green in the town of Hopkinton is on course, and the fine tuning has been completed.
