Non-Olympics stories are listed below.  Stories are moving in category shown at end of each budget item.  Olympics  EDITORS: Below are five stories from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Every item is moving to Sports queues. WARNING: Some stories also will move to other departments of your newspaper as indicated by a category letter in parenthesis at the end of the item. Copy is handled in Atlanta by Tom Bennett at 404-526-5471. Photos and graphics are available through the NYTNS. For copy reruns, call the Cox Washington Bureau at 202-331-0900. For further information, call Jim Bentley, managing editor of the Cox News Service, at 912-635-3650.  OLY-CYCLING _ DALLAS _ USA Cycling's dream machine for the 1996 Olympics is plastered with the corporate logos of sponsors, but none breaks the flawless, supersmooth surface of the bike's red, white and blue frame. (s)  OLY-AMBUSH _ ATLANTA _ Two heavyweights _ the Olympic movement and the U.S. Postal Service _ are sparring over several Games-related issues, including commemorative T-shirts and stamps, mail service at the Olympic Village and the sale of stamps on traffic-congested streets come July. The dispute, which revolves around alleged ``ambush marketing,'' may end up in court. (s)  OLY-TRAIN _ YUMA, Ariz. _ Olympic Torch Relay security officials were being especially vigilant Tuesday as the flame boards a 19-car Union Pacific train here for the first of 3,500 miles it will travel by rail. The section of track from Yuma through the cactus-studded Painted Rock Mountains into Phoenix is where an Amtrak train was deliberately derailed last October, killing one person and injuring scores of other. (s)  OLY-HOMELESS _ ATLANTA _ Activists held an unusual sit-in at Woodruff Park to call attention to a lack of public toilets in Atlanta that they say will inconvenience the city's homeless as well as thousands of Olympic visitors. (s)  OLY-TORCH _ CAMPO, Calif. _ The owner of the Ice Cream Place, a roadside establishment in this windswept desert outpost, was so excited about the Olympic Torch Relay's visit that she raised three American flags and asked her soft drink supplier to make up a welcoming banner. (s)  Lifestyle, Entertainment  ASK-THE-DOC _ undated _ TAKING CARE: When things don't get better, get help. (l)  NETWATCH.X-FILES _ undated _ Fans can lose themselves in `X-Files' search. (e)  NETWATCH.NEWS _ undated _ Your URL or mine? Send your avatar _ a thumbnail image you choose to represent yourself _ over the World Wide Web. Your avatar can chat and gesture to others when it reaches the site of your choice. That's the promise of Virtual Places, introduced last week by GNN, America Online's Web subsidiary. (l)  National  PRAYER _ undated _ Americans celebrate the National Day of Prayer on Thursday, continuing a tradition older than the U.S. Constitution. It's a practice rich with history and now controversy. (a)  PRAYER-CHART _ undated _ While Americans may have differing views about public prayer, surveys show that a vast majority pray privately. (a)  MORIAL-QNA _ undated _ At 38, New Orleans Mayor Marc Morial is one of the youngest leaders of a major American city. One of his first acts upon taking office two years ago was to establish a curfew for juveniles. In the first year of the curfew, 3,900 youths were detained for violations and total juvenile crime dropped by 27 percent. (a)  PASTORS-2takes _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Pastors are real people and sometimes they need help too. Some denominations are offering pastors counseling for depression and other problems. (a)  TOXIC _ PENSACOLA, Fla. _ Environmental agency offers plan to move residents from shadow of `Mount Dioxin'. (a)  CDC _ ATLANTA _ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director David Satcher, who will present Congress with a $2.5 billion 1997 budget request Wednesday, is expected to come armed with statistical ammunition to fight off critics who have launched a spirited attack to kill his agency's violence prevention efforts. (a)  Business  FARMING _ ATLANTA _ Farmers moving from traditional endeavors into more unusual crops. (f)  FARMING-TURF _ ATLANTA _ If you had told Larry Johnson 10 years ago that he would make a living growing grass, he would have considered you crazy. Now the peanut and cotton farmer turned turf grower laughs at the transition, describing the needs and qualities of grasses from Bermuda to zoysia. (f)  MACNEWS _ undated _ MAC NEWS: New utilities package simplifies some chores. (f)  Sports  See Olympics section.  BISHER-COLUMN _ UHWARRIE POINT, N.C. _ Reunions, I guess, are the surest form of realizing the relentlessness of passing years. This was not a reunion as such. Bill Hensley, my public relations friend, had this brainstorm about getting together a collection of old North Carolina comrades of various ages and past connections, guys who don't see a lot of each other any more, for a little golf, some beer and barbecue. So we gathered on the shore of Badin Lake, which used to be the largest mudhole I'd ever seen when I was growing up about 12 miles away. (s)  Commentary  SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ Even if I have to wrap myself in an old shower curtain just to keep from getting arrested on the way to the mailbox, I am through with shopping. As a matter of fact, doing hard time on bread and water would be a lot more enjoyable than what I went through yesterday. (k)  For answers or resends, call the Cox News Service at 202-331-0900. (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. From Let's Live magazine By KATHY SENA c.1995 Kathy Sena (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  When Monica Lewis found out she was pregnant with her first child, she planned to eat only well-balanced meals and snack on plenty of fruits and vegetables, she recalls.  But, thanks to a three-month bout of morning sickness, it wasn't that easy.  ``As it turned out, I could eat macaroni and cheese and applesauce and that was about it for my first trimester,'' says Lewis, now the mother of a healthy 3-year-old daughter.  When you're pregnant, eating right can sometimes be a challenge. Of course, you want to do what's best for your baby and yourself. You've already heard about what you shouldn't consume during the nine months of pregnancy: caffeine, alcohol and cigarettes.  But, what should you put into your body during this crucial time? Which vitamins and minerals does your developing baby need? Can certain foods or herbs ease some of the uncomfortable side effects of pregnancy? And what can you do to ease morning sickness _ which affects more than half of all pregnant women? VITAMINS ARE IMPORTANT  Taking specific prenatal vitamins and minerals can not only make a difference in the health of an unborn baby, it can also help ease some of the most common discomforts of pregnancy.  Here are some important prenatal vitamins and minerals:  _ Folic acid:  Doctors agree that folic acid (a B vitamin) is one of the most important vitamins a mother-to-be can take.  Since 1992, the U.S. Public Health Service has recommended that all fertile women should consume 0.4 milligrams of folic acid per day from foods such as legumes and dark, leafy green vegetables or supplements.  Folic acid helps ward off neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, in the developing fetus. In 1993, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration announced that folic acid could probably prevent half of the 2,500 cases of neural tube defects that occur each year in the United States.  _ Vitamin B6:  ``It has been shown that taking a vitamin B6 supplement is effective in reducing severe morning sickness in pregnancy,'' says M. Sara Rosenthal, author of ``The Pregnancy Sourcebook'' (Lowell House, 1994).  Unfortunately, Rosenthal notes, the vitamin doesn't seem to have any effect on mild-to-moderate nausea.  _ Vitamin D:  This vitamin helps to ensure proper absorption and uses of calcium and phosphorus in the diet, says William H. Lee, a registered pharmacist and author of the handbook, ``How Do I Know If I Need Vitamins, and If I Do Which One?'' (Lee Press, 1991).  _ Iron:  This mineral is essential for prevention of anemia in both mother and baby during pregnancy, experts say.  _ Vitamin B complex, calcium and magnesium:  Feeling a little stressed? These vitamins and minerals can help normalize the emotional ups and downs that often occur during pregnancy, Lee says.  It's important to note that too much of certain vitamins can be harmful to the developing fetus. Women should always consult their doctors to determine the correct vitamin dosage. WHAT CAN HERBS DO TO EASE PREGNANCY DISCOMFORT?  According to Jeanne Rose, author of ``Herbs and Aromatherapy for the Reproductive System'' (Frog Ltd., 1994), the following herbal teas can provide helpful benefits during pregnancy.  _ Raspberry leaf contains fragarine (a uterine tonic/relaxant) and is a standard herb used as a tea throughout pregnancy and lactation.  _ Basil, catnip, chamomile, peppermint and raspberry leaf teas are considered to be antispasmodic and can help alleviate morning sickness.  _ Basil, lavender and nutmeg teas are recommended by midwives at birthing time.  _ Alfalfa, comfrey leaf, fennel seed and nettle tops herb teas can encourage milk production.  There are other prenatal uses for herbs besides tea, according to Rose. For instance, aromatherapy can be soothing during both pregnancy and labor, she says.  _ Chamomile and lavender essential oils, inhaled via a diffuser or simply from a handkerchief, will often bring relief from nausea.  Note that the handkerchief must be kept in a plastic bag so the essential oils won't evaporate.  _ Basil and lavender oils may be inhaled for stimulation and relaxation, respectively, during labor.  Rose notes that certain herbs should be avoided or used with caution during pregnancy.  ``Some herbs have strong medicinal qualities that may harm the developing fetus,'' she warns. Women are best advised to talk with their doctors about which herbs are right for them. WHAT TO DO FOR MORNING-NOON-AND-NIGHT SICKNESS  Morning sickness puts 50,000 women a year in the hospital and affects more than half of all pregnant women, according to Miriam Erick. Erick is a boston-based, nationally recognized expert on morning sickness and co-writer (with Liz Weiss) of the video, ``Morning Sickness All Day &AMP; All Night _ A 24-Hour Survival Guide for Pregnant Women and Their Families'' (Lemon-Aid Films Inc., 1994).  Morning sickness doesn't just happen in the morning, Erick says. If it becomes severe, the nausea resulting from morning sickness can cause a woman to vomit up to 15 times a day. In turn, this can disrupt her metabolism, deplete her of fluids and make her anemic. Some women have even broken ribs or ruptured blood vessels by dry heaving.  However, there are ways to reduce morning sickness:  _ Know the facts.  Many pregnant women are told that morning sickness is all in their heads, but many experts believe it is caused by an increase in hormones, especially estrogen. Morning sickness can actually be a good sign that these hormones are protecting the developing fetus, Erick says.  However, if women don't experience morning sickness, there's no need to worry, she notes.  _ Think snacks, not meals.  ``Small feedings of soup _ such as a shotglass of soup at a time _ with bread every 15 minutes will usually work,'' says Mark Decker, an obstetrician in private practice in West Bend, Wis.  _ Avoid unpleasant odors.  ``I call it the `radar nose of pregnancy,''' Erick laughs, describing the enhanced sense of smell many pregnant women notice.  Almost any normal smell can suddenly trigger nausea in a woman who's suffering from morning sickness. Even a formerly favorite smell, such as fresh-brewed coffee, can cause nausea.  The fresh, natural smell of lemon helps many women overcome the symptoms of morning sickness, Erick reports. Simply cutting a lemon in half and breathing in the scent can often immediately relieve nausea.  _ Try liquid-filled foods.  ``We all need 2 quarts of fluids every day,'' Erick says. But, if the idea of drinking that much liquid is more than most women can stand, they should look for foods that contain water, such as apples, celery sticks, pears and watermelon.  _ Eat what sounds good.  While women certainly want to maintain a healthy diet during pregnancy, if they're battling an especially tough case of morning sickness, ``this is the time to think about what sounds good,'' Erick says.  ``Eat what you want at the moment, even if it's lemonade or spicy chicken.''  This unconventional approach struck Erick when she asked her patients to describe what appealed to them when they were feeling nauseous. She found the responses varied widely, including spicy, crunchy, bitter, hot and fruity foods.  _ Don't worry about cravings.  During this time it's not uncommon for women to crave foods they never liked before they were pregnant.  ``The most important thing is to take in fluids and calories,'' Erick says.  _ Wake up slowly.  If possible, women should try to rearrange their work days so they don't have to rush in the morning, Weiss suggests. The jolt of a loud alarm clock can be enough to cause nausea while pregnant.  Also, getting plenty of rest can help lessen the effects of morning sickness.  _ Don't be surprised if morning sickness lasts beyond three months.  Morning sickness that lasts for 17 weeks is about average.  ``Twenty percent (of pregnant women) have morning sickness for nine months,'' Erick says.  The most important thing for women to do is work together with their doctors, she emphasizes.  ``If you consume no food or drink for 24 hours; or, if the volume of your urine is greatly reduced, see your doctor.''  Women may need to receive intravenous fluids to avoid further dehydration. Some obstetricians treat dehydration due to morning sickness by administering intravenous solutions in the office, according to Decker.  As long as women visit their health practitioners regularly and avoid severe dehydration by drinking enough liquid to ensure they urinate a few times each day, Decker says, ``You really can't starve your baby.''  (Kathy Sena is a Los Angeles-based free-lance writer.) (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960819.0360 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-KIDS-IN-SPORTS-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> SHOULD PARENTS PUSH KIDS TO GO FOR GOLD, OR JUST FOR FUN? (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives: (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. From Child magazine By MARTHA RADDATZ c.1996 Martha Raddatz (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  After the Olympic Games in Atlanta, the dream of a gold medal permeated kids' minds. But is it a goal to which they should aspire? That depends on whether the desire is athletic fulfillment or athletic fame.  According to Mary Kirk, associate professor of physical education at Northern Kentucky University in Highland Heights and author of a recent study on organized sports, many parents and coaches ``are pushing their kids too early and too far,'' increasing both the physical and psychological risks.  Once the pressure is removed, however, the benefits can be vast. Research has long shown that boys develop important skills from competitive sports, including an ability to work with a team, to perform under pressure, to set goals and to accept criticism.  The news is even more encouraging for girls. A study by the Women's Sports Foundation in East Meadow, N.Y., revealed that girls involved in sports are less likely to use drugs or get pregnant and more likely to graduate from high school. MODERN CONCERNS  After a decade of couch-potato habits and alarming rates of childhood obesity, it's refreshing to hear that more kids are participating in organized recreational or competitive sports _ more than 20 million, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) in Chicago.  ``Organized sports have grown tremendously,'' confirms Sally S. Harris, a pediatrician with the Palo Alto Medical Clinic in California and chairwoman of the AAP section on sports medicine.  ``It's become more difficult for kids to participate in informal activities because of the structured way families live nowadays, so signing them up for leagues and lessons has taken the place of neighborhood pickup games.''  While many parents want their kids to get involved out of a love of sports, there is yet another, more modern reason: to fill the time when parents are at work.  Charles Pine of Seattle, father of 6-year-old twins Zachary and Jonathan, signed up his sons for tennis and swimming lessons when they turned 5. Because he and his wife both work, Pine likes to keep the twins busy with outside activities.  ``This makes us feel that we aren't leaving them in daycare, so it takes some pressure off,'' the father admits.  Parental convenience aside, organized sports offer something essential to young children.  ``Physical skills are not only crucial to development, but they provide simple, timeless fun,'' explains CiCi Nielsen, head teacher at the New Milford, Conn., Head Start Center.  Fun seems to be the key in developing a healthy attitude. According to sports psychologist Jim Loehr, the Orlando, Fla.-based author of ``Toughness Training for Life'' (Dutton, 1993), athletic fulfillment begins as play, something children are equipped to do from birth.  ``Making sports a job at a young age is the exact opposite of what sports should be _ just plain fun,'' he emphasizes. IS YOUR CHILD READY?  The AAP recommends waiting until children are age 6 before letting them begin competitive team sports.  ``Prior to that, kids do best in a nonstructured environment where they can experiment with different skills,'' Harris says. ``At this early age, they don't respond to repetition or coaching. And no amount of practice will speed up the development of their coordination.''  Does that mean a 3- or 4-year-old shouldn't take gymnastics or play soccer?  No, Harris says, ``as long as they're allowed to play at their developmental level. It's when we expect them to compete and strategize like adults that the trouble begins.''  While kids exhibit sports readiness _ through their ability and enthusiasm _ at many different ages and stages, parents should expose them to basic physical activities such as running, jumping, balancing and kicking by the early grade-school years. If these motor skills are not developed by about age 8, your child won't be able to keep up with other kids at a time when sports become a form of socializing, Loehr says.  Kids who get a slow start in sports may be labeled uncoordinated; but, Harris notes, don't let them give up trying because ``they could catch up with the others eventually.'' DANGERS ON THE FIELD  A healthy dose of sports may be a fun way to keep kids active, but parents shouldn't discount the safety risks, either.  According to the Scottish Rite Children's Medical Center in Atlanta, sports injuries in children ages 6 through 13 are on the rise. Many of the injuries, the center reports, are occurring because of intensive training schedules, long playing seasons, poor equipment and specialty camps that emphasize single-sport training.  ``We're seeing more and more overuse injuries,'' Harris says, ``which used to be rare in children.''  Some examples: stress fractures of the lower back in gymnasts, inflammation of the heel in soccer players, tendinitis and bursitis of the shoulder in swimmers and baseball players and tendinitis of the shoulder and elbow in tennis players.  Why the rise in sports injuries to kids? Most experts agree that pressure is a major reason. Kirk found that ``not all kids are ready for a competitive environment, and some parents and coaches don't recognize this as a problem.''  In Kirk's study, 49 percent of the children lacked the fundamental skills needed for the sports in which they were participating.  Remarkably, that's the same percentage of kids that have significant cardiac risk factors, such as obesity, high blood pressure, high cholesterol and an inactive lifestyle, according to a study by the National Association of Sports and Physical Education in Reston, Va. PERFORMANCE PRESSURES  The National Alliance for Youth Sports in West Palm Beach, Fla., takes the charge of ``too much too soon'' even further.  ``The physical and emotional stresses placed on some youngsters amount to child abuse,'' says Fred Engh, president of the nonprofit organization.  ``Because of the professional atmosphere created in children's athletics these days, parents and coaches simply lose perspective. When the child doesn't live up to expectations, emotions can go wild.''  Allan Overland, a Seattle tennis pro, has witnessed parents telling their children, ``If you don't win, don't bother asking me for a ride home.''  Overland is currently coaching the Pine twins, Zachary and Jonathan. Because he is a twin himself and knows how competitive they can be, Overland suggested that the boys take separate lessons and that their father not attend.  ``I agreed with the coach that they do better when I don't watch,'' Pine says, adding that he has a tendency to ``push it'' with the boys, so he forces himself to restrain his instincts.  ``I know they want to please me,'' Pine says. ``They get concerned if they don't feel I'm happy.''  That attitude would be a red flag for Cynthia Smith, a coach for young children at Hill's Gymnastics in Gaithersburg, Md., where 19-year-old gymnast Dominique Dawes trained before competing in the Olympics.  ``I've had parents who insist that their 5-year-old daughter work out five days a week because they are convinced the child is the next great Olympian,'' Smith says.  But inevitably, these are the children who develop problems.  ``If they are doing it for someone else instead of themselves, they will not reap any benefits,'' she emphasizes. CREATING A WIN-WIN SITUATION  Not all parental involvement in kids' sports is bad. Like a lot of fathers, Dan Gjelten of St. Paul, Minn., had a vision of his son, Arne, 9, playing ``really good baseball or hockey.'' He signed Arne up at an early age, but it soon became obvious that his son was not terribly competitive.  Gjelten fought his instincts to push Arne by ``remembering how difficult it was for me when I was a kid. My goal is to show Arne the joys of physical fitness,'' Gjelten says. ``He doesn't have to win.''  Little League coach Clay Jensen of El Sobrante, Calif., thinks playing team sports can be an invaluable experience. His ball players have gone on to high school with higher grade-point averages and a greater interest in school activities.  ``Instead of getting into trouble on the streets, these kids have developed their athletic abilities and their self-confidence,'' Jensen says.  This is certainly a goal for all young athletes, and one that experts feel can be attained if care and caution are applied to the physical and psychological aspects of sports. Teach your children the joy of movement and competitive play, Loehr recommends, and you will give them the greatest gift you can give: a head start on a lifetime of fitness, health and happiness.  (Martha Raddatz is a contributing editor of Child magazine and a reporter with National Public Radio. She lives in Washington, D.C.)  ------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960819.0361 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-DERMOT-MULRONEY-`TRIGGER EFFECT'-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> NO MORE MR. NICE GUY: DERMOT MULRONEY IN `THE TRIGGER EFFECT' (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Dermot Mulroney in a scene from ``The Trigger Effect.'' By IAN SPELLING (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  ``You saw `Survival Quest?''' Dermot Mulroney says with a laugh, referring to a movie made in 1989, ``I'm impressed.  ``I've been in big films no one saw and small films that weren't supposed to get seen but did. But `Survival Quest,' that's a small film no one saw.''  Indeed, the actor's resume includes ``Sunset'' (1988), a Bruce Willis film gone awry; ``Young Guns'' (1988), an independent film bought by a major studio and transformed into a hit; ``Longtime Companion'' (1990), a critically adored independent film that turned a profit; the duds ``Career Opportunities'' (1991) and ``The Thing Called Love'' (1993); and the winners ``Living in Oblivion'' (1995) and ``How to Make an American Quilt'' (1995).  ``I've been on deck as `the next big thing' for 11 years, and I think it's a bunch of crap,'' Mulroney, 32, says during a phone interview from his Los Angeles home. ``For me, the reward of what I do is doing it.  ``I long ago gave up hoping my movies go through the roof or caring whether people like them. If I made that stuff part of what I'm doing this for, I'd be insane, if not just bitter.  ``Instead, I just enjoy my life and work and try to be as good as I can be. I don't pressure myself, because I already get paid handsomely and I've always been able to pursue the roles that interest me.''  The latest role to interest Mulroney is Joe, a key character in the drama ``The Trigger Effect,'' which will open nationwide on Aug. 30. The film was written and directed by David Koepp, whose screenwriting credits include ``Jurassic Park'' (1993) and ``Mission: Impossible.''  ``Trigger'' presents the question: How would people react if, in a major American city, all lights, phones, radios, TV sets, etc., mysteriously went dead one night?  That's precisely the situation which an upwardly mobile young couple _ Matt (Kyle MacLachlan) and Annie (Elisabeth Shue) _ and their friend Joe find themselves.  Suddenly, their neighbors are a potential menace, and it takes armed robbery just to get medicine for Matt and Annie's baby.  Joe makes an edgy situation even edgier by buying a gun and by generating a sexual heat with Annie that threatens her marriage.  ``This is a dark movie, which is what I love about it,'' Mulroney says. ``It's powerful but subtle, and Koepp never really tells you, `This is what you're supposed to be thinking.'  ``He really leaves it to the audience to decide what's going on, to find in it how they'd relate to a similar situation.  ``I like the feeling of impending doom. Anything horrible can happen to anybody at any time, and it's a challenge to play that without overdramatizing it or, on the other hand, completely sanitizing it.  As for Joe, Mulroney reports that he appreciated the changes the character undergoes. When night comes, average Joe reveals his true colors.  ``He's misleading,'' Mulroney says. ``He's this T-shirt-wearing nice guy, but he doesn't make the right decisions at the right moment, especially when he buys the gun.  ``Joe gives you the impression of being very capable, of being an `I can handle it' guy. But how he handles things doesn't help his friends or him.''  Mulroney says Koepp did a nice job of bringing the script to life, but he saves his greatest praise for his co-stars.  He and MacLachlan had worked together before, briefly, on the ensemble film ``Where the Day Takes You'' (1992). Mulroney had never met Shue before they began filming ``Trigger.''  ``Elisabeth is great, and we spent a lot of time figuring out how far to go with the attraction between Annie and Joe. Kyle makes the movie, though, which is a good thing because it's about a passive man who has to become decisive when his family needs him.''  And how does Mulroney act in a real-life crisis?  ``The closest I've come to a real crisis was when we had the earthquake in L.A.,'' he says. ``(During a crisis) I find myself being really calm, which isn't to say I always make the right decisions.  ``I don't experience a lot of fear,'' he adds. ``I like heights, I like small, crowded rooms and I'm not stricken by phobias of any sort. It's not in my makeup.''  That makeup was formed in 1963, when Mulroney was born in Alexandria, Va. He began acting in a neighborhood troupe at age 7 and stayed with it through high school and during his college years at Northwestern University in Illinois.  At the end of Mulroney's senior year at Northwestern, an agent from William Morris visited the school.  ``This was on the heels of (the success of) John Malkovich, Glenne Headly and Laurie Metcalf, who all came out of Steppenwolf,'' Mulroney says, referring to the Chicago theater group that launched several of today's highly respected actors. ``So, the hunt was on for more Chicago prospects.''  Mulroney met with the agent and performed a scene from Sam Shepard's play ``Fool for Love.''  ``I did my thing, and she said, `Sign here,' then shipped me out to L.A.,'' Mulroney recalls, laughing. ``I moved out here in August, 1985, and got my first job on Jan. 4, 1986.  ``It was a TV movie called `Sin of Innocence,' with Bill Bixby and Dee Wallace, and I was the male lead. So I didn't start out with bit parts and work my way up, which was an interesting experience.  ``I was thrown right into the fire.''  Since then, Mulroney has worked steadily in a variety of television and movie projects.  ``When you look at the things I've done, there are some wild ones, good and terrible, but most of them have a great spirit and were fun to make,'' he says. ``I've met some extraordinary people, and that's what I look for when I consider what to do next.''  By Mulroney's side for the better part of his career has been his wife, actress Catherine Keener, whom he met while shooting ``Survival Quest,'' and who can be seen in the current release ``Walking and Talking.''  ``We've been married six years, and she's the greatest,'' he says. ``We got together six months after finishing the film and we've been together ever since.''  The couple acted together again most recently in ``Oblivion.''  Mulroney can currently be seen in the new Robert Altman film, ``Kansas City.'' He plays Johnny O'Hara, a small-time 1930s hood kidnapped by big-time gangster Seldom Seen (Harry Belafonte) in retaliation for robbing one of Seen's best customers.  O'Hara's wife, Blondie (Jennifer Jason Leigh), responds by kidnapping Carolyn Stilton (Miranda Richardson), a socialite with ties to Seen.  ``Oh man, to be in an Altman film, I just about fell over when I got the call,'' Mulroney says enthusiastically. ``Talk about a plum role.  ``The whole thing was amazing, being in Kansas City, the period costumes, working with that cast and Altman. A lot of people may not get the story, but that's their problem.''  Mulroney's latest project is ``My Best Friend's Wedding,'' a comedy co-starring Julia Roberts.  The film is being shot in Chicago, but Mulroney's enjoying a few days off in Los Angeles, where he's performing with his band, the Low and Sweet Orchestra.  ``We do punk-folk music, I guess,'' Mulroney says when asked to describe the band's sound. ``I play the mandolin and cello and sing backup.''  In ``Wedding,'' Mulroney and Roberts play best pals and former college paramours who struck a deal that if they weren't married by age 28, they'd marry each other.  Right around Mulroney's 28th birthday, he calls Roberts to inform her that he's getting married.  ``That drastically affects Julia's life, and she does everything she can to throw a wrench into my wedding to Cameron Diaz,'' Mulroney says. ``We're not exactly inventing the wheel in terms of the story, but it's a romp and very romantic.  ``I'm marrying Cameron and Julia wants me. Big problems I've got, right?  ``And I get PAID to do this stuff.''  c.1996 Ian Spelling  (Ian Spelling is a New York-based free-lance writer.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960819.0362 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-TESTING-`RELATIVITY'-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ABC DECIDES TO PUT `RELATIVITY' TO THE TIME-SLOT TEST (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Kimberly Williams and David Conrad, the stars of ``Relativity.'' By CINDY PEARLMAN c.1996 Cindy Pearlman World rights except Chicago. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  On a blazing hot summer day in the corner of a Culver City, Calif., sound stage, Kimberly Williams and David Conrad are proving there is one major requirement to filming their new ABC series ``Relativity'': strong lips. The two actors have been necking for hours.  ``I have never done so many kissing scenes in my life,'' Williams later reports. ``It has gotten to the point where I have lotion to put on my chin after a few takes.''  Director Mark Piznarski informs them that they can finally break their lip lock. This is a cut.  He announces, ``Well, I'm going to stop rolling the camera. You guys can stop kissing whenever you want to ... You can really stop kissing now.''  On the TV drama, Conrad and Williams play two people who are mad about each other. And the ABC network is mad about ``Relativity,'' which premieres this fall.  While most other proposed drama series were kissed off by the network, this one is being given four weeks at the prized and lofty ``NYPD Blue'' Tuesday-night time slot (10 p.m. Eastern Standard Time) to pick up an audience.  Some might remember that that's the old ``thirtysomething'' time slot, which is fitting because ``Relativity'' comes from the critically acclaimed team of Marshall Herskovitz and Edward Zwick, who created that yuppie drama, as well as the beloved but short-lived ``My So-Called Life.''  Over coffee in Washington, D.C., where he has come to promote his summer hit film ``Courage Under Fire,'' director-producer Zwick says the duo was looking to get back into television.  ``We have a deal with ABC to provide three series,'' he says. ``Relativity'' is the second of those post-``thirtysomething'' projects.  ``Relativity'' is about Isabel Lukens (Williams), a beautiful and smart 24-year-old from Los Angeles who runs away to Rome to mull over a marriage proposal from her boyfriend, the slightly dweeby and controlling Everett Moreland (Randall Batinkoff).  While sightseeing, she runs into the adorable Leo Roth (Conrad), who, coincidentally, is also from Los Angeles and is in Rome to get over his mother's death.  It's love at first sight, but when the vacation is over both return to Los Angeles to face the music.  ``This is more than the story of a young couple,'' Zwick says. ``It's based on the Freudian premise that when two people go to bed together there are six people in the room. It's about a young couple and their families.''  Behind the scenes, Herskovitz and Zwick are heavily involved with the show. However, they say, the ``voice'' of the show belongs to co-executive producer and writer Jason Katims.  Katims met Herskovitz and Zwick when he was hired to work on ``My So-Called Life.'' A New York City playwright, Katims wrote a few scripts for ``My So-Called Life'' and ended up as a story editor. Last spring he co-wrote the David Schwimmer film ``The Pallbearer'' (1996).  After ``My So Called Life'' was cancelled, he expected his TV run to end. But Zwick and Herskovitz made him an offer he couldn't refuse.  ``They simply said, `Wanna do a new show?''' Katims recalls during a telephone interview from the set of ``Relativity.''  Katims explains how the scripts evolved.  ``I started writing the first script with a young couple's wedding day,'' he says. ``Then Ed and Marshall said, `Why cheat the audience out of the days, weeks and months that lead up to a wedding? There are all those pivotal and sometimes shocking events, such as the families meeting. Think of all that drama.'''  Zwick is quick to point to the series' depth, ``The show is more the anatomy of this relationship. They're in love with each other, but this couple doesn't really know each other.''  Prior to shooting, the difficult task was finding the perfect couple. In the case of Williams, best known for her role as Steve Martin's daughter in the ``Father of the Bride'' movies, she had auditioned for an upcoming movie called ``The Honest Courtesan'' directed by Herskovitz for a 1997 release.  ``Of course, we had seen `Father of the Bride' (1991) and thought she was perfect for the series,'' Herskovitz says during a telephone interview. ``She's a rare talent. When you work with her it's interesting because people see that face and think she isn't acting, that she's just being herself. That's not true. This woman can act.''  Casting Leo was more troublesome.  ``We did a huge search,'' says Zwick, who along with Katims found Conrad on an audition tape sent to them by ABC.  ``We were on our fourth tape and his audition was buried in between 20 other guys','' Katims says. ``After looking at 60 actors, the whole thing is really a blur, but we noticed a real wonderful heartfelt quality in David.''  Williams and Conrad did a reading together and it was instant chemistry. But, like any good soap opera, will there be a glitch?  Katims says the relationship will have bumps.  ``They'll have all the normal concerns such as `When should we move in together? Do I really want to be with your family? How will we deal with our different religious and ethnic backgrounds? Should we get married?'''  Will they say ``I do''?  That has not been decided, Katims says.  ``The approach we're taking is improvisational. We'll see what happens between the characters to determine their future. We don't have any particular plans.''  One plan from ABC is to move the series to Saturday nights after the initial four-week run on Tuesdays. Herskovitz says he's ``reserving judgment'' about the time slot.  ``It's possibly OK. We're not experts on programming decisions. I hope it proves to be a boost for us.''  ``I think we'll have more time to build an audience on Saturday night because the expectations won't be so high,'' Katims says.  Expectations have always been high for Zwick, a native of the Chicago suburbs, and Herskovitz, who hails from Philadelphia.  ``Ed and I met at the American Film Institute,'' Herskovitz recalls. They were directing fellows in 1975.  ``We saw each other as mutual threats and ended up becoming friends. It's been an amazing partnership,'' Zwick says.  Both worked on the series ``Family'' and the Emmy Award-winning ``Special Bulletin.''  Zwick has a feature-film-directing career that includes ``About Last Night'' (1986), ``Glory'' (1989) and ``Courage Under Fire'' (1986).  Herskovitz directed ``Jack the Bear'' (1993) and the upcoming ``The Honest Courtesan,'' starring Jacqueline Bisset and Catherine McCormack.  As for their success on ``thirtysomething,'' Zwick says, ``We never expected the show to take off. I always thought it would have limited appeal.''  ``We were aware some people couldn't stand the show. It was strange that even people who hated it would still analyze it,'' Herskovitz says.  As for the much-awaited ``thirtysomething'' reunion special, don't hold your breath.  ``We'll do it eventually, but we don't know when,'' Herskovitz says. ``I don't think you'll be seeing `A Very ``thirtysomething'' Thanksgiving Special' this year.''  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based entertainment writer) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448; fax: 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960819.0363 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-ELIMINATING-EXECUTIVE-STRESS-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> EXECUTIVE STRESS: ALLEVIATING PRESSURE AT THE TOP (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives: (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. Includes a 200-word sidebar. By SHARON JOHNSON c.1996 USAir magazine (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  A Minneapolis executive recently completed a 30-day diary in which he noted the times he experienced tightness in his neck, a pounding heartbeat and a loss of confidence. His physician used heart monitors and other technical devices to measure his physiological responses in situations ranging from commuting to public speaking.  With the data, the physician designed a stress prescription that included neck exercises the executive could do in the privacy of his office, a low-fat diet to decrease his risk of heart attack and instruction in visualization as a tool to cope with a difficult boss.  A Boston executive who suffered anxiety attacks because she feared that her job would be eliminated changed the way she formulated her to-do list. Each day she included five items that would help her get a new job or switch industries.  She also learned to decrease her anxiety by consulting an imaginary mentor who handled challenges in a positive way. Whenever the woman faced an exasperating situation, such as a budget cut, she considered what the mentor would do.  These techniques are just two of the many ways top businesspeople cope with stress today. Stress has always been a challenge for executives, but it has increased in recent years because of downsizing and other economic trends, according to John H. Howard, a professor and management psychologist at the University of Western Ontario who has been surveying executives about their response to stress since 1971.  ``Executive positions are stressful even in good times because they involve uncertainty, overwork, a feeling of helplessness and urgency,'' he explains.  The stress of urgency also has increased, Howard says, because executives have insufficient time between tasks. In studying 300 managers at 12 major companies, Howard found that the typical executive performed a different task every seven minutes. That means having to switch focus more than eight times an hour.  As a result, stress has become a major health concern. More than half of those in high-stress positions suffer from such physical or mental health problems as exhaustion, headaches and insomnia, according to a study by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Co. in Minneapolis.  As researchers learn about stress and its effects on mental and physical health, more effective prevention and treatment plans are being developed. Research has also identified with greater specificity those who suffer stress and why.  ``Although two-thirds of the 3,000 executives we interviewed for a study at the University of Massachusetts Medical School reported a significant amount of stress, only half of them said it was a negative factor in their lives,'' says James. M. Rippe, a cardiologist and director of the Center of Clinical and Lifestyle Research in Shewsbury, Mass.  ``Personal stresses such as divorce or the problems of caring for a handicapped child were harder for executives at all levels to handle than stress at work.  ``The higher the executive's position, the less stress he reported. Although chief executive officers felt stress from pressure to keep their businesses successful, they reported less stress than other executives because they had more control over what they did and when they did it.  ``Money also helped, because the CEOs didn't have to worry about how they would pay for their children's college education and could buy services that enabled them to avoid the hassles of daily life.''  According to Dr. James Campbell Quick, editor of the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology, female executives respond better than men to stress even though they often have the primary responsibility for raising children and caring for the home.  ``Women are better at establishing friendships and networking, so if something goes wrong in their professional or personal lives, they have several women from whom they can get emotional support and help,'' Quick says.  Work experience also affects stress levels. Executives who had been in their positions two to four years had less stress than those in their first managerial jobs or those who had been in the same positions for decades, Quick's research showed.  ``The key to avoiding stress is to tackle responsibilities that allow an executive to grow but are not so difficult that the executive feels overwhelmed, or so easy that he becomes bored and allows his performance to slip,'' Quick says.  Schools such as New York University's School of Continuing Education, have developed such workshops as ``The Time-Stress Connection,'' at which executives examine the personal attitudes, lifestyles and habits that determine daily effectiveness and explore what perpetuates the inefficient use of time and increased stress levels.  ``It's critical for an executive to know his or her long-term objectives because it can help in weathering crises outside one's control,'' says Carolyn Goldberg, the course instructor.  Regular exercise also helps control stress, says Rippe, author of the book ``Fit Over Forty'' (Morrow, 1996). More than 90 percent of the CEOs he surveyed participated in calisthenics at least three times a week, 70 percent said they ran regularly and more than 50 percent lifted weights.  Studies have shown the importance of using a variety of strategies to combat stress.  ``A businessperson may run three miles on weekends to help reduce workweek stress. (But) If he or she is out of town and develops a high level of anxiety before a meeting, a several-mile run won't be an option. Other techniques such as deep breathing exercises, visualization of a successful performance or recollection of a previous meeting where he or she triumphed might be a better approach,'' Howard explains.  Such experts as Salvatore R. Maddi, a professor of psychology at the University of California at Irvine and president of the Hardiness Institute at Irvine, have developed ways to help executives cope with such catastrophic events as the loss of a job or the death of a mate.  Maddi studied executives at Illinois Bell Telephone who had thrived during the breakup of the utility despite changes that left other executives unable to perform effectively.  ``The executives who thrived had hardy personalities,'' Maddi says. ``They had a strong sense of commitment, control and challenge. They could find ways to involve themselves in the changes so that they didn't feel overwhelmed by the loss of responsibilities or elimination of departments.  ``They viewed the changes as challenges rather than threats, then found something they could control, such as coming up with a new product.''  The Hardiness Institute offers workshops and self-help materials. One technique Maddi uses is situational reconstruction. For example, after a stress-producing event such as the loss of a key contract, the executive would imagine specific ways in which the situation might have turned out better or worse.  Situational reconstruction leads to action plans so that executives don't sink into self-pity and become immobilized.  However, some executives arrive at the institute already immobilized. In those cases Maddi recommends compensatory self-improvement.  For example, instead of sending out resumes, an unemployed executive would concentrate on a task over which he has complete control, such as improving his computer skills.  ``Once he has mastered the skill, the executive comes back with a renewed sense of accomplishment and self-esteem,'' Maddi says. ``He realizes that the catastrophic event is just one part of life and he can overcome it, just as he mastered the skills in his compensatory self-improvement project.  ``Best of all many executives identify new interests that can lead to even more satisfying jobs than the ones they lost and gain a technique that enables them to overcome stress throughout life.'' -0- TEN RELAXATION TIPS  John H. Howard, a professor and management psychologist at the University of Western Ontario, suggests the following to help reduce stress:  1. Don't procrastinate by doing low-priority tasks, thereby neglecting high priorities until there is a crisis. It's difficult to use time and energy to your best advantage without specific goals.  2. Accept the things out of your control. An overbearing boss or subordinate is unlikely to change, no matter what you do.  3. Avoid business lunches. Lunchtime should be a psychological break.  4. Avoid chronic hurriedness. Cultivate good judgment and decision, not speed.  5. If you have been working 60-hour weeks, cut back. Productivity drops in people under high stress.  6. When you are tense, relax your muscle groups. Start with arms, then face and neck, then shoulders and abdomen and finally legs.  7. If a stressful event is approaching, visualize yourself doing it well and in a relaxed manner.  8. Take a daily music break for at least 10 minutes.  9. Learn to feel comfortable confiding in someone, but not the same person every time. Give others support.  10. Laugh more. (Sharon Johnson writes for The New York Times, Working Woman and Self. She lives in New York City.) (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. If you have questions, please call Susie McBee at 202-298-6920 or Judy Holland or Eric Rosenberg at 202-298-6320.  (The ``HNS'' tag appears in all sluglines.)  For Friday:  POLITICS (``p'' category)  PEROT (Washington) _ Reform Party presidential candidate Ross Perot on Thursday rejected Bob Dole's invitation to quit the race and instead lambasted Dole and President Clinton for what he called their ``corrupt'' political fund-raising activities. By CHARLES J. LEWIS.  CLINTON-CAMPAIGN (Birmingham, Ala.) _ President Clinton continues dueling Bob Dole in Southern states by paying a visit to one of the first Southern colleges to integrate voluntarily. Then it's on to New Orleans. By NANCY MATHIS.  DOLE-CAMPAIGN (Florida or Louisiana) _ Republican presidential nominee Bob Dole blasts the press for obscuring his message and not telling the American people that the country will go down the drain if it gets four more years of Bill Clinton. By BENNETT ROTH.  HELMS-GANTT-CAMPAIGN (Wilson, N.C.) _ As Harvey Gantt tries for the second time in six years to end Jesse Helms' 24-year hold on a U.S. Senate seat, the black liberal and former mayor of Charlotte is scrambling to the middle in an effort to attract more support from conservative voters. By GREG McDONALD.  BUSINESS &AMP; FINANCIAL (``f'' category)  WORKING-COLUMN (Undated) _ If you're a looking for a good-paying job but don't want to spend time in college or vocational school, here are four possibilities: mail carrier, postal clerk, roustabout and seaman. These jobs, however, are tough to get. By L.M. SIXEL.  ARTS &AMP; ENTERTAINMENT (``e'' category)  MILLENNIUM-TV-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Millennium,'' the long-awaited encore to ``The X-Files,'' is intense, ugly and grim. It's a well-produced disappointment, too one-note to be real and too nightmarish to make me, for one, want to come back. It premieres Friday night. By ANN HODGES.  LIFESTYLE (``l'' category)  HALLOWEEN-STEW (Undated) _ Halloween menus are pretty scary _ they can turn into four or five dessert courses. But the clever kitchen witch will plan a substantial supper to help party guests or trick-or-treaters avoid sugar shock later in the evening. Stew is a perfect choice for an entree. By ANN CRISWELL.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  MEANS-COLUMN (Washington) _ How did Bob Dole get in such a pickle? Is it the fault of the candidate or his agenda, or both? By MARIANNE MEANS.  For Sunday:  POLITICAL NEWS (``p'' category)  CAMPAIGN-FINANCE (Washington) _ As the scandal-ridden campaign-finance system is getting a lot of national attention, voters in five states are ready to do something about it. Ballot initiatives in California, Maine, Colorado, Nevada, and Arkansas ask voters to decide whether to cap individual donations and limit the amount of money that can be spent to run for political office. By ELIZABETH SCHWINN.  DOLE-CLINTON-DRUGS (Washington) _ Bob Dole has hammered Bill Clinton for being ``AWOL'' in the war on drugs, and the president has replied that Dole and the GOP Congress failed to give him as much drug-fighting money as he requested. We look at the record. By DAN FREEDMAN.  BUSINESS &AMP; FINANCIAL (``f'' category)  COMPUTER-COLUMN (Undated) _ A look at two intriguing, next-generation, Internet-based utility titles for Windows 95 that deserve your undivided attention. By DWIGHT SILVERMAN. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961024.0737 type=story > <HEADLINE> IN NEW JERSEY, TRADITION OF ELECTION MUDSLINGING </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-NJ-SENATE-MUDSLINGING-575(2TAKES)-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199610.gz"

Times News ServiceNo. 1947 Tuesday, Nov. 26, (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  THE ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  From the home office in Coral Gables, Fla...  ``Good Things About Being a Senior Citizen''  As presented on the Friday, Nov. 22 broadcast of the LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN.  As presented by 10 residents of Century Village in Pembroke Pines, Fla.:  10. The 3M's: Mahjong, Metamucil and Matlock!  9. When you're on a Carnival cruise and Kathie Lee starts singing, you can turn off your hearing aid.  8. Instead of tipping waiters, I just tell them they can have my car when I die.  7. It's easy to annoy all young people. Step one: get in car. Step two: turn on blinker. Step three: leave it on for 50 miles.  6. The early bird special at Hooters  5. You can say whatever the hell pops into your mind. Waffles!  4. Once you hit 70, you start to look damn good in polyester!  3. My new bridge partner: Bob Dole  2. Social Security will be bankrupt in 50 years, and guess what --we don't care.  1. You're lookin' at a guy who's nailed all the Golden Girls.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Nov. 18-Thursday, Nov. 21)  ``A week ago Saturday, Bob Dole appeared on Saturday Night Live.' The previous week, Bob Dole was actually on this program down in Washington, D.C. Are you like me, ladies and gentlemen, are you beginning to get the feeling that maybe Bob doesn't know the election is over?''  ``I feel bad for President Clinton. That's a tough situation there in Hawaii, you know. He sees those women in grass skirts, and he doesn't know whether to smoke them or chase them.''  ``Bad news, I guess, for O.J. Simpson out there in Santa Monica. In the civil suit against him, the prosecution will not be able to play the Mark Fuhrman tapes in front of the jury. You know, the tapes in which Mark Fuhrman uses racial slurs? However, those tapes will be played at the next Texaco board meeting.''  ``Tomorrow, in the civil case out there in Santa Monica, O.J. Simpson will actually testify -- first time, actually take the stand. Are you like me -- do you get the feeling that when O.J. puts his hand on the Bible, it might not fit?''  ``Earlier this week out in Los Angeles -- this is unbelievable --there was a $50 a plate fundraising banquet for O.J. Simpson...I understand it was a lovely party. First, they had cocktails and then the guests were invited to follow the trail of blood into the dining room.''  ``But, I think the highlight of the evening -- and, by the way, they raised $5,000 at this fundraiser for O.J. Simpson -- I think the most exciting part, of course, was when they auctioned off the murder weapon.''  ``Last week, Michael Jackson, of course, married the woman who is carrying his child -- in Australia, I believe. Very, very touching ceremony. The justice of the peace said, All right, you may now kiss the bride, and then she lifted his surgical mask.'''  ``Debbie, Michael's wife, was actually married once before. This is her second marriage. Her first husband was a chemistry professor. So, it's interesting to me, she's gone now from a science teacher to a science project.''  ``I think this is also encouraging. Executives at Texaco have promised that for the next 24 hours, they will try not to light up a cross.''  MARRIAGE ANYONE? Vol. II  Frank Klimko of the San Diego Union Tribune imagined the following matches made in mirth:  If Bea Arthur married Sting, she'd be Bea Sting  If Woody Allen married Natalie Wood then divorced him to marry Gregory Peck, then divorced him to marry Ben Hur, he'd be Woody Wood Peck Hur.  If Dolly Parton married Tommy Smothers then went even further back in show business to marry Mr. Lucky, then divorced him to marry Martin Short, then divorced him to marry blues great Buddy Guy, we'd all nod knowingly when we heard Dolly Smothers Lucky Short Guy.  If Boog Powell married Felipe Alou, he'd be Boog Alou.  If Snoop Doggy Dogg married Winnie the Pooh, he'd be Snoop Doggy Dog Pooh.  If Liv Ullman married Judge Lance Ito then divorced him to marry Jerry Mathers, she'd be Liv Ito Beaver.  If Sondra Locke married Elliott Ness, then divorced him to marry Hermann Munster, she'd be Sandra Locke Ness Munster.  CAN'T ANYBODY HERE PLAY THIS GAME?  But the Jets do have trouble. Offensive tackle Harry Boatswain summed up their feeling.  ``Special teams?'' he said. ``It feels like a special-education team this year.''  _ Quoted in the New York Times  BILL'S WORLDBy Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  Mr. Clinton and China's president plan to exchange visits over the next two years. Sounds like a revival of ping-pong diplomacy.  Mr. Clinton's visit to Thailand was the first by an American president since Richard Nixon went there in 1969. No, Nixon was on a state visit, not a work-release program.  Hillary Rodham Clinton says she will ``speak out and write about'' welfare reform. Has anyone agreed to listen to or read her words?  Mr. Clinton's search for a Republican for his new Cabinet hasn't turned up much yet, it's reported. For one thing, Abe Lincoln isn't available.  Economists think retailers will do well this Christmas. One way to make sure is to buy expensive, anonymous gifts for newspaper columnists.  The White House Christmas tree this year is a Colorado blue spruce from Ohio. Sounds like George Bush _ a New England Yankee from Texas.  The height of the White House Christmas tree is 18.5 feet. Too bad Ross Perot wasn't elected. That's the same size as his ego.  The recent Army scandals prove to Aunt Ilse from Oelwein that the question of whether women should be in combat has long since been answered.  Experts think the economy will grow steadily into the 21st century, a new survey shows. It would be more impressive as if they'd say the 22nd.  Offer not available in any store! THE ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  From the home office in Coral Gables, Fla...  ``Good Things About Being a Senior Citizen''  As presented on the Friday, Nov. 22 broadcast of the LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN.  As presented by 10 residents of Century Village in Pembroke Pines, Fla.:  10. The 3M's: Mahjong, Metamucil and Matlock!  9. When you're on a Carnival cruise and Kathie Lee starts singing, you can turn off your hearing aid.  8. Instead of tipping waiters, I just tell them they can have my car when I die.  7. It's easy to annoy all young people. Step one: get in car. Step two: turn on blinker. Step three: leave it on for 50 miles.  6. The early bird special at Hooters  5. You can say whatever the hell pops into your mind. Waffles!  4. Once you hit 70, you start to look damn good in polyester!  3. My new bridge partner: Bob Dole  2. Social Security will be bankrupt in 50 years, and guess what --we don't care.  1. You're lookin' at a guy who's nailed all the Golden Girls.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Nov. 18-Thursday, Nov. 21)  ``A week ago Saturday, Bob Dole appeared on Saturday Night Live.' The previous week, Bob Dole was actually on this program down in Washington, D.C. Are you like me, ladies and gentlemen, are you beginning to get the feeling that maybe Bob doesn't know the election is over?''  ``I feel bad for President Clinton. That's a tough situation there in Hawaii, you know. He sees those women in grass skirts, and he doesn't know whether to smoke them or chase them.''  ``Bad news, I guess, for O.J. Simpson out there in Santa Monica. In the civil suit against him, the prosecution will not be able to play the Mark Fuhrman tapes in front of the jury. You know, the tapes in which Mark Fuhrman uses racial slurs? However, those tapes will be played at the next Texaco board meeting.''  ``Tomorrow, in the civil case out there in Santa Monica, O.J. Simpson will actually testify -- first time, actually take the stand. Are you like me -- do you get the feeling that when O.J. puts his hand on the Bible, it might not fit?''  ``Earlier this week out in Los Angeles -- this is unbelievable --there was a $50 a plate fundraising banquet for O.J. Simpson...I understand it was a lovely party. First, they had cocktails and then the guests were invited to follow the trail of blood into the dining room.''  ``But, I think the highlight of the evening -- and, by the way, they raised $5,000 at this fundraiser for O.J. Simpson -- I think the most exciting part, of course, was when they auctioned off the murder weapon.''  ``Last week, Michael Jackson, of course, married the woman who is carrying his child -- in Australia, I believe. Very, very touching ceremony. The justice of the peace said, All right, you may now kiss the bride, and then she lifted his surgical mask.'''  ``Debbie, Michael's wife, was actually married once before. This is her second marriage. Her first husband was a chemistry professor. So, it's interesting to me, she's gone now from a science teacher to a science project.''  ``I think this is also encouraging. Executives at Texaco have promised that for the next 24 hours, they will try not to light up a cross.''  MARRIAGE ANYONE? Vol. II  Frank Klimko of the San Diego Union Tribune imagined the following matches made in mirth:  If Bea Arthur married Sting, she'd be Bea Sting  If Woody Allen married Natalie Wood then divorced him to marry Gregory Peck, then divorced him to marry Ben Hur, he'd be Woody Wood Peck Hur.  If Dolly Parton married Tommy Smothers then went even further back in show business to marry Mr. Lucky, then divorced him to marry Martin Short, then divorced him to marry blues great Buddy Guy, we'd all nod knowingly when we heard Dolly Smothers Lucky Short Guy.  If Boog Powell married Felipe Alou, he'd be Boog Alou.  If Snoop Doggy Dogg married Winnie the Pooh, he'd be Snoop Doggy Dog Pooh.  If Liv Ullman married Judge Lance Ito then divorced him to marry Jerry Mathers, she'd be Liv Ito Beaver.  If Sondra Locke married Elliott Ness, then divorced him to marry Hermann Munster, she'd be Sandra Locke Ness Munster.  CAN'T ANYBODY HERE PLAY THIS GAME?  But the Jets do have trouble. Offensive tackle Harry Boatswain summed up their feeling.  ``Special teams?'' he said. ``It feels like a special-education team this year.''  _ Quoted in the New York Times  BILL'S WORLDBy Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  Mr. Clinton and China's president plan to exchange visits over the next two years. Sounds like a revival of ping-pong diplomacy.  Mr. Clinton's visit to Thailand was the first by an American president since Richard Nixon went there in 1969. No, Nixon was on a state visit, not a work-release program.  Hillary Rodham Clinton says she will ``speak out and write about'' welfare reform. Has anyone agreed to listen to or read her words?  Mr. Clinton's search for a Republican for his new Cabinet hasn't turned up much yet, it's reported. For one thing, Abe Lincoln isn't available.  Economists think retailers will do well this Christmas. One way to make sure is to buy expensive, anonymous gifts for newspaper columnists.  The White House Christmas tree this year is a Colorado blue spruce from Ohio. Sounds like George Bush _ a New England Yankee from Texas.  The height of the White House Christmas tree is 18.5 feet. Too bad Ross Perot wasn't elected. That's the same size as his ego.  The recent Army scandals prove to Aunt Ilse from Oelwein that the question of whether women should be in combat has long since been answered.  Experts think the economy will grow steadily into the 21st century, a new survey shows. It would be more impressive as if they'd say the 22nd.  Offer not available in any store! (Or any other news service!)  Looking for contributors with wit, style, depth, charm and genius with jokes, anecdotes, humorous news items, bonus NYLite offerings, or filler material.  Dr. NYLite will respond with a GENUINE New York Times rolling writer-style pen if your item is used.  All items fit to fax to 212-556-3535 (24 hours), or via uniformed government courier:  Dr. NYLite  c/o N.Y.Times News Service  229 W. 43rd St., Room 943  New York, N.Y. 10036  (Or call, 212-556-1927) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19961126.0575 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-GRAPHICS-BUDGET-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Here are the New York Times News Service Macintosh graphics scheduled for AMs of Wednesday, 11/27/96. Non-subscribers may make individual graphics purchases or get additional information by calling the NYT Photo/Graphics desk at (212) 556-4204 between noon and 10 p.m. EST. BRODY/Sinus Symptons -- 2 x 3 1/2 -- (BC-BRODY-HEALTH-NYT)  How to distingush between cold, allergy, and sinus symptoms.  TRAVEL  WHATSDOING/Washington DC -- 2 x 4 1/4 -- (BC-SF-TRAVEL-DOING-NYT)  Weekly featured travel map.  STATISTICS/Washington DC -- 1 x 5 1/2 -- (BC-SF-TRAVEL-DOING-NYT)  Sample travel costs for featured travel destination.  FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES 12/1 -- 2 x 9 1/2 -- travel feature.  LOWEST AIR FARES 12/1 -- 3 x 6 1/2 -- travel feature.  The lowest restricted and unrestricted round trip airfares.  EVENTS CALENDAR 12/1 -- 2 x 5 1/4 -- travel feature.  Events around the world.  WORLD WEATHER/December -- 2 x 4 1/4 -- Monthly travel feature.  FINANCIAL  JAPAN/Economy -- tk-- (BC-JAPAN-ECON-NYT)  Japan's outflows, inflows and surplus with the world.  MUTFUND/Cash flow -- tk -- (BC-MUTFUND-REPORT-NYT)  Cash flows into stock funds.  MUTFUND/Cash value -- 2 x tk -- (BC-MUTFUND-REPORT-NYT)  Cash as a percentage of fund assets.  IBM/Stock chart 11/27 -- 14p x 3 -- (BC-IBM-BUYBACKS-NYT)  IBM stock performance.  S&AMP;P Components -- 24p x 3 1/2 -- Alternating business chart.  N.Y. Times News ServiceNo. 1947 Tuesday, Nov. 26, (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  THE ``LATE SHOW'' TOP TEN  From the home office in Coral Gables, Fla...  ``Good Things About Being a Senior Citizen''  As presented on the Friday, Nov. 22 broadcast of the LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN.  As presented by 10 residents of Century Village in Pembroke Pines, Fla.:  10. The 3M's: Mahjong, Metamucil and Matlock!  9. When you're on a Carnival cruise and Kathie Lee starts singing, you can turn off your hearing aid.  8. Instead of tipping waiters, I just tell them they can have my car when I die.  7. It's easy to annoy all young people. Step one: get in car. Step two: turn on blinker. Step three: leave it on for 50 miles.  6. The early bird special at Hooters  5. You can say whatever the hell pops into your mind. Waffles!  4. Once you hit 70, you start to look damn good in polyester!  3. My new bridge partner: Bob Dole  2. Social Security will be bankrupt in 50 years, and guess what --we don't care.  1. You're lookin' at a guy who's nailed all the Golden Girls.  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Nov. 18-Thursday, Nov. 21)  ``A week ago Saturday, Bob Dole appeared on Saturday Night Live.' The previous week, Bob Dole was actually on this program down in Washington, D.C. Are you like me, ladies and gentlemen, are you beginning to get the feeling that maybe Bob doesn't know the election is over?''  ``I feel bad for President Clinton. That's a tough situation there in Hawaii, you know. He sees those women in grass skirts, and he doesn't know whether to smoke them or chase them.''  ``Bad news, I guess, for O.J. Simpson out there in Santa Monica. In the civil suit against him, the prosecution will not be able to play the Mark Fuhrman tapes in front of the jury. You know, the tapes in which Mark Fuhrman uses racial slurs? However, those tapes will be played at the next Texaco board meeting.''  ``Tomorrow, in the civil case out there in Santa Monica, O.J. Simpson will actually testify -- first time, actually take the stand. Are you like me -- do you get the feeling that when O.J. puts his hand on the Bible, it might not fit?''  ``Earlier this week out in Los Angeles -- this is unbelievable --there was a $50 a plate fundraising banquet for O.J. Simpson...I understand it was a lovely party. First, they had cocktails and then the guests were invited to follow the trail of blood into the dining room.''  ``But, I think the highlight of the evening -- and, by the way, they raised $5,000 at this fundraiser for O.J. Simpson -- I think the most exciting part, of course, was when they auctioned off the murder weapon.''  ``Last week, Michael Jackson, of course, married the woman who is carrying his child -- in Australia, I believe. Very, very touching ceremony. The justice of the peace said, All right, you may now kiss the bride, and then she lifted his surgical mask.'''  ``Debbie, Michael's wife, was actually married once before. This is her second marriage. Her first husband was a chemistry professor. So, it's interesting to me, she's gone now from a science teacher to a science project.''  ``I think this is also encouraging. Executives at Texaco have promised that for the next 24 hours, they will try not to light up a cross.''  MARRIAGE ANYONE? Vol. II  Frank Klimko of the San Diego Union Tribune imagined the following matches made in mirth:  If Bea Arthur married Sting, she'd be Bea Sting  If Woody Allen married Natalie Wood then divorced him to marry Gregory Peck, then divorced him to marry Ben Hur, he'd be Woody Wood Peck Hur.  If Dolly Parton married Tommy Smothers then went even further back in show business to marry Mr. Lucky, then divorced him to marry Martin Short, then divorced him to marry blues great Buddy Guy, we'd all nod knowingly when we heard Dolly Smothers Lucky Short Guy.  If Boog Powell married Felipe Alou, he'd be Boog Alou.  If Snoop Doggy Dogg married Winnie the Pooh, he'd be Snoop Doggy Dog Pooh.  If Liv Ullman married Judge Lance Ito then divorced him to marry Jerry Mathers, she'd be Liv Ito Beaver.  If Sondra Locke married Elliott Ness, then divorced him to marry Hermann Munster, she'd be Sandra Locke Ness Munster.  CAN'T ANYBODY HERE PLAY THIS GAME?  But the Jets do have trouble. Offensive tackle Harry Boatswain summed up their feeling.  ``Special teams?'' he said. ``It feels like a special-education team this year.''  _ Quoted in the New York Times  BILL'S WORLDBy Bill Tammeus, The Kansas City Star  Mr. Clinton and China's president plan to exchange visits over the next two years. Sounds like a revival of ping-pong diplomacy.  Mr. Clinton's visit to Thailand was the first by an American president since Richard Nixon went there in 1969. No, Nixon was on a state visit, not a work-release program.  Hillary Rodham Clinton says she will ``speak out and write about'' welfare reform. Has anyone agreed to listen to or read her words?  Mr. Clinton's search for a Republican for his new Cabinet hasn't turned up much yet, it's reported. For one thing, Abe Lincoln isn't available.  Economists think retailers will do well this Christmas. One way to make sure is to buy expensive, anonymous gifts for newspaper columnists.  The White House Christmas tree this year is a Colorado blue spruce from Ohio. Sounds like George Bush _ a New England Yankee from Texas.  The height of the White House Christmas tree is 18.5 feet. Too bad Ross Perot wasn't elected. That's the same size as his ego.  The recent Army scandals prove to Aunt Ilse from Oelwein that the question of whether women should be in combat has long since been answered.  Experts think the economy will grow steadily into the 21st century, a new survey shows. It would be more impressive as if they'd say the 22nd.  Offer not available in any store! Money managers reacted by advising Lott to keep his hands off the Fed, chaired by Alan Greenspan. ``Any politician who takes on Greenspan will lose, because the bond market is rooting for Greenspan,'' said James Awad, president of the New York money management firm of Awad &AMP; Associates. "81981"	"I"	"guess"	" A: Well, the tough thing in making this film was that I had to stick to the facts. I took that very seriously, because I know that some people get their history through movies. So I wanted to be accurate and factual. If I'd had a free hand as a dramatist, I would have made De La Beckwith take the witness stand and have him and DeLaughter go at each other in the climax, but it didn't happen that way. What did happen is that, in the course of the trial, Bobby told me, he ran into De La Beckwith in the men's room at the courthouse. He said that De La Beckwith basically said, ``How do you think it's goin' for you, son?'' with this kind of big grin on his face, and Bobby said, ``Well, we'll see soon enough, I guess,'' and De La Beckwith said, ``That we will, son, that we will,'' and he had this cocky grin on his face, like nobody could touch him. I took that little nub of an encounter and I made a full scene out of it. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199612.gz"
