"93369"	"I"	"guess"	" DePaul center Steven Hunter appears to have been the guy who helped himself the most at the just-concluded predraft camp in Chicago. That's Wallace's take, anyway. ``When he was a reserve as a freshman, you thought if he made the natural progression, that he'd be a possible lottery pick as a senior,'' Wallace said. Instead, Hunter declared after his sophomore season, which was only slightly more eventful than his uninspiring freshman year. ``It was a lackluster year,'' Wallace said. ``But he showed enough flashes (at the camp) to move into the first round, probably inside the top 20.'' Hunter is a 7-footer who has shot-blocking capabilities but otherwise ordinary numbers (5.5 rebounds, 11.4 points on a sub-.500 team). Wallace said the camp was better than in past years because a number of underclassmen showed up and played well. Other than Hunter, that would include Gilbert Arenas of Arizona, Omar Cook of St. John's, and Kenny Satterfield of Cincinnati . . . What do we make of the resounding rejection (57-43 percent) of the arena referendum in Charlotte? Well, judging by Stern's comments, he seems to be telling the folks in Charlotte to work it out and not to depend on him to bail them out. He didn't issue any threats. He didn't state the obvious, which is that the initiative would likely sail through if George Shinn and Ray Woolridge sold the team. He simply told them to solve it. ``I would like to hope that because these two enterprises (the city and the team) do mean a certain amount to each other, that there will be a way to find a way to do what has to be done there, and that's to build a new building,'' Stern said. The NBA wants the Hornets in Charlotte, and Stern generally gets what he wants. As of now, Louisville probably is the most logical choice for relocation, although the arrival of Rick Pitino to coach the Cardinals may be enough to placate the basketball people in that city . . . Keith Van Horn to Utah? That's one predraft trade rumor that's out there. The Jazz would have to part with a combination of players, and Van Horn's trade situation is still affected by the dreaded base-year compensation rules. Utah is also interested to see Russian Andrei Kirilenko, whom the Jazz selected with the 24th pick in the 1999 draft. He is slated to play in the Utah Summer League and join the team this season. Kirilenko, a 6-10 center/power forward, has been playing in Russia since being drafted at the age of 18 . . . It will be interesting to see what happens to high school big man DeSagana Diop. He's a full slab (7 feet, 300 pounds) and was widely perceived to be one of the top six picks. He still could be. But he also is, as Wallace noted, ``somewhat of a mystery man'' because he hasn't had any workouts yet and missed a lot of the All-Star games with a foot injury . . . Damage Control Dept.: After Antonio Davis's name was mentioned in the ongoing trial in Atlanta regarding strippers at a nightclub providing succor and other salacious stuff, agent Bill Duffy quickly got his client in a teleconference with Toronto reporters. Davis said he would soon file a lawsuit against the individual who mentioned his name in testimony. ``I don't know if it's a personal attack or not,'' Davis said. ``The bottom line is he said my name and it's a lie. He's not yelling out a bunch of names. He's yelling out particular people. He makes it sound like I was one of the top five or six guys who were doing this stuff, which is completely false.'' Davis did admit to visiting the club, but said it was before he was married, very early in his NBA career. ``I was young and, I guess, stupid,'' he said. Stern was asked about the situation in Atlanta and cracked, ``Wouldn't you rather talk about declining ratings and attendance being off?'' He did add, ``We have to do a better job of identifying places like that and warning our players against it. There is a line you traditionally try to walk, a very thin one, from saying based upon every innuendo or what vowel somebody's name ends with as to whether you should go to a place or not, and we're not going to be a party to that.'' . . . This will be a busy week for the Celtics, who will have four days devoted to working out players for the draft. Included in the group of about 16-20 players will be a couple of foreigners: point guard Tony Parker, who played in France, and Vladimir Radmanovic, a 6-10 forward who played in Yugoslavia. The Celtics also will take a look at point guards Jamaal Tinsley and Earl Watson as well as former Worcester Burncoat High School star Michael Bradley, who went to Kentucky to play for Pitino only to see Pitino leave to coach the Celtics shortly after Bradley had made his commitment. Bradley subsequently transferred to Villanova and played one year, declaring early for this year's draft. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200106.gz"

"94754"	"I"	"guess"	" A very classy and kind gesture by O'Connell at Saturday's draft, calling longtime scouts Bob Tindall, Jim Morrison, and Jean Ratelle to the podium as a way of announcing their retirements. Three truly terrific men. Ex-Bruin Peter McNab on the ever-classy Ratelle: ``When I came to Boston, I knew nothing about playing defensive hockey. Not a thing. And Ratty's way was just wonderful. When we went out on that long trip at the start of October, he quietly got me on the plane and said, `Look, you and I are going to work on a few things out there, OK?' That's all. Simple. And for months he worked with me, on faceoffs, on positioning, on defensive coverage. Just little things, like saying, `OK, now (Rick) MacLeish is fast, very fast, don't get caught trying to chase him _ stay with him.' You couldn't help but learn from Ratty. He was so patient, so smart. And you know, he didn't tell anyone what he was doing, how he was helping, and he never came up later and said anything to me, or looked for thanks. That was the way his generation did things, I guess, and I'll never forget how much he helped me.'' . . . The Coyotes grabbed the fastest skater in the draft when they selected Fredrik Sjostrom No. 11 overall last Saturday. The speedy Sjostrom was tutored on blades by his mom, a Swedish speedskater in the '76 Olympics. With the 180th pick, the Desert Dogs took Scott Polaski, a cousin of US Olympic speedskater Bonnie Blair. The genes look good. (Visit the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)  N A T I O N A L / T E X A S  DEREG-TEXAS  AUSTIN _ Texas began its trial run of electricity deregulation Tuesday, with a limited number of customers being switched over to competitors of the state's major power producers, including TXU and Houston Power &AMP; Light. The state thinks it has learned from California's woes and hopes to have a smoother, and less price-volatile, time of it. By R.A. DYER. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  CAMPAIGN-TAAS  FORT WORTH, Texas _ Declared Texas gubernatorial candidate Marty Akins says that if he's elected he will work to abolish a state-required test for high school students because it is crippling teachers' efforts to educate thier students. ``I think you need a standardized test, I guess, to test our children to see that they're learning.But I think right now that the teachers, all that they're worried about ... is teaching how to pass that TAAS test,'' he said at a breakfast gathering in Fort Worth. By JACK DOUGLAS JR. Story will move in ``p'' political category.  E N T E R T A I N M E N T  VIDEO-GAMES  UNDATED: Weekly roundup of summer time-killers. By MALCOLM MAYHEW. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  IWANTMY-MTV  UNDATED: Twenty years ago, at midnight Aug. 1, 1981, MTV was born and spoke its first words: ``Ladies and gentlemen,'' uttered MTV co-founder John Lack, ``rock 'n' roll.'' On the heels of that small introduction, heard and seen by a smidgen of viewers, compared with MTV's monster viewership of today (300 million and counting), MTV aired its first video, ``Video Killed the Radio Star'' by The Buggles. It was supposed to be a moment of irony _ a suggestion that, well, maybe, this new thing really could wipe out radio. MTV didn't kill radio stars; it has only made them stronger. Accompanied by MTV-VJS. By MALCOLM MAYHEW. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  MTV-VJS  UNDATED: During its 20-year reign, MTV has gone through more than 50 video-jocks. Here's a look at the 10 most memorable VJs, what we loved about them and _ you might have guessed it _ ``Where are they now?''By MALCOLM MAYHEW. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  CHICK-FLICK  UNDATED: ``The Princess Diaries'' _ What it's worth: Full price. You've played it in your dreams a dozen times, and the filmmakers don't ruin the fantasy. Brief review by Gaile Robinson. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  L I F E S T Y L E  FRAZZLED-PARENT  UNDATED: The fate of Rufus the cat (''Catherine, you don't need that cat. You DON'T need that cat. Please don't take that cat. Thank you.'' Click.) By CATHERINE NEWTON. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  BACKPACKS  UNDATED: Almost time for your kids to hit the books (aaaargh!), and they're going to have to lug quite a few of them. A new backpack might make the process a little less painful. Check out these totes. By AMANDA ROGERS. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  EDDIE-BAUER  UNDATED: His signature is on the SUV next to you at the traffic light, the car seat your well-off college friends strap their kids into, the sunglasses your doctor wears, the Compaq Presario notebook your co-worker is still paying for and the wallpaper in your neighbors' tastefully decorated living room filled with his special-edition furniture. And don't forget your closet full of his clothes. But for millions of devoted Eddie Bauer customers, the man behind the label _ the son of Russian immigrants who built an empire off personal fishing tips and a talent for stringing tennis rackets _ remains a mystery. Accompanied by OTHER-NAMES. By TODD CAMP. Story will move in two takes in ``l'' lifestyle category.  OTHER-NAMES  UNDATED: So who else is real? Abercrombie? Fitch? Victoria?. By TODD CAMP. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  SPF-TIPS  UNDATED: Think that moisturizer with sunscreen that you pat on daintily in the morning will protect you from the sun? Think again. Although the sun-protection factor (SPF) in cosmetic products is monitored by the Food and Drug Administration, a beauty expert says most people don't apply makeup liberally enough to achieve the full protection suggested by the SPF on the label. By JESSIE MILLIGAN. Story will move in ``l'' lifestyle category.  BEER-SPHERE  Sapporo Draft, made by Japan's oldest brewer, is less well-known in the United States than Kirin. People might be surprised that a mass-produced beer like this light, German-style lager can be so distinctive. By BARRY SHLACHTER. "99525"	"I"	"guess"	" Review: A good performance by William H. Macy and a timely message about prejudice can't overcome the heavy-handed and essentially dated material. Based on a novel written by playwright Arthur Miller in 1945, the movie is about an insurance clerk whose new pair of glasses causes everyone to think he's Jewish. Laura Dern is a secretary who's also mistaken for being Jewish. Both must endure being ostracized and insulted for what they're not, which, I guess, says something about judging a book by its cover. The film has some of the punched-up, didactic earnestness of an old ``Twilight Zone'' episode, but Rod Serling would've given it a better kicker at the end. (ERG) 1 hour, 40 minutes. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200111.gz"

Then rushed through the rest of his deliveries, certain that any second someone would come rushing up from behind and grab him. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz

, he said,	 After ``El Super,'' he worked on ``Saturday Night Live'' and developed ``Crossover Dreams,'' which starred the Panamanian-born music star Ruben Blades. In 1996, Ichaso made his third feature as writer and director, another film about Cuba called ``Azucar Amarga (Bitter Sugar),'' about a young couple, an underemployed psychiatrist and a man with AIDS all chafing under the restrictions of the Castro regime. The NYT frontpage advisory, with layout description, will move by 7:30 p.m. ET. The night supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Pat Ryan; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: patryan(at)nytimes.com.  TERROR-ASHCROFT (Washington) _ Attorney General John Ashcroft said Tuesday that about 600 people are in jail in connection with the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks, and some of them, he added, are members of the al-Qaida terrorist network who may have been planning additional terrorist incidents. By David Johnston.  Editors, this story replaces the previously budgeted TERROR-INQUIRY, now scratched.  TERROR-DETAIN-ASSESS (Washington) _ A news analysis on the decision by the administration to release a list of those who remain in federal custody. By Todd S. Purdum.  ATTACK-PRISONERS (Tashgurghan, Afghanistan) _ Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate. The prisoners were the sorry byproduct of the Northern Alliance's most recent victory, in Kunduz. It was a defeated army this, all rags and filth and lowered heads. Flies swarmed men with matted hair, and fights unfolded in the tangle of bodies for the tiny corners of space. The air around the trucks reeked so powerfully that th guards wrapped their faces with their scarves before they approached. The prisoners had come to this spot, a way station in the parched vastness of northern Afghanistan, to wait for some word on their final destination. Mostly illiterate young men from Pakistan, they were not being allowed to return to their homes, like the Taliban from Afghanistan. By Dexter Filkins.  With photos, NYT1-4.  ATTACK-UPRISING (Qala Jangi, Afghanistan) _ The Northern Alliance crushed a two-day uprising of Taliban prisoners of war, an effort that, according to the victors, required a tank firing point-blank into a house containing the last holdouts. American and British troops assisted. By Carlotta Gall.  ANTHRAX-CT (dateline to come) _ The death of an 84-year-old man who lived in the same area as the elderly woman who died of inhalation anthrax last week does not appear to be related, Gov. John G. Rowland said Tuesday. The man died at home, several weeks ago, and his body was not discovered for a few days, Rowland said. ``The 84-year-old man from Seymour did not die from anthrax,'' he said. (Summary from wires) By Paul Zielbauer.  NY-VICTIM-MIXUP (New York) _ The identity of two victims in the World Trade Center attack were switched and officials are now trying to set it right. By N.R. Kleinfield.  In addition, the following stories are tentatively planned for the front of ``A Nation Challenged,'' the daily section devoted to Afghan and terrorism coverage:  ATTACK-MILITARY (Dateline to come) _ Military developments: briefing at Central Command in Tampa. By James Dao and Thom Shanker.  AFGHAN-DEFECT (Quetta, Pakistan) _ At least on the outside, Mullah Amirjan Selabe had already begun to reinvent himself. After slipping across the border out of Afghanistan, he had unfurled the Taliban's telltale black turban, replacing it with a gray one with white stripes. Selabe is one of countless Taliban soldiers or commanders who have disappeared by melding themselves in Afghan communities in Pakistan. Crossing porous borders, most are believed to have settled in areas populated by fellow ethnic Pashtuns, who regard them as relatives or friends from the same village, not as fugitives. By Norimitsu Onishi.  PENDLETON-MARINES (Oceanview, Calif.) _ With more than 2,000 Marines from this base alone now overseas, some of them on the ground in Afghanistan, a slow but steady stream of reservists is flowing in to fill the empty barracks and prepare for assignments at bases in the United States and abroad. Though they have finished with their term of duty, sometimes for years, the officers on this canyon base of 41,000 Marines proudly state that the reservists are here because they want to be, because they have offered to serve. But while they hardly make noise about it, few of the reservists here say they were ever given that choice. In fact, the letters they clutch clearly state that they have been ``involuntarily ordered to active duty.'' By Greg Winter.  With photos, NYT21-24.  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011127.0215 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-LADN-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The Los Angeles Daily News plans to move the following general stories for use by NYTimes News Service clients, AMs and PMs of Wednesday, Nov. 28, and thereafter. For questions, contact Carol Bidwell at the Daily News, (818) 713-3702.  LAX-LOSSES (Los Angeles) -- Los Angeles International Airport officials say they've lost big bucks in the 11 weeks since Sept. 11 and are looking to reduce the workforce by 400 through retirements, transfers and attrition. Much of the loss is due to the fall-off in business and parking revenues at the airport. City officials also said Tuesday they have spent more than $4 million in extra security costs since Sept. 11, City Administrative Officer Bill Fujioka said. Also getting numbers for Burbank and Ontario airports. By Rick Orlov. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  AMBASSADOR-PURCHASE (Los Angeles) -- The Los Angeles Unified School District may be in for another decade-long fight to buy the historic Ambassador Hotel site. A Los Angeles bankruptcy court judge on Tuesday ordered the owners of the Ambassador to negotiate a deal with Alan Casden, one of the nation's largest residential real estate developers, who has said he is willing to pay $115 million in cash for the 23-acre site. Casden's plan comes only weeks after district officials announced a $76.5 million deal to end a 12-year battle with developers, who once included Donald Trump and Magic Johnson. If Casden gets the land and the district still wants it, it would have to take the property by eminent domain. By Sonia Giordani. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  LOST-HERO (Los Angeles) -- To 77-year-old Judi Mardenfeld, her father was a gentle, shy man who loved his family. To history, he was a WWI soldier who saved his fellow soldiers from certain death in what became known as the Lost Battalion. Splintered off from their company, the 77th division found itself surrounded by Germans in the Forest d'Argonne in France, 1918. After other soldiers were killed in their attempts, Pvt. Abraham Krotoshinsky's broke through enemy lines and secured help. Mardenfeld remembers her father, who will be portrayed in A&AMP;E's ``Lost Battalion'' on Sunday, Dec. 2. (Will move on the ``n'' California and ``a'' national news wires.)  POTTER-INTERNET (Los Angeles) -- Harry Potter isn't just a record-breaking hit at the box office. The 11-year-old wizard is burning up the Internet as well, with the official Warner Bros. Harry Potter Web site having so many visitors that extra staff has been brought in to handle the onslaught. By Greg Hernandez. (Will move on the ``f'' financial, ``a'' national and ``n'' California news wires.)  AMGEN-NASA (Los Angeles) -- Biotechnology giant Amgen and NASA are collaborating to study osteoporosis in space, where the bone loss is accelerated because of a lack of gravity. By Evan Pondel. (Will move on the ``f'' financial, ``a'' national and ``n'' California news wires.)  XXX </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011127.0216 type=story > <HEADLINE>     MORE MEMBERS OF CONGRESS? , I suspect,	 Encased in Cryovac bags, the cheeses age for six to eight months. It is this technique, I suspect, that makes them so much moister than Stilton. They are less pungent than Roquefort because they are made with cow's milk, not sheep's milk. Their remarkable richness, reminiscent of Gorgonzola, is a family secret, at least for now. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 But Meyer said it would be a mistake to rule out further rate cuts in an effort to preserve the flexibility to reduce rates further down the road should the economy not recover or encounter an unexpected shock like another terrorist attack. Among other things, he said, the Fed had to keep in mind the possibility of deflation, or a general decline in prices, a development that would require rapid rate reductions. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 Speaking to the National Association of Business Economics in St. Louis, Meyer said the Fed's aggressive campaign of interest rate cuts this year has not rippled through the economy and the financial markets as much as traditional economic theory would have predicted. As a result, he said, the Fed has been forced to cut rates more deeply than past experience would have suggested is necessary. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 Meyer also said the outlook for a quick recovery would be tempered somewhat if Congress and the Bush administration cannot agree on a fiscal stimulus package in coming weeks. The long-term forecast, he said, was being dimmed a bit by the likelihood that federal budget surpluses would be smaller than previously projected, a development likely to push up interest rates. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he added,	 He said such concerns had played a role in his decision to support a half-point rate cut at the Fed's last meeting, on Nov. 6. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011127.0222 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-LADN-BUDGET-SPORTS-LADN) </DATELINE> <TEXT> LOS ANGELES DAILY NEWS BUDGET (November 28 editions) For questions and resends, call Joe Jares at (818) 713-3602  FBC-USCBOWL (Los Angeles) -- As expected, USC will play Utah in the Las Vegas Bowl on Christmas day. By Steve Dilbeck. (Will move on the ``s'' sports file.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011127.0223 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-TECH-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> TECHNOLOGY NEWS IN BRIEF  c.2001 New York Times News Service  INTERNET  EMI BUYS VIDEO DISTRIBUTOR  The EMI Group agreed to buy a 4.76 percent stake in the Newsplayer Group, which distributes videos over the Internet, for 32,903 pounds, or $46,448, in cash. EMI has the option to raise its stake to 5 percent next year, the companies said. The agreement allows the London-based Newsplayer to include EMI video footage of bands like Genesis and artists like Nat King Cole in its database. Like other music companies, EMI, which is also based in London, has been seeking ways to make money from online music, as sales from conventional retail outlets fall. EMI shares, which are traded in London, fell 7.50 pence, or 2.14 percent, to 3.43 pounds.  TELECOMMUNICATIONS  SATELLITE RADIO COMPANY NAMES CHIEF  SiriusSatellite Radio in New York said on Tuesday that it had named Joseph P. Clayton president and chief executive. Clayton had been vice chairman at Global Crossing in Rochester, a worldwide Internet and long-distance services provider, and had held numerous posts in consumer electronics over the years. The 52-year-old Clayton succeeds David Margolese, the Sirius chairman, whom the company said had given up the chief executive post last month. Sirius plans to introduce its 100-channel digital radio service on Feb. 14, 2002, in Denver, Houston and Phoenix. The Sirius rival, XM Satellite Radio, introduced its 100-channel digital radio service in two markets in September, and introduced its service nationally earlier this month.  RESEARCH  GENOMICS-DERIVED DRUG TO BE TESTED  Millennium Pharmaceuticals said on Tuesday that the first drug discovered using its genomics technology had entered clinical trials. Millennium, based in Cambridge, Mass., is widely considered a leader in sifting through genetic data to find genes that might be involved in disease, and big drug companies have paid hundreds of millions of dollars for access to its technology. But pressure was growing on the company to show that it could actually develop a drug. ``People were beginning to say, `When are we going to see the proof here?''' said Rachel Leheny, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. The drug, taken orally, is for obesity and is being developed with Abbott Laboratories. The drug inhibits an enzyme that may play a role in regulating metabolism. The new drug, called MLN4760, joins only a handful of other drugs in the pharmaceutical industry that were developed using genomics. Millennium has several other drugs being tested in patients, but those were acquired from other companies. Millennium's shares rose 2 cents, to $33.52.  HARDWARE  CHIP MACHINE SALES SLIP FURTHER  Still suffering through its worst slump ever, the chip-making equipment industry in the third quarter shipped products worth less than half as much in total and took in a quarter as many new orders as during the year-earlier period, a trade association said. The group, Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, based in San Jose, Calif., said equipment suppliers worldwide reported shipments worth $5.6 billion, a 56 percent drop from the $13.0 billion in the comparable 2000 period and a 20 percent drop from the second quarter of this year. Projecting a bleak outlook for shipments during the fourth quarter and early next year, when goods ordered between July and September will be shipped, new orders last quarter were $3.47 billion, down 77 percent from the $15.49 billion in the third quarter of 2000. ``We don't see clear signals for a sustainable recovery in the near term,'' said Elizabeth Schumann, the association's director of research and statistics. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011127.0224 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-TERROR-ADVISORY-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The New York Times plans these stories, photos and graphics on the situation in Afghanistan and the terrorist attacks on the United States for the paper of Wednesday, Nov. 28. OTHER STORIES  International  AFGHAN-CHAOS (Kunduz, Afghanistan) _ Lawlessness has become the rule in northern cities across Afghanistan, witness the killing of a Swedish journalist in an apparent robbery, and the stipping of a hospital here of all medicine, food and other supplies. By C.J. Chivers.  AFGHAN-WOMEN (Kabul, Afghanistan) _ The Northern Alliance barred women from marching on behalf of a larger political voice in the post-Taliban government. By David Rohde.  AFGHAN-TALKS (Bonn, Germany) _ Negotiations on a post-Taliban Afghanistan get under way with warnings, to Afghan factions and outside countries, not to repeat the mistakes of the past. By Steven Erlanger.  AFGHAN-TALKS-VOICES (Jalalabad, Afghanistan) _ Doctors, teachers, preachers and the boys in the bazaar comment on Tuesday's conference in Bonn, the prospects for a broad-based Afghan government and why ``Afghan coalition'' is or is not an oxymoron. By Tim Weiner.  TERROR-BRITAIN (London) _ Extradition hearing opens for Lotfi Raissi, an Algerian suspected of training some of the pilots in the Sept. 11 attacks, who faces charges in the U.S. that he gave false testimony in applying for a pilot's license. By Alan Cowell.  TERROR-PAKISTAN (Islamabad, Pakistan) _ Pakistan said Tuesday that it had detained two retired nuclear scientists after the recent discovery in offices frequented by them in Afghanistan of documents describing ways to use anthrax as a weapon and other suspicious material. By Douglas Frantz and Jeff Gerth.  National  AIRPORT-SECURITY (Washington) _ Transportation Secretary Mineta talks about the new transportation security agency within his department. He says it may be impossible to meet the mid-January statutory deadline for inspecting all checked baggage. He also sets a goal of no more than 10 minutes to clear security screening at all U.S. airports. By Matthew L. Wald.  TERROR-DETAIN (Undated) _ The Justice Department has quietly tightened the rules that govern the detention of foreigners in the United States, allowing the government to hold an alien indefinitely even after a federal immigration judge has ordered the alien to be released for lack of evidence. By David Firestone.  ANTHRAX-CHILE (Orlando, Fla.) _ More on the anthrax-contaminated letter sent to a Chilean doctor with a return address from an Orlando medical publisher. By Dana Canedy. The night supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Pat Ryan; phone: 888-346-9867; e-mail: patryan(at)nytimes.com.  EXP-ATTACK-UPRISING (Qala Jangi, Afghanistan) _ The Northern Alliance crushed a two-day uprising of Taliban prisoners of war, an effort that, according to the victors, required a tank firing point-blank into a house containing the last holdouts. American and British troops assisted. By Carlotta Gall.  EXP-ATTACK-MILITARY (Dateline to come) _ Military developments: briefing at Central Command in Tampa. By James Dao and Thom Shanker.  EXP-ATTACK-PRISONERS (Tashgurghan, Afghanistan) _ Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate. The prisoners were the sorry byproduct of the Northern Alliance's most recent victory, in Kunduz. Mostly illiterate young men from Pakistan, they were not being allowed to return to their homes, like the Taliban from Afghanistan. By Dexter Filkins.  EXP-AFGHAN-TALKS (Bonn, Germany) _ Negotiations on a post-Taliban Afghanistan get under way with warnings, to Afghan factions and outside countries, not to repeat the mistakes of the past. By Steven Erlanger.  EXP-AFGHAN-DEFECT (Quetta, Pakistan) _ At least on the outside, Mullah Amirjan Selabe had already begun to reinvent himself. After slipping across the border out of Afghanistan, he had unfurled the Taliban's telltale black turban, replacing it with a gray one with white stripes. Selabe is one of countless Taliban soldiers or commanders who have disappeared by melding themselves in Afghan communities in Pakistan. By Norimitsu Onishi.  EXP-MIDEAST-U.S. (Afula, Israel) _ Two Palestinian gunmen went on a suicidal shooting spree Tuesday through the heart of this northern Israeli city, killing 2, seriously wounding 10 and providing a billboard for Israelis' security fears during the visit of U.S. envoys seeking a cease-fire. By James Bennet.  EXP-TERROR-ASHCROFT (Washington) _ Attorney General John Ashcroft said Tuesday that about 600 people are in jail in connection with the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks, and some of them, he added, are members of the al-Qaida terrorist network who may have been planning additional terrorist incidents. By David Johnston.  EXP-NY-VICTIM-MIXUP (New York) _ The identity of two victims in the World Trade Center attack were switched and officials are now trying to set it right. By N.R. Kleinfield.  EXP-ANTHRAX-CT (dateline to come) _ The death of an 84-year-old man who lived in the same area as the elderly woman who died of inhalation anthrax last week does not appear to be related, Gov. John G. Rowland said Tuesday. The man died at home, several weeks ago, and his body was not discovered for a few days, Rowland said. ``The 84-year-old man from Seymour did not die from anthrax,'' he said. By Paul Zielbauer.  EXP-ENRON-MARKETPLACE (Undated) _ Hobbled energy giant Enron Corp.'s. dizzying stock market flameout worsened on Monday, as its shares fell again amid growing doubts that its buyout by smaller rival Dynegy Inc. would go through as planned. By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Andrew Ross Sorkin.  QUESTIONS OR RERUNS: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927:  The day supervisor is Gary E. McCardell (E-mail, garymc(at)nytimes.com). Business Day Front Page of The New York Times, Wednesday, Nov. 28.  (Top lede)  ENRON-MARKETPLACE (Undated) _ Enron Corp. and Dynegy Inc. struggled Tuesday to find ways to bolster confidence in Enron's energy-trading business as the companies' negotiators continued talks on revising the terms of their merger, executives close to the talks said. Dynegy, they said, was prepared to invest an additional $500 million in Enron, but Dynegy wants the new cash backed by hard assets. By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Andrew Ross Sorkin.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  (Center display)  MASS-FLEECE-MILL (Undated) _ It is another unhappy holiday season for Aaron M. Feuerstein, the widely admired New England mill owner whose textile company, Malden Mills, is again on the brink of disaster. After a Christmas-season fire six years ago ravaged his factory in Lawrence, Mass., Feuerstein won plaudits for rebuilding the mill from top to bottom and for paying his idled workers for months. By the time the new factory reopened nearly two years later, he had rehired most of his 2,700 employees. Now the private company is mired in debt and facing bankruptcy. By Lynnley Browning.  With photos and graphic.  (Story has moved.)  (Center right)  MICROSOFT-EUROPE (Undated) _ Offering a strong signal that it wants to settle its antitrust case in Europe, Microsoft has told the European Commission that it will forgo its right to a hearing next month, company officials and European regulators said Tuesday. By Steve Lohr with Paul Meller.  (Scheduled to move by 8 p.m. ET.)  (Bottom right)  AUTO-SALES (Detroit) _ Auto sales have remained surprisingly strong this month _ easing the recession, economists say, and possibly shortening it, with automakers beginning to announce plans to increase production more than initially expected early next year to rebuild inventories. By Danny Hakim.  (Scheduled to move by 8:15 p.m. ET.)  (Bottom center)  TV-BURNETT (Undated) _ In a development that stunned most television industry executives, a CBS special Monday night featuring old clips and outtakes from the Carol Burnett variety show, which left the air in 1978, attracted almost 30 million viewers, one of the biggest audiences this season. By Bill Carter.  With graphic.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  Here are tonight's columns and regular features:  BUSINESS-TRAVEL (Undated) _ Air fares dropped 19.2 percent last month compared with October 2000, according to the Air Transport Association's Office of Economics. Cheaper fares didn't put more customers in the seats, though. Domestic passenger traffic was off 22 percent, and the number of people flying internationally on domestic airlines fell 31 percent in October, the airline trade association said. By Joe Sharkey.  (Scheduled to move by 8 p.m. ET.)  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World business news in brief.  (The briefs have moved.)  TECH-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Technology news in brief.  (The briefs have moved.)  BIZGLANCE (Undated) _ Digest of the day's financial stories.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET.)  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. , they said,	 In its report on existing home sales, the realtors association said  sales were running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.17 million  units. The group expects sales this year to be the second-highest on  record, and, with mortgage rates averaging about 6.6 percent, another  uptick is expected in the spring. Sales in the Northeast rose 10.2  percent in October and were 3.2 percent above last year. The median  existing-home price was $142,800, a 3.5 percent rise from last year. The PMs news desk, 212-556-1927, opens at 7 a.m. Eastern Time. To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI DataNews.  NYT News Service  INTERNATIONAL _ (Moved in ``i'' category)  ATTACK-PRISONERS (Tashgurghan, Afghanistan) _ Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate. The prisoners were the sorry byproduct of the Northern Alliance's most recent victory, in Kunduz. It was a defeated army. The prisoners had come to this spot to wait for some word on their final destination. By Dexter Filkins.  With photos, NYT1-4.  ATTACK-UPRISING (Qala Jangi, Afghanistan) _ The Northern Alliance crushed a two-day uprising of Taliban prisoners of war, an effort that, according to the victors, required a tank firing point-blank into a house containing the last holdouts. U.S. and British troops assisted. By Carlotta Gall.  MIDEAST-U.S. (Afula, Israel) _ Two Palestinian gunmen went on a suicidal shooting spree Tuesday through the heart of this northern Israeli city, killing 2, seriously wounding 10 and providing a billboard for Israelis' security fears during the visit of U.S. envoys seeking a cease-fire. By James Bennet.  SAFRICA-AIDS (Mtubatuba, South Africa) _ The role traditional doctors play in spreading or not spreading AIDS. By Donald G. McNeil Jr.  MICROSOFT-EUROPE (Undated) _ Offering a strong signal that it wants to settle its antitrust case in Europe, Microsoft has told the European Commission that it will forgo its right to a hearing next month, company officials and European regulators said Tuesday. By Steve Lohr with Paul Meller.  NATIONAL _ GENERAL (Moved in ``a'' category)  TERROR-ASHCROFT (Washington) _ Attorney General John Ashcroft said Tuesday that about 600 people are in jail in connection with the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks, and some of them, he added, are members of the al-Qaida terrorist network who may have been planning additional terrorist incidents. By David Johnston.  TERROR-DETAIN-ASSESS (Washington) _ A news analysis on the decision by the administration to release a list of those who remain in federal custody. By Todd S. Purdum.  NY-VICTIM-MIXUP (New York) _ The identity of two victims in the World Trade Center attack were switched and officials are now trying to set it right. By N.R. Kleinfield.  WASHINGTON _ (Moved in ``w'' category)  AIRPORT-SECURITY (Washington) _ Transportation Secretary Mineta talks about the new transportation security agency within his department. He says it may be impossible to meet the mid-January statutory deadline for inspecting all checked baggage. He also sets a goal of no more than 10 minutes to clear security screening at all U.S. airports. By Matthew L. Wald.  SCOTUS (Washington) _ A roundup: The Supreme Court dismisses the Adarand case, ending a long-running attempt by conservatives to end the federal government's affirmative action program for government contracts. Other high court activity. By Linda Greenhouse.  SCIENCE (``a'' code)  SCI-EXTRASOLAR-PLANET (Undated) _ NASA scientists use the Hubble telescope to observe the atmosphere of an extrasolar planet for the first time. By John Noble Wilford.  BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)  ENRON (Undated) _ Following developments: Shares of Enron are down 2 percent to less than $4 after a brief surge at the opening amid optimism that Dynegy would proceed with an acquisition after renegotiating the terms of its offer. By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Andrew Ross Sorkin.  MASS-FLEECE-MILL (Lawrence, Mass.) _ Malden Mills Industries, known for its decision to rebuild here and keep on its workers after a devastating fire in 1995, is on the brink of bankruptcy. While the company says that it is optimistic that it will receive the additional funds it needs to pay for raw materials and other operating costs this week, it acknowledges that a Chapter 11 filing is still a possibility. Looking at what led to the collapse of Malden Mills, the maker of Polartec fleece fabric down. By Lynnley Browning.  EGYPT-TOURISM (Cairo) _ When developers started building Egypt's first private international airport three years ago at the Red Sea resort of Marsa Alam, they had visions of tourists by the thousands whisked from the cold and damp of the north European winter to enjoy fun in the sun. Then came Sept. 11. Now the airport gets one plane a week, the hotels are half-closed or shut down entirely, and the whole of the Egyptian tourist industry, its most important source of revenue, is gasping for breath. By Abeer Allam.  LLOYDS-OUTLOOK (Undated) _ Lloyd's of London raises its estimate of losses from Sept. 11 to $2.68 billion from an initial forecast in September of $1.8 billion. Lloyd's says the losses were still manageable. By Joseph B. Treaster.  COMMENTARY (Moved in ``k'' category)  DOWD-COLUMN _ In three decades, feminism has done a back flip. Once men in uniform were the oppressors. Now they're trophy mates. Once cops were pigs. Now they're foxes. Once firemen were the guys you brought home if you couldn't snag a doctor. Now they're the most sizzling accessory.By MAUREEN DOWD  SPORTS (Moved in ``s'' category)  BKN-WISE-COLUMN (East Rutherford, N.J.) _ Sports of The Times on the Nets, who are a healthy, and surprising, 9-5 this season and are actually in first place in their division. They play the Bulls in a 7:30 p.m. game. By Mike Wise.  BBO-OWNERS (Chicago) _ Baseball owners meet again in Chicago to discuss contraction, and to most likely give Commissioner Bud Selig a second term. By Murray Chass. , he said,	 After the age of 15, he said, he refused to play any of the signature chord voicings of McCoy Tyner, Herbie Hancock or Chick Corea. ``Look, those are three of the greatest pianists of all time,'' he said. ``I couldn't possibly outdo them at their own game.'' , he says,	 For Hockney, the proof is in the paintings. By looking at the art itself, he says, one can find aspects that could have been done only with the help of optics: highlights in Vermeer; a woman who seems to have two elbows on the same arm in Chardin's ``Return From the Market''; the pattern on a carpet in Lorenzo Lotto's ``Husband and Wife.'' Having studied paintings with Falco, Hockney said, ``It is inconceivable that artists wouldn't have used such devices.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 At the symposium, Liedtke, Tinterow and Steadman are speaking on the same panel, on Saturday at 5 p.m. Chuck Close, also a panelist, said, ``I really support David's view that from a point when lenses existed, and people saw what the world looked like flattened out, art definitively changed.'' The primary resistance from art historians, he said, is ``that there are no eyewitness accounts.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 Hockney said that before photography, artists used lenses to project images of their subjects, images that were ephemeral, ``until the chemical process could freeze it on a piece of paper.'' An optical projection looks like a photograph, he said, ``except that it has soft edges.'' When Hockney demonstrates the process, people say the results resemble a painting. ``The paintings looked like optical projections because they came first,'' he said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he added,	 Linear perspective, he added, does not allow artists to paint patterns, to follow folds in material or shine in armor. He decided that for such detailed work, they may have had optical instruments. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 Hockney insists he is not accusing artists of cheating. A device like a camera lucida, he said, is difficult to use and is ``just a tool _ it doesn't paint the picture.'' Though art historians may disagree, he believes that knowing more about the technique enhances art appreciation. As he said, ``It made a lot of pictures more interesting _ certainly not less so.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz

, they said,	 Both generals also said that while they were confident that most local members of the Taliban would embrace peace and a chance at normal civilian life, there remained risks of isolated uprisings. For this reason, they said, several hundred alliance soldiers would remain in the city. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, I guess,	 So here comes new life Saturday night for the Longhorns, with Hicks watching on TV from Georgia. His social calendar, however, is clear for early January. ``I will be at either the Rose Bowl or the Fiesta Bowl,'' he said, which, I guess, was a personal prediction for the Colorado game. Randy Galloway's Sports at Six can be heard weeknights, 6-8 p.m., on WBAP News Talk 820. rgalloway\Nstar-telegram.com nn </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011128.0439 type=story > <HEADLINE> ENGINEERS HAVE CULPRIT IN PART OF TRADE CENTER COLLAPSE: DIESEL </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> NEW YORK (BC-WTC-COLLAPSE-ART-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, it seems,	 Every night, it seems, came the clarion call of Michele Bergsohn. It went like this: ``Alvin! Make it lower! I'm trying to talk on the phone!'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, she resisted,	 While a mutual friend pleaded for months with Havlish to meet her future husband, a senior vice president at Aon, she resisted, convinced, though she had never seen him, that the relationship would never work. ``Guys do not like women with two kids,'' Mrs. Havlish told the friend. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 ``I'll never forget, on the night before our wedding, at the rehearsal dinner, he said, `Tomorrow I'm marrying my best friend,''' she said. ``That said it all.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011128.0450 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS:  All photos and graphics from the New York Times News Service are available at nytimages.com. (NYT60) JALALABAD, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-JALALABAD -- American forces have enlisted commanders in eastern Afghanistan to help search for Osama bin Laden in isolated mountain hide-outs south of the city of Jalalabad, a senior minister of the regional government said on Wednesday. Hajji Zaman Khan Ghum Shareek, center, the Jalalabad commander of the Eastern Shura, the self-proclaimed government in Jalalabad says he had asked a scouting party of tribal leaders to go to Tora Bora, a mountain redoubt about 35 miles southwest of Jalalabad. Shareek says he is ``90 percent sure'' that bin Laden and senior members of al-Qaida were hiding there.'' (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)  (NYT59) JALALABAD, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-TALKS-VOICES-4 -- With the Taliban gone from the northeastern city of Jalalabad, the bazaar is once again a marketplace of ideas. Trading is heavy as people taking pleasure in thinking out loud argue how to run this country. Via shortwave radio, they are keeping a watch on the Rhine, where talks on forming a representative Afghan government entered their second day on Wednesday at a well-appointed hotel across the river from Bonn. ``A broad-based government under the umbrella of Zahir Shah would be helpful for the Afghan nation,'' says Wahidullah Adil, left, 23, a tailor in Jalalabad. ``They have to give power to a multi-ethnic and politically diverse government. I want a democracy, without people lording it over one another. Two years later, he was catapulted to fame with the production of his first play, ``Short Eyes,'' a graphic portrayal of life, love and death among prison inmates. Now his life blazes on-screen in ``Pinero,'' which opens in New York and Los Angeles on Dec. 14. Pinero, at a rehearsal of his first play, ``Short Eyes,'' at the Public Theater in New York in 1974. Even Queen Victoria, so austere in public, was a party girl at heart. This is the underlying premise of ``Exposed: The Victorian Nude,'' an entertaining exhibition running through Jan. 27 in Tate Britain's Linbury Galleries in London. ``Lady Godiva's Prayer,'' by Edwin Landseer, around 1865, is on view at the Tate Britain. (James Estrin/The New York Times) LITE  (NYT38) HLABISA, South Africa -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- SAFRICA-AIDS-MEN -- Patrons of a bar in Hlabisa, South Africa, say they often refuse to use condoms, citing Zulu customs, their views about sex and cynicism about the quality of foreign condoms. Cynicism about condoms is virtually universal. For years, the government's slipshod testing practices had made South Africa a dumping ground for substandard foreign condoms, and many tell stories of having them break. (Joao Silva/The New York Times)  (NYT37) MTUBATUBA, South Africa -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- SAFRICA-AIDS-WOMEN -- At least a third of the adults in rural KwaZulu/Natal province, which has a population of 8 million, have HIV. This is the worst infection rate in a country that has more people infected with the virus than any in the world. It is assumed that the disease spread rapidly here because truckers from all over southern Africa pass through on their way to the port at Durban. Nosipho, left, and Phindile, say they ask their customers to use condoms, but other prostitutes in Mtubatuba, South Africa, do not. (Joao Silva/The New York Times)  (NYT36) JALALABAD, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-TALKS-VOICES-3 -- With the Taliban gone from the northeastern city of Jalalabad, the bazaar is once again a marketplace of ideas. Trading is heavy as people taking pleasure in thinking out loud argue how to run this country. Via shortwave radio, they are keeping a watch on the Rhine, where talks on forming a representative Afghan government entered their second day on Wednesday at a well-appointed hotel across the river from Bonn. ``This is a turning point for Afghanistan, maybe for the whole world,'' says Noor Muhammad, 30, a shopkeeper selling prized possessions at the flea market in Jalalabad. ``I'm very hopeful about this meeting in Germany. We have to be. The Afghan crisis has left our neighbors and the whole world in crisis.'' (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)  (NYT35) JALALABAD, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-TALKS-VOICES-2 -- With the Taliban gone from the northeastern city of Jalalabad, the bazaar is once again a marketplace of ideas. (NYT32) UNDATED -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- OLD-MASTERS-OPTICS -- More than 25 curators and scholars, artists and art historians will gather at New York University this weekend to discuss David Hockney's iconoclastic theory that old masters, all the way back to 1430, used optical devices to help them produce realistic images. Hockney recently published his findings in a lavishly illustrated book, ``Secret Knowledge: Rediscovering the Lost Techniques of the Old Masters.'' Hockney poses on the cover of his new book. A false alarm can be silenced by pushing a button on a remote control that does not have to be programmed by the user. No building like it -- a modern steel-reinforced high-rise -- had ever collapsed because of an uncontrolled fire. A smoldering 7 World Trade Center two days after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- BLACKBURN-CRAFTS-3 -- Janice Blackburn is known in Britain as a high-end tastemaker, and her passionate and uncompromising adoption of the crafts world has put a telling imprimatur on an emerging artistic market. (Susana Raab/The New York Times) MAGS OUT--NO SALES  (NYT13) NEW YORK -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- CIR-HOSP-KIDS-2 -- The Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx,N.Y. fulfills the technological visions of its founders. The hospital is built on the theory that even brief encounters in a child's life can leave indelible marks. ``We are not only here to heal the children,'' says Dr. Irwin Redlener, president of the Children's Hospital, which opened a month ago. ``We want to help create a life-changing experience. Living in some of the neighborhoods in the Bronx can give children a limited sense of their future. We want them to think anything is possible.'' Redlener stands by a pendulum in the lobby of the hospital. (James Estrin/The New York Times)  (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- CIR-HOSP-KIDS -- The Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx,N.Y. fulfills the technological visions of its founders. The hospital is built on the theory that even brief encounters in a child's life can leave indelible marks. The Internet, a gold mine of educational materials, makes the hospital's mission much simpler. After reviewing tens of thousands of Web pages, the hospital administrators cobbled together an intranet, which will go online next week. From their bed-side computers, patients will have links to 2,000 Web sites. Precious Feliciano tests an overhead monitor linked to the Internet as Dr. Irwin Redlener looks on. (Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)  (NYT11) CHAMAN BORDER CROSSING, Pakistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-BORDER -- An armed Taliban soldier patrols on the Afghan side of the Chaman border crossing, Wednesday. Although U.S. marines have landed in Kandahar, about a two hour drive from Chaman, the border remained quiet and the situation across the border remained unclear. Rumors of the Taliban handing over control of the town of Spin Boldak to Pashtun tribal leaders could not be confirmed.  (Ruth Fremson/ New York Times)  (NYT10) MAZAR-E-SHARIF, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-AFGHAN-6 -- Gen. Rashid Dostum, center, a senior Northern Alliance commander whose headquarters is in the fortress devastated by a bloody three-day uprising, during a tour of the facility, Wednesday. Dostum said Wednesday 30 of his fighters were killed and 200 wounded. Alliance officials said earlier that some 450 Taliban were killed. (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT9) MAZAR-E-SHARIF, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-AFGHAN-5 -- A Northern Alliance fighter among corpses in the dusty courtyard of a mud-walled Afghan fortress Wednesday after a three-day uprising by Taliban prisoners. (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT8) TALOQAN, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-SCENE-4 -- Ramazani Yosufi, 22, a fighter with the Northern Alliance, right, returns a shot to his colleagues during a volleyball game in Taloqan, Wednesday. Yousufi, who has known war all his life, said that despite always wanting to play. today was his first opportunity. Taloqan was captured by the Northern Alliance from the Taliban militia earlier this month. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT7) TALOQAN, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-SCENE-3 -- Haji Mir prepares the morning supply of bread at his bakery in Taloqan, Wednesday. The city was captured from Taliban forces last week. Mir has been selling bread in the city for the past 10 years. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT6) TALOQAN, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-SCENE-2 -- Shoppers walk past a window in Haji Mir's bakery in Taloqan, Wednesday. The city was captured from Taliban forces last week. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT5) DASHTE QALA, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- AFGHAN-SCENE-1 -- A boy struggles to control a young donkey while crossing the Darihona River, Wednesday. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)  (NYT4) MAZAR-E-SHARIF, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-AFGHAN-4 -- Northern alliance fighters turn over the body of a Taliban militiaman on Wednesday in the courtyard of an Afghan fortress after an uprising by prisoners. The fighting erupted Sunday when hundreds of non-Afghans, who had fought with the Taliban, were brought to the fortress after the weekend surrender of Kunduz, the Islamic militia's last stronghold in the north. Once inside, the men stormed the armory and rose up against their alliance c aptors. (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT3) MAZAR-E-SHARIF, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-AFGHAN-3 -- Northern alliance fighters wandered among corpses in the dusty courtyard of a mud-walled Afghan fortress Wednesday after a three-day uprising by Taliban prisoners. (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT2) MAZAR-E-SHARIF, Afghanistan -- Nov. 28, 2001 -- ATTACK-AFGHAN-2 -- Northern alliance fighters wandered among corpses in the dusty courtyard of a mud-walled Afghan fortress Wednesday after a three-day uprising by Taliban prisoners. , he said,	 Dahmani said he quit his job at Sunset Market in late June and flew to Boston to get married to the former Jennifer Yeager, a native of Toledo, Ohio. While in Massachusetts, he said, he had no contact with any of the 19 hijackers preparing for the Sept. 11 suicide attacks, none of whom he claims he was ever acquainted with. Two of the four planes in the attacks took off from Boston's Logan International Airport. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 ``I won't rule out the possibility that Microchip emerges from this downturn as the leader,'' CEO Steve Sanghi said. Microchip's focus on microcontrollers and consistent corporate strategy, he said, has helped it win customers over Motorola, a giant in chip and cellphone products. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 He says he feels confident about the economy and isn't afraid to take on debt. Low mortgage rates have tempted him to buy a new house, he said, but he put that purchase off for other reasons. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 English, who had been appointed to represent Indonesian student Agus Budiman, cited a conflict of interest in stepping down. The former Army officer said he had friends who were killed when one of the hijacked planes hit the Pentagon. His wife, he said, works for the Department of the Army. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he thinks,	 McCaffrey admires President Bush. Ultimately, he thinks, Bush must go after the entire gamut of states that support terrorism, getting them to change their ways, either by persuasion or by force. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 ``It's a god-awful process,'' said Dr. A. George Bennett, who retired in June as a professor of aerospace engineering at Mississippi State University, in Starkville, and as the director of the university's Raspet Flight Research Lab. Quality control must be exacting, he said, to assure that there are no bubbles left in the material that can form voids, making the structure weaker, or other errors in curing the matrix. The Federal Aviation Administration requires strict quality-control procedures. One problem is that ``pre-preg'' must be kept refrigerated until use, and it has a short shelf life. </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz
, he said,	 The strength-to-weight ratio of carbon is about twice that for aluminum, Bennett said. But the actual weight saving is closer to 25 percent because builders must add extra epoxy and fiber where fittings are attached. Still, he said, 25 percent is ``a terrific incentive.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200111.gz

, she adds,	 While it's wise not to suspend these diminutive treasures from a tree when lit, the lights still add a festive warmth to hearth and home. ``We use our lights as year-round decorations,'' says Heatley. ``They're gorgeous even unlit in a sunny windowsill,'' lining a dining table lit by foil-wrapped tea-light candles, or scattered throughout the house as candy holders. , he prevails,	 _ You don't have to be perfect. Harry's not your standard hero. In fact, he's rather gawky, and his hair won't even stay in place. ``He has a scar on his forehead. INTERNATIONAL  (Will move in `i' news category)  ATTACK-MILITARY (Washington) _ Military developments in Afghanistan. By James Dao.  ATTACK-HUNT (Washington) _ Developments in the hunt for Osmama bin Laden. By Thom Shanker and James Risen.  ATTACK-MAZAR (Mazar-e-Sharif, Afghanistan) _ Developments: Northern Alliance forces are continuing to find live Taliban prisoners in the fortress near Mazar-e-Sharif. The U.N. human rights commissioner calls for an inquiry. By Carlotta Gall.  ATTACK-EXECUTE (Islamabad, Pakistan) _ Anti-Taliban Pashtun forces confirmed that they did execute 160 captured Taliban near Spin Baldak last week. There are also reports that British troops entered Pakistan in hot pursuit. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld will be speaking with Pakistan journalists in a session to be broadcast in Pakistan. By Douglas Frantz.  AFGHAN-DIPLO (Washington) _ Splits are emerging between the U.S. and Europe over the composition of an international security force for a post-Taliban Afghanistan. Washington has said that it will not contribute troops to any kind of peacekeeping force. Europe, on the other hand, wants American participation. By Patrick E. Tyler.  AFGHAN-TALKS (Bonn, Germany) _ Negotiations continue among the various Afghan groups on the shape of a future Afghan government. By Steven Erlanger.  TERROR-ITALY (Milan) _ Police arrest two North Africans suspected of links to al-Qaida. By Melinda Henneberger.  ATTACK-OVERVIEW (Undated) _ A synoptic look at the day's news related to the situation in Afghanistan and terrorist attacks in the United States. By Clyde Haberman. (700 words)  NKOREA-U.S. (Seoul, South Korea) _ North Korea angrily rejects American calls for weapons inspections and threatens to take ``necessary countermeasures'' if the United States does not change its ``hostile'' attitude toward the reclusive communist state. By Don Kirk.  EURO-PRICE-HIKES (Frankfurt, Germany) _ One month before euros become the new common currency in 12 European countries, the great price re-shuffle is in full swing, and many people are not amused as consumer surveys find price hikes that appear tied to the euro changeover. By Edmund L. Andrews.  POLAND-POLITICS (Warsaw) _ The deputy speaker of parliament is ousted after calling the foreign minister a ``scoundrel,'' among other things, for moving too quickly on negotiations to join the European Union, demonstrating growing frustration over the bad economy and fears of what joining the union will actually mean for things like farming, foreign ownership of land. By Ian Fisher.  SWITZERLAND-NAZIS (Geneva) _ A report by an independent commission finds that Switzerland helped cover up German economic interests during World War II and benefited from the technical skills of Germans fleeing the collapsing Nazi regime. By Elizabeth Olson.  MIDEAST (Jerusalem) _ On the eve of his departure for the United States, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon says he will not budge from a demand for a week without Palestinian attacks as a condition for peace talks. But in a sign of a growing rift in Israel's government, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres criticizes this security-centered approach, saying that without hope for a resumption of peace talks Palestinians could not be expected to crack down on militants. Meanwhile, the 1,000th victim dies in more than a year of violence. By James Bennet.  WORLD-BRIEFS (Undated) _ The World Briefing column.  UNITED STATES (General)  (Will move in `a' news category)  FLA-BOYS-SLAY (Pensacola, Fla.) _ Boys 12 and 13 charged are with murdering their father and burning their house down. By Dana Canedy.  MEXICO-U.S.-TRUCKS (Undated) _ Folo on the unexpected compromise on Mexican trucks. (staff byline to come)  SPACE-SHUTTLE (Cape Canaveral, Fla.) _ Thursday's Space Shuttle launching was postponed to Friday morning because of a docking problem at the Russian space station. By Warren E. Leary.  NY-POLICE-COUNSELING (New YOrk) _ In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, New York city police officers will have mandatory counseling for the first time, financed by the police foundation and conducted by Columbia University. By Richard Lezin Jones.  TERROR-DAFFODILS (New York) _ A daffodil bulb. The last batch of bulbs, from a million donated by the Dutch and planted throughout the city, will go into the ground Thursday, at a neighborhood garden. The founder of the little plot, one of the first African Americans in the neighborhood who began the garden to help his family truly integrate, lost his only son, a Port Authority policeman, at the World Trade Center. By Jim Dwyer.  With photo.  (Another in a series of articles on how ordinary objects took on new significance because of the terrorist attack.)  UNITED STATES (WASHINGTON)  (Will move in `w' news category)  TERROR-BUSH (Washington) _ A day lede: President Bush talks to federal prosecutors and may address civil liberties issues. The White House says that the Justice Department and Department of Defense are drafting rules for the conduct of Bush's military tribunals. By David E. Sanger.  TERROR-ACCOMPLICE (Washington) _ Agus Budiman, who authorities say has ties to the hijackers, appears in federal court on Thursday. By Philip Shenon and Don Van Natta.  TERROR-ASHCROFT (Washington) _ John Ashcroft, the attorney general, holds out the promise of fast track to U.S. citizenship for foreigners who provide useful information about terrorism. He calls it the ``responsible cooperators program.'' By Neil A. Lewis.  TERROR-RIGHTS (Undated) _ The aggressive expansion of the government's powers to arrest, detain and prosecute people in the war on terrorism seems destined to produce years of litigation that lawyers say will help define the power of the executive branch. By William Glaberson.  TERROR-INTERVIEWS (Undated) _ Is the Bush administration's plan to interview 5,000 men coercive? The Bush administration insists it is not, but an INS memo casts doubt on that claim, legal experts and immigrant advocates say. The memo says that those who are interviewed could be held without bond if investigators develop an interest in them. By William Glaberson.  FINANCIAL  (Will move in `f' news category)  ENRON (Undated) _ A ledeall: Developments in the Enron deathwatch. Shares fall another 34 percent in early trading, to 40 cents, as energy traders and creditors assess their exposure to the teetering company. By Richard A. Oppel and Andrew Ross Sorkin.  With  ENRON-DYNEGY (Undated) _ Dynegy's Chuck Watson ultimately walked away, but made a sharp reversal that has raised questions about Dynegy's prospects. Last week, he pledged to complete the deal and went to great pains to describe how strong Enron's business was. The comments prompted a prominent short seller to short Dynegy. By Alex Berenson.  Others as appropriate.  SMALLPOX-ACAMBIS (Undated) _ What the smallpox vaccine contract means for Acambis, a small British company that does not yet have a product on the market. In London trading, shares of Acambis nearly double. By Melody Petersen.  NORRIS-COLUMN (Undated) _ The weekly column. By Floyd Norris.  Editors, no marketplace column on days with a Norris column.  CRASH-TESTS (Detroit) _ The Jeep Liberty and Ford Explorer both perform poorly in a new bumper collision test by the Insurance Inst. for Highway Safety. For the completely redesigned Explorer, this is embarrassing. For the new Liberty, this also looks bad, especially after it rolled over in a recent AutoWeek driving test. By Danny Hakim.  EUROPE-INTERNET-PRIVACY (Brussels) _ The European Union Council of Ministers is taking a pro-security stance on allowing law enforcement authorities access to phone and Internet traffic data. This collides head-on with the European Parliament's more pro-civil liberties position adopted last week. By Paul Meller.  KOREA-BAILOUTS (Seoul, South Korea) _ A government audit finds pervasive corruption in the government-financed bailouts of troubled companies over the past four years, with $5.3 billion siphoned off by some 4,900 executives and business owners. Yet it recommends prosecution of only 44 people. By Don Kirk.  BRITAIN-BANK (London) _ Standard Chartered replaces Rana Talwar as chief executive with Mervyn Davies, raising fresh speculation about whether the British bank, which gets nearly all its profit from Asia, may be a takeover target. By Alan Cowell.  JAPAN-ECON (Tokyo) _ Japan's economic outlook darkens further as a new report shows that industrial production has fallen to its lowest level in more than 13 years. The Bank of Japan, meanwhile, leaves monetary policy unchanged. By Ken Belson.  INDIA-VSNL (Bangalore, India) _ India says its 53 percent stake in VSNL, the international-calling monopoly and largest Internet service provider, will be privatized in December. The monopoly expires in April 2002. By Saritha Rai.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Short items on business news from around the world.  COMMENTARY (``k'' code)  Thomas L. Friedman's ``Foreign Affairs.''  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  (Will move in `e' news category or as indicated)  MOVIES-TRAVOLTA (Los Angeles) _ Another in the series ``Watching Movies With'': John Travolta sat quietly in a square, well-cushioned chair along the back wall of his home screening room. He had just finished watching ``Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' a glossy Warner Brothers bio-pic about the legendary George M. Cohan, a movie that's been dear to him since he was a little boy in New Jersey dreaming about a life on the stage. Travolta rubbed his eyes. Yes, he had been crying; there was no use denying it. He nodded sheepishly. The movie that had meant so much to him as a boy, he discovered, still had the power to reach into his heart. And now, in the wake of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, what had once seemed corny, flag-waving jingoism in the screen saga of the man who wrote ``You're a Grand Old Flag'' and ``Over There'' instead came across as almost eerily in touch with the current national mood. By Rick Lyman.  With photo.  BROADWAY-REPLACEMENT (New York) _ The wig was loose. The dress was tight. The lift was botched. The turn was late. Well, that's what rehearsing is for, isn't it? Oops, no, sorry. That's the other show business. This was the one where time is money, where an actress and dancer of the caliber of Charlotte d'Amboise was supposed to get it right the first time. One full run-through with the cast _ the put-in, they call it _ was all d'Amboise got before she had to go out there and dance her heart out. In front of a real audience. Hundreds of people with high expectations and newly incurred credit card debt. As the replacement for Karen Ziemba in ``Contact,'' the Tony-winning musical, she was entitled to only one rehearsal with the entire ensemble of dancers and actors, around whom she would have to leap and pirouette eight times a week. Starting here, starting now. Occasionally, new blood can totally transform a show: look at what Reba McEntire did for ``Annie Get Your Gun.'' And frequently, a fresh face invigorates a tired cast that may have entered the zombie phase of its performance cycle. By Peter Marks.  With photo.  IMPRESSIONIST-STILL-LIFE (Washington) _ There's absolutely nothing still about a good still-life painting. And because a high number of the 90 works in ``Impressionist Still Life'' at the Phillips Collection here are exceptionally good to outright great, a show that doesn't promise much on paper feels very active, very alive. By Holland Cotter.  With photo.  The Times will review these films:  ABCD-FILM-REVIEW: ``ABCD''  NECKLACE-FILM-REVIEW: ``The Affair of the Necklace''  BEHIND-FILM-REVIEW: ``Behind Enemy Lines''  INDEPENDENT-FILM-REVIEW: ``The Independent''  PORN-STAR-FILM-REVIEW: ``Porn Star: The Legend of Ron Jeremy''  FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION please contact Gary E. McCardell, the day editor, e-mail garymc(at)nytimes.com; (888) 346-9867 or (212) 556-1927. TERROR-MISSING (Undated) _ The daily feature: A glimpse at the lives of people missing in the World Trade Center attacks.  MEXICO-U.S.-TRUCKS (Undated) _ Folo on the unexpected compromise on Mexican trucks. (staff byline to come)  SPACE-SHUTTLE (Cape Canaveral, Fla.) _ Thursday's Space Shuttle launching was postponed to Friday morning because of a docking problem at the Russian space station. By Warren E. Leary.  NATIONAL-BRIEFS (Undated) _ National news in brief.  FINANCIAL (``f'' code)  Enron  ENRON (Undated) _ A ledeall: Developments in the Enron deathwatch. Shares fall another 34 percent in early trading, to 40 cents, as energy traders and creditors assess their exposure to the teetering company. By Richard A. Oppel and Andrew Ross Sorkin.  ENRON-DYNEGY (Undated) _ Dynegy's Chuck Watson ultimately walked away, but made a sharp reversal that has raised questions about Dynegy's prospects. Last week, he pledged to complete the deal and went to great pains to describe how strong Enron's business was. The comments prompted a prominent short seller to short Dynegy. By Alex Berenson.  ENRON-LIQUIDATE (Undated) _ The growing trend in corporate bankruptcy has been liquidation. Looking at Enron's prospects in today's bankruptcy environment. By Riva D. Atlas.  ENRON-CALIF (Los Angeles) _ Looking at the reaction in California, where Enron has often been portrayed as the villain in that state's messy deregulation. What are the Enron's assets in the state and do power companies and utilities face any exposure from the collapse of Enron? By Laura D. Holson.  Others as appropriate.  Other financial  CONGRESS-INSURE (Washington) _ The House is expected to pass its bill on relief to the insurance industry for future terrorist attacks, along with a wide array of so-called tort reforms sought by conservatives and the White House to limit legal damages and cap lawyers' fees, while Senate Democrats continue to negotiate over terms of similar measure without the tort changes. House vote is expected late Thursday afternoon. By Stephen Labaton.  SMALLPOX-ACAMBIS (Undated) _ What the smallpox vaccine contract means for Acambis, a small British company that does not yet have a product on the market. In London trading, shares of Acambis nearly double. By Melody Petersen.  NORRIS-COLUMN (Undated) _ The weekly column. By Floyd Norris.  Editors, no marketplace column on days with a Norris column.  CRASH-TESTS (Detroit) _ The Jeep Liberty and Ford Explorer both perform poorly in a new bumper collision test by the Insurance Inst. for Highway Safety. For the completely redesigned Explorer, this is embarrassing. For the new Liberty, this also looks bad, especially after it rolled over in a recent AutoWeek driving test. By Danny Hakim.  AT-HOME-INTERNET (Undated) _ A federal bankruptcy judge may allow At Home to suspend Internet service. But few expect a shutdown of the service, which has 4r million customers. Looking at what's at stake for AT&AMP;T, the cable industry and consumers. By Matt Richtel.  EUROPE-INTERNET-PRIVACY (Brussels) _ The European Union Council of Ministers is taking a pro-security stance on allowing law enforcement authorities access to phone and Internet traffic data. This collides head-on with the European Parliament's more pro-civil liberties position adopted last week. By Paul Meller.  TECH-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Technology news in brief.  KOREA-BAILOUTS (Seoul, South Korea) _ A government audit finds pervasive corruption in the government-financed bailouts of troubled companies over the past four years, with $5.3 billion siphoned off by some 4,900 executives and business owners. Yet it recommends prosecution of only 44 people. By Don Kirk.  BRITAIN-BANK (London) _ Standard Chartered replaces Rana Talwar as chief executive with Mervyn Davies, raising fresh speculation about whether the British bank, which gets nearly all its profit from Asia, may be a takeover target. By Alan Cowell.  JAPAN-ECON (Tokyo) _ Japan's economic outlook darkens further as a new report shows that industrial production has fallen to its lowest level in more than 13 years. The Bank of Japan, meanwhile, leaves monetary policy unchanged. By Ken Belson.  IRELAND-BANK (Dublin) _ In an innovative deal that may show how banking and other services can be kept viable in the depopulating Western European countryside, Allied Irish Banks signs a deal with the Irish postal system that will effectively make every rural post office a limited-service branch bank of AIB. Post offices here, as in much of Europe, are small franchise-like businesses somewhat like a convenience store, and they stand to benefit as much as the bank will. By Warren E. Leary.  INDIA-VSNL (Bangalore, India) _ India says its 53 percent stake in VSNL, the international-calling monopoly and largest Internet service provider, will be privatized in December. The monopoly expires in April 2002. By Saritha Rai.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Short items on business news from around the world.  COMMENTARY (``k'' code)  Thomas L. Friedman's ``Foreign Affairs.''  MOVING LATER:  AM-ADD-NYT-BUDGET _ A rundown of culture, lifestyle, sports, and special section stories will move by 3:00 p.m. ET.
