INTERNATIONAL (i)  ATTACK-MADRASSAS (Peshawar, Pakistan) _ Pakistan, ever more wary of  the brand of Islamic fundamentalism it has bred, is cracking down on  madrassas, trying to expel all foreign students and trying to control  the curriculum. But so far such efforts appear for naught. By Yvonne  Abraham. 1100 words.  ATTACK-RIGHTS (Undated) _ What obligation, if any, do US soldiers  have to stop human rights abuses being committed in front of them by  their Northern Alliance allies? By Elizabeth Neuffer. 950 words.  ATTACK-AID (Khoja Ghar District, Afghanistan) _ A few weeks ago,  food packets were falling from the sky. Now it's parkas, hats, gloves,  blankets and sleeping bags. But in further evidence of the lawlessness  of Northern Afghanistan, the drops are falling into the hands of local  bandits, who hear the C-17s coming, stake out the territory, and grab  the goods. By David Filipov. 1220 words.  ATTACK-BOMBS (Kabul, Afghanistan) _ Fourteen teams of detonation  specialists, along with the UN Mine Action Program, are fanning out to  31 airstrike targets throughout Kabul this week in search of live  ordnance left over from the weeks of US-led attacks. Their work is  critical to restoring a degree of normalcy around this nerve center. By  Patrick Healy. 700 words.  COMMENTARY (k)  JACOBY-COLUMN (Undated) _ The constant enlargement of ``civil  rights'' exacts a price. It cheats private owners of their property  rights, replaces voluntary interaction with intimidation and force, and  teaches aggrieved groups to use the law to compel changes instead of  using persuasion and education to change minds. By Jeff Jacoby.  VENNOCHI-COLUMN (Undated) _  Jane Swift, the acting governor, is  trying to show evidence of solid political strength and long-term  political viability. It isn't easy to come by, even with Andrew Card's  help in dousing a rumor that he wants to run for governor. By Joan  Vennochi.  LIFESTYLE (l)  CHILDCARE-COLUMN (Undated) _ There are three trends in toys that  professional toy-watchers are warning parents away from this holiday  season: toys with electronic or computer technology; toys spun off from  Hollywood creations, and war toys. By Barbara Meltz. 1700 words.  BEAM-COLUMN (Undated) -- No one ever says anything nice about the  French, perhaps with cause. But they are currently involved in a thank  you project that is doubtless making them some friends and influencing a  person or two. By Alex Beam.  BEDFORD-PLOT (Undated) _ The New Bedford school plot raises  questions for parents. Among them: Does anyone really know what their  kids are up to? Parents debate the troubling matter of how far to go  when monitoring your kids, and what to do when you suspect they're  getting themselves into trouble. By Bella English. 1350 words.  BEDFORD-TEENS (Undated) _ For most parents of teenagers, the  revelations early this week about a Columbine-esque plot at New Bedford  High School boil down to a simple yet heart-wrenching question: What  about my child? Is he or she somehow on a trajectory that could lead to  a catastrophic conclusion? By Barbara Meltz. 1050 words.  HOMESTYLE (l)  GARDEN-COLUMN (Apopka, Fla.) _ When people think of Florida farming,  they think of oranges. In Apopka, however, the cash crop is houseplants  _ millions of them. In fact, some of the ones in your living room  probably came from this small city in the flat sunny heart of Florida  that produces almost half the country's indoor foliage plants. By Carol  Stocker. 1510 words.  HANDYMAN-HOTTON (Undated) _ The Globe Handyman answers readers'  questions. By Peter C. Hotton.  AUTOMOTIVE (l, f)  AUTOS-COLUMN (Las Vegas) _ This is where Charlie the Tuner goes on  vacation. He rides in on a huge wave of auto enthusiasts, auto builders,   and aftermarket manufacturers _ tens of thousands strong _ who come  each year to the Specialty Equipment Market Association  convention. By  Royal Ford. 940 words  AUTOS-REVIEW (Undated) _ The Lexus IS 300 SportCross, a peppy hauler  of people and gear, is a vehicle designed to fill a niche within niches  in a world where SUVs, station wagons, and sport sedans are melding  before our eyes. By Royal Ford. 860 words.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e)  MUSIC-JUNOON _ Death threats and phone taps are hardly a concern for  most rock bands, but Junoon has dealt with these adversities for years.  Known as the ``U2 of Pakistan,'' Junoon imparts messages of peace and  tolerance in a country where rock music has been frowned upon and  ``where religious extremism and terror are in your face,'' says the  band's founder, Salman Ahmad. By Steve Morse. 680 words.  ARCHITECT-KHAN (Undated) -  Can architecture be a way of bridging  the gap between Western and Islamic cultures? For most of us, the need  to build that bridge is something we've only recently become aware of.  But someone who has long been trying is the Aga Khan. By Robert  Campbell. 910 words.  COMPUTERS (a)  COMPUTERS-COLUMN (Undated) _ In these perilous times, I'm glad the  FBI is hard at work on new technologies to outwit terrorists and  criminals. And while it's good to see corporate America rallying around  to help, there's such a thing as being too supportive. By Hiawatha Bray.  810 words.  FINANCIAL (f)  ONBUSINESS-COLUMN (Undated) _  If you came into this year counting  on the nation's economic forecasters to warn you about the coming  recession, you would be very disappointed. By Steven Syre and Charles  Stein. 800 words.  SPORTS (s)  SKI-OLYMPICS (Undated)  - When the US Alpine Ski Team clicks in for  action eight weeks from now in Utah, legitimate Olympic medal hopes will  be riding on two young skiers as familiar with Sugarloaf's Narrow Gauge  as most people are with walking through their living rooms: Kirsten  Clark and Bode Miller. By Tony Chamberlain. 900 words.  SKI-COLUMN (Undated) _ Buck up, ye the pent up, the frustrated.  Winter is coming. By Tony Chamberlain. 840 words. FEATURES  MOVIES-TRAVOLTA (Los Angeles) _ Another in the series ``Watching Movies With'': John Travolta sat quietly in a square, well-cushioned chair along the back wall of his home screening room. He had just finished watching ``Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' a glossy Warner Brothers bio-pic about the legendary George M. Cohan, a movie that's been dear to him since he was a little boy in New Jersey dreaming about a life on the stage. Travolta rubbed his eyes. Yes, he had been crying; there was no use denying it. He nodded sheepishly. The movie that had meant so much to him as a boy, he discovered, still had the power to reach into his heart. And now, in the wake of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, what had once seemed corny, flag-waving jingoism in the screen saga of the man who wrote ``You're a Grand Old Flag'' and ``Over There'' instead came across as almost eerily in touch with the current national mood. By Rick Lyman.  BROADWAY-REPLACEMENT (New York) _ The wig was loose. The dress was tight. The lift was botched. The turn was late. Well, that's what rehearsing is for, isn't it? Oops, no, sorry. That's the other show business. This was the one where time is money, where an actress and dancer of the caliber of Charlotte d'Amboise was supposed to get it right the first time. One full run-through with the cast _ the put-in, they call it _ was all d'Amboise got before she had to go out there and dance her heart out. In front of a real audience. Hundreds of people with high expectations and newly incurred credit card debt. As the replacement for Karen Ziemba in ``Contact,'' the Tony-winning musical, she was entitled to only one rehearsal with the entire ensemble of dancers and actors, around whom she would have to leap and pirouette eight times a week. Starting here, starting now. Occasionally, new blood can totally transform a show: look at what Reba McEntire did for ``Annie Get Your Gun.'' And frequently, a fresh face invigorates a tired cast that may have entered the zombie phase of its performance cycle. By Peter Marks.  IMPRESSIONIST-STILL-LIFE (Washington) _ There's absolutely nothing still about a good still-life painting. And because a high number of the 90 works in ``Impressionist Still Life'' at the Phillips Collection here are exceptionally good to outright great, a show that doesn't promise much on paper feels very active, very alive. By Holland Cotter.  MOVIES  ABCD-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``ABCD'': Krutin Patel, director; with Faran Tahir, Sheetal Sheth, Mahdur Jaffrey. Reviewed by Stephen Holden.  NECKLACE-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``The Affair of the Necklace'': Charles Shyer, director; with Hilary Swank, Simon Baker, Adrien Brody, Jonathan Pryce, Christopher Walken. Reviewed by A.O. Scott.  BEHIND-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Behind Enemy Lines'': John Moore, director; with Gene Hackman, Owen Wilson, David Keith, Gabriel Macht. Reviewed by Stephen Holden.  INDEPENDENT-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``The Independent'': Stephen Kessler, director; with Jerry Stiller, Janeane Garofalo, Max Perlich. Reviewed by Stephen Holden.  PORN-STAR-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Porn Star: The Legend of Ron Jeremy'': Ron Hyatt, director. Reviewed by Dave Kehr.  AT-THE-MOVIES (Hollywood) _ News of the silver screen. By Bernard Weinraub.  HOMEVIDEO (Undated) _ Short items on what's news in home video and short reviews of what's new in home video. By Peter M. Nichols.  OTHER ENTERTAINMENT  WRONG-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``The Wrong Man,'' by James Neff (Random House). Reviewed by Michiko Kakutani.  TV-GREEN-LIGHT-REVIEW (Undated) _ Sunday on HBO, ``Project Green Light.'' Reviewed by Caryn James.  TV-BRIANS-REVIEW (Undated) _ Sunday on ABC, ``Brian's Song.'' Reviewed by Ron Wertheimer.  THEATER-NOTES (Undated) _ News of The Great White Way. By Jesse McKinley.  ANTIQUES-COLUMN (New York) _ The Antiques Column. By Wendy Moonan. , they concluded,	 But at the start of the Bush administration, the intelligence agencies also agreed that Iraq had not in fact resumed its nuclear weapons program. , they reported,	 It turned out, they reported, that Iraq had for years used high-strength aluminum tubes to make combustion chambers for slim rockets fired from launcher pods. Back in 1996, inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency had even examined some of these tubes, also made of 7075-T6 aluminum, at a military complex, the Nasser metal fabrication plant in Baghdad, where the Iraqis acknowledged making rockets. According to the international agency, the rocket tubes, some 66,000 of them, were 900 millimeters in length, with a diameter of 81 millimeters and walls 3.3 millimeters thick. </P> 	nyt_eng_200410.gz
, they conceded,	 Joe and his WINPAC colleagues at the CIA were not persuaded. Yes, they conceded, the tubes could be used as rocket casings. But this made no sense, they argued in a new report, because Iraq wanted tubes made at tolerances that far exceed any known conventional weapons. In other words, Iraq was demanding a level of precision craftsmanship unnecessary for ordinary mass-produced rockets. </P> 	nyt_eng_200410.gz
, they noted,	 By year's end, Energy Department analysts published a classified report that even more firmly rejected the theory that the tubes could work as rotors in a 1950s Zippe centrifuge. These particular Zippe centrifuges, they noted, were especially ill suited for bomb making. They were a prototype designed for laboratory experiments, operating as single units. To produce enough enriched uranium to make just one bomb a year, Iraq would need up to 16,000 of them working in concert, a challenge for even the most sophisticated centrifuge plants. </P> 	nyt_eng_200410.gz
, they insist,	 Not so, agency officials said. In July 2002, they insist, they were the first intelligence agency to seek JAEIC's intervention. , they said,	 Intelligence analysts at the State Department waged a quiet battle against much of the proposed language on tubes. The agency says it has investigated Israeli accusations, and has not found evidence that its employees acted improperly. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20041003.0087 type=advis > <HEADLINE> ALSO MOVING TRAVEL WIRE; WITH GRAPHIC AIRPORT TREATS MAKE TIME FLY </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> DENVER </DATELINE> <TEXT> It's the epicenter of wait, the heart of the long sit, the crossroads of cooling one's heels.  As travelers in ever-greater numbers pack Denver International Airport, while security measures remain heightened, the sprawling white-tented compound on the prairie has become a grand stage for the practice of passing time. (July was the busiest month on record for DIA, logging a little more than 4 million passengers.)  People flop on the floor and listen to music through earphones, their eyes closed. They hunch over paperbacks, tap on keyboards, yap into cellphones, watch CNN and stare into some middle distance where they observe nothing but the fuzzy thoughts in their frazzled heads.  They stand in line and walk barefoot through metal-detecting doorways, and they stand some more while they get wanded. They arrive early to prepare for the odyssey through the security hive, and then they sit on molded-plastic seats for an hour or two.  If you're at DIA and you've got time (face it, you do), you've also got options.  First, you need to understand the logic of the place. There's the big terminal,with its two-story density of amenities, and there's three concourses, lined up and parallel to one another, like tines on a fork: A, B and C. Concourse B dwarfs the others. Concourse C is the smallest. Once you submit to the security gantlet, you're free to roam.  In the terminal: Start with a cappuccino from Brew Mountain ExpressO. With its unctuous cap of foam and espresso bitterness, Brew Mountain's cappuccino beat those from four other shops, all of which were milky and weak.  You should nibble on chocolate between sips of cappuccino, and the terminal houses the best of the two fancy chocolate shops at DIA. Both Stephany's Chocolates and the Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory maintain outposts, with Stephany's in the terminal and Rocky Mountain in Concourse B. We taste-tested truffles from both. Rocky Mountain's were a good deal larger -- like golf balls to Stephany's kumquats -- but lacking in nuance. Stephany's chocolate mousse truffle especially thrilled.  Enjoy your dark treats in the padded chairs on the east side of the terminal, facing a wall of windows overlooking the airport and surrounded by tall potted plants. It's relatively peaceful there. You'll hear a nearby fountain and bathe in the light.  But now you're too fired up on caffeine and sugar.  Head over to Pour La France Cafe, on the second floor of the terminal. Order a Baron Philippe de Rothschild viogner -- or one of the many other wines the restaurant sells by the glass -- or a Numero Uno Margarita, made with Jose Cuervo Reposado tequila, Grand Marnier and fresh-squeezed lime juice, or one of the great microbrews.  Try the escargot, redolent of anise and garlic. Slurp a cup of the chunky French onion soup with the cheese-draped crouton lurking in the broth. The roasted chicken's skin wasn't as crisp as it should have been, but herb-scented moisture infused the meat. A tangy richness spiked with smoky bacon described the excellent quiche Lorraine.  Pour La France also sells corn-syrup-free sodas made by Boylan's and small plastic bowls of fruit-and-nut-studded granola that make for one of the few healthy breakfast options in DIA.  Visit Yaz Jewelry and Gifts. Jewelry and assorted upscale knickknacks (vases carved from local aspen trees, knee-high sheep made by a Navajo sheepherding couple, Egyptian cats carved in Kenya out of soapstone) decorate every inch of the store, owned by Mahmood Rana, an erect, tie-wearing font of information about every artifact in his store. Interested in a coin from the Roman Republic, dated 107 B.C., encircled in gold and turned into a pendant? An antique mother-of-pearl gambling chip from Macao turned into a stick-of- gum-shaped pendant? Rana's got them.  Denver Realtor Emily Roet says she arrives early at the airport just to shop at Rana's store.  I'm the kind of person who never has the time to shop, she says. The only time I ever have nothing to do is when I'm in the airport. When I go to the airport and I have free time, I love to shop.  Roet also adores Colorado West, a store in Concourses A and B in which everything -- including clothes and jewelry -- is steeped in either American Indian or cowboy and cowgirl.  In the concourses: Here, you're best to visit the nearly half-mile-long Concourse B. Pour la France has another spot here, this one brick-walled and charming.  The concourse also sports a fantastic Mexican restaurant, Que Bueno, that serves up a variety of tequilas and Mexican beers, and some mean tacos. The chicken and beef in the tacos was tender, charred, perfumed with spice; the fish tacos flaky and full of citrus zing; the salsas rich and hot. Cilantro studded the rice, and the beans were fork-tender.  At Next Generation, a toy store, you can buy dolls of blond flight attendants in blue uniforms (representing different airlines), each with her own rolling suitcase. The dolls come in pink backpacks. For aeronautically inclined boys, go with the model jets.  You know your friends and family already are missing you. So find a Shibby kiosk in any of the concourses, pay $5 for 20 minutes of Web surfing, direct the machine to take a 30-second video of your smiling face, and ship it off in e-mails.  As for art, DIA showcases gigantic installations, paintings and sculpture in the terminal and on every concourse. Art in tall glass display cases lines a long walkway on the north end of the terminal connecting to Concourse A. The exhibit changes every season.  Your flight leaves in 30 minutes. You've just killed two pleasant hours. Who knew?  Bon voyage. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20041003.0088 type=advis > <HEADLINE> ALSO MOVING FEATURE WIRE; WITH GRAPHIC AIRPORT TREATS MAKE TIME FLY </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> DENVER </DATELINE> <TEXT> It's the epicenter of wait, the heart of the long sit, the crossroads of cooling one's heels.  As travelers in ever-greater numbers pack Denver International Airport, while security measures remain heightened, the sprawling white-tented compound on the prairie has become a grand stage for the practice of passing time. (July was the busiest month on record for DIA, logging a little more than 4 million passengers.)  People flop on the floor and listen to music through earphones, their eyes closed. They hunch over paperbacks, tap on keyboards, yap into cellphones, watch CNN and stare into some middle distance where they observe nothing but the fuzzy thoughts in their frazzled heads.  They stand in line and walk barefoot through metal-detecting doorways, and they stand some more while they get wanded. They arrive early to prepare for the odyssey through the security hive, and then they sit on molded-plastic seats for an hour or two.  If you're at DIA and you've got time (face it, you do), you've also got options.  First, you need to understand the logic of the place. There's the big terminal,with its two-story density of amenities, and there's three concourses, lined up and parallel to one another, like tines on a fork: A, B and C. Concourse B dwarfs the others. Concourse C is the smallest. Once you submit to the security gantlet, you're free to roam.  In the terminal: Start with a cappuccino from Brew Mountain ExpressO. With its unctuous cap of foam and espresso bitterness, Brew Mountain's cappuccino beat those from four other shops, all of which were milky and weak.  You should nibble on chocolate between sips of cappuccino, and the terminal houses the best of the two fancy chocolate shops at DIA. Both Stephany's Chocolates and the Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory maintain outposts, with Stephany's in the terminal and Rocky Mountain in Concourse B. We taste-tested truffles from both. Rocky Mountain's were a good deal larger -- like golf balls to Stephany's kumquats -- but lacking in nuance. Stephany's chocolate mousse truffle especially thrilled.  Enjoy your dark treats in the padded chairs on the east side of the terminal, facing a wall of windows overlooking the airport and surrounded by tall potted plants. It's relatively peaceful there. You'll hear a nearby fountain and bathe in the light.  But now you're too fired up on caffeine and sugar.  Head over to Pour La France Cafe, on the second floor of the terminal. Order a Baron Philippe de Rothschild viogner -- or one of the many other wines the restaurant sells by the glass -- or a Numero Uno Margarita, made with Jose Cuervo Reposado tequila, Grand Marnier and fresh-squeezed lime juice, or one of the great microbrews.  Try the escargot, redolent of anise and garlic. Slurp a cup of the chunky French onion soup with the cheese-draped crouton lurking in the broth. The roasted chicken's skin wasn't as crisp as it should have been, but herb-scented moisture infused the meat. A tangy richness spiked with smoky bacon described the excellent quiche Lorraine.  Pour La France also sells corn-syrup-free sodas made by Boylan's and small plastic bowls of fruit-and-nut-studded granola that make for one of the few healthy breakfast options in DIA.  Visit Yaz Jewelry and Gifts. Jewelry and assorted upscale knickknacks (vases carved from local aspen trees, knee-high sheep made by a Navajo sheepherding couple, Egyptian cats carved in Kenya out of soapstone) decorate every inch of the store, owned by Mahmood Rana, an erect, tie-wearing font of information about every artifact in his store. Interested in a coin from the Roman Republic, dated 107 B.C., encircled in gold and turned into a pendant? An antique mother-of-pearl gambling chip from Macao turned into a stick-of- gum-shaped pendant? Rana's got them.  Denver Realtor Emily Roet says she arrives early at the airport just to shop at Rana's store.  I'm the kind of person who never has the time to shop, she says. The only time I ever have nothing to do is when I'm in the airport. When I go to the airport and I have free time, I love to shop.  Roet also adores Colorado West, a store in Concourses A and B in which everything -- including clothes and jewelry -- is steeped in either American Indian or cowboy and cowgirl.  In the concourses: Here, you're best to visit the nearly half-mile-long Concourse B. Pour la France has another spot here, this one brick-walled and charming.  The concourse also sports a fantastic Mexican restaurant, Que Bueno, that serves up a variety of tequilas and Mexican beers, and some mean tacos. The chicken and beef in the tacos was tender, charred, perfumed with spice; the fish tacos flaky and full of citrus zing; the salsas rich and hot. Cilantro studded the rice, and the beans were fork-tender.  At Next Generation, a toy store, you can buy dolls of blond flight attendants in blue uniforms (representing different airlines), each with her own rolling suitcase. The dolls come in pink backpacks. For aeronautically inclined boys, go with the model jets.  You know your friends and family already are missing you. So find a Shibby kiosk in any of the concourses, pay $5 for 20 minutes of Web surfing, direct the machine to take a 30-second video of your smiling face, and ship it off in e-mails.  As for art, DIA showcases gigantic installations, paintings and sculpture in the terminal and on every concourse. Art in tall glass display cases lines a long walkway on the north end of the terminal connecting to Concourse A. The exhibit changes every season.  Your flight leaves in 30 minutes. You've just killed two pleasant hours. Who knew?  Bon voyage. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20041003.0089 type=story > <HEADLINE> TAKE 1,283 OF GOURMET'S WINNERS, ADD FOLKSINESS, HOLD GLITTER </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> NEW YORK </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200410.gz

It seemed almost predestined.  And as it turned, the Broncos' free safety was directly involved in two of the game's biggest plays.  I had a feeling I might play well, said Lynch, who played 11 seasons with the Bucs, five of them ending in the Pro Bowl. In the second half I was strugling with cramps ... when you let the adrenolin go early, sometimes you struggle with that.  But Lynch's biggest struggle came right after the game when many old friends congratulated him and tears came to his eyes.  Finally everything hit me. I anticipated that might come at some point, he said. Last night, to be honest, I didn't sleep a wink. I don't know if I was even that nervous before the Super Bowl.  That Super Bowl was about winning an NFL championship. Sunday's game was about the return of John Lynch.  I'm just glad I didn't walk into the wrong locker room when I came in, or walk out to the wrong sideline, said Lynch, who got a long standing ovation after his pre-game introduction.  A blunder by the 33-year-old Lynch enabled the Bucs to score their only touchdown and turned the momentum in Tampa Bay's favor.  Denver led, 10-0, early in the second quarter when Brad Johnson threw deep to Michael Clayton. The Bucs receiver fell down while making the catch at the Bronco 20-yard line, but got up before Lynch came over to touch him down. Lynch had a free shot at Clayton but merely tapped him, assuming he was down. Clayton got up and ran for a touchdown that got the Bucs back in the game.  Lynch was fined for a hit he delivered on a Kansas City player three weeks ago.  Ultimately, the responsibility is on me there and I have to tackle him, I guess, Lynch said. But there is a new league emphasis that if you hit them while they're lying down, you will be penalized 15 yards.  I asked the referee: 'Would you have given me a 15-yard penalty if I hit him when he was down?' He said yes. So from now on, I guess I'll just take the 15-yard penalty.  Lynch came back to make a big play for the Broncos late in the third quarter. The Bucs had tied it, 13-13, and faced third down with less than a yard to go at their 44. Mike Alsott got the call, but Lynch blitzed and nailed him for a two-yard loss, forcing the Bucs to punt.  That's one of my best friends in this world, Lynch said of Alsott. I've never had an opportunity to tackle him, but (defensive coordinator Larrry Coyle) made the call. Mike's a tough guy to bring down, and I know why people have been bouncing off him so many years.  For the Bucs on that play, there were too many people to block.  Lynch has seen that a few times before from the other side of the field. This time he enjoyed it more. , he said,	 Dr. Robert Wachter of the University of California at San Francisco believes that, overall, medicine has made a little bit of progress in making patients safer. But he argues that the improvement comes after decades in which mistakes soared as new technologies and treatments allowed doctors to do more for -- and to -- their patients. An intensive-care patient, he points out, is typically on numerous intravenous medications, any one of which is lethal if given incorrectly, while breathing is maintained on a respirator that could bring instant death if it malfunctions. , he says,	 Garton Ash, the Oxford historian who has gained a solid reputation as a wise and erudite commentator on European affairs over the years, takes a different approach from these other analysts. His view is that things are more complicated than the commonplace notion that the West has become divided between Europe and America. The West, he says, did not split neatly into a European and an American half, like a well-cracked walnut. We are not, he writes, two separate civilizations but two variants of the same set of values, most of whose long-term interests are common, coincident or, at the very least, compatible.' And most important, only by working together can the two zones of the old Cold War West capitalize on what Garton Ash describes as a historic chance, namely working in concert to go beyond the 'free world' of the old West and lay the foundations of a free world. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz

, he said,	 TREVI-MUSIC (Undated) -- The moment Gloria Trevi left prison, Luis Medina's problems began. Oh my God, I can't wait to see her. Is she going to sing? Trevi's scandals were astonishing: She'd landed on Mexico's Most Wanted list; hidden a dead infant which has never been found; eluded Interpol for more than a year; slipped in and out of at least three countries without detection; ignited a prison scandal in Brazil by, according to investigators, impregnating herself with a syringe smuggled from a Brazilian druglord as part of a plot to avoid extradition to Mexico; and allegedly helped mastermind a secret cult. So what's an award director to do? Even though Trevi was one of Mexico's most famous singers, she wasn't on the ballot. Her unexpected acquittal on Sept. 21 shocked even Trevi. , he sensed,	 ALEXANDER-BATTLE-SCENE (Undated) -- Last year, the Oxford University historian Robin Lane Fox, the author of a much-admired 1973 biography of Alexander the Great, found himself astride a horse, carrying a wooden lance, thundering through the desert dust with scores of mounted companions as Alexander's greatest conquest unfolded. The setting was an uninhabited stretch of Morocco -- far from the Persian village of Gaugamela in present-day Iraq, where the historic battle occurred in 331 B.C. And the messianic warrior Fox followed wasn't the 25-year-old Alexander but the actor Colin Farrell, who plays the lead in Oliver Stone's Alexander, which has its premiere on Nov. 24. Fox, after decades of researching often-incomplete texts about Alexander's time, was now empirically testing history. Yes, he sensed, you could charge with a lance without using stirrups. No, his body told him, you couldn't carry a shield in your other arm while riding. And what of the popular notion that Alexander guided his soldiers with battlefield commands? That, too, felt hollow in the noisy rattle of battle Historical films routinely reinterpret or simply trash history. Indeed, Stone is a pariah in some quarters for his conspiratorial assertions in J.F.K. and Nixon. But the filming of the Battle of Gaugamela appears to have been a more complex experience, one in which there was often no historical consensus, forcing Stone and his consultants to extrapolate their grand movie reality around an earnest synthesis of the authentic and the plausible, with at least a small dollop of the merely cool. By Bob Baker. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz

, she said,	 To put it into perspective, she said, imagine watching your children walk from one side of a busy freeway to the other, and all you can do is stand on the shoulder and watch. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, I think,	 When you look at the American elderly at age 75, many of them are confined. Confinement alone, I think, didn't do this. That's a big stretch, Plaut said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz
, I say,	 Whenever I see people at book signings with the 'Caroline' script, I say, 'You have to get the CD.'  says Kushner. I can't even talk about the lyrics without the music that goes with it. This is something that is half Jeanine's and half mine. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200411.gz"

(NYT60) NEWARK, OH -- Nov. 12, 2004 -- OHIO-TOWN-POLITICS-3 -- Julie Uible, seen in Newark, OH, on Nov. 11, 2004, said that although she had voted against the same-sex marriage amendment, her opinions about civil unions were not yet solidified. (J. Kevin Fitzsimons/The New York Times)  (NYT59) UNDATED -- Nov. 12, 2004 -- Adv. for Sun., Nov. 14 -- SLEEP-IN-THE-CITY -- Undated photos of a man sleeping in bed. Detroit is the worst toughest city for a good night's sleep, a survey finds, and Minneapolis is best according to a new study, told in the context of a nation where insomnia and lack of sleep has never been more epidemic. (Rahev Segev/The New York Times)  (NYT58) NEW YORK -- Nov. 12, 2004 -- ANGRY-ME-PRISON -- Jerry Ciauri, second from right, and Sean Johnson, with dreadlocks, speaking with actors after a performance of Twelve Angry Men at the American Airlines Theater in November. In 2002, 12 angry men incarcerated at New York's Sing Sing prison put on a performance of the play Twelve Angry Men at the prison. Nine of them have been released, and this week two of them -- one was convicted of trying to kill the head of the Columbo crime family in 1991, the other was a drug dealer -- went to see Twelve Angry Men on Broadway. They liked it fine, and freedom better. But it was their upstate performance, they say, that was truly special. Nine of us are out now, said Ciauri, the hitman, and none of us have gone back. That's a success story. (Edwine Seymour/The New York Times)  (NYT57) GRANVILLE, OH -- Nov. 12, 2004 -- OHIO-TOWN-POLITICS-2 -- Marj Creech and a lesbian minister in her Granville, OH, home, plays a hymn during Sunday service November 7, 2004. Granville, which occupies a four-square-mile patch of Central Ohio 34 miles outside of Columbus, is home to markedly divergent social ideologies that have, until recently, lived in parallel seclusion. For years, the rural town of 3,100 has embraced both a conservative evangelical community and an impassioned liberal one that includes a small, quiet sub-culture of left-leaning gay Christians. Until last week they quietly coexisted. (J. A 360 pound Maytag refrigerator was mounted on the roof of the vehicle to represent a grossly overload and unbalanced condition. Top auto experts, however, say there are two important must-have safety features that every buyer should be looking at: side airbags specifically designed to protect a person's head, and electronic stability control, which helps drivers regain control of a swerving vehicle by automatically applying brake pressure. Esopus exists between book and art, and sells no ads, only itself -- and then only to finance the next issue. Batista has emerged as one of the most effective advocates of the indigenous cause in Brazil, the bane of ranchers, miners and loggers who want to encroach on Indian land. But unlike the tribal chiefs and shamans with whom she works closely, her weapon is the white man's law, which she fights to have obeyed by all, including those who make it. , he said,	 TREVI-MUSIC (Undated) -- The moment Gloria Trevi left prison, Luis Medina's problems began. Only days from staging the Latin People's Choice Awards ( El Premio de la Gente) in Los Angeles, he said, Hundreds of people were calling and asking 'Is Gloria going to be there? Oh my God, I can't wait to see her. Is she going to sing? Trevi's scandals were astonishing: She'd landed on Mexico's Most Wanted list; hidden a dead infant which has never been found; eluded Interpol for more than a year; slipped in and out of at least three countries without detection; ignited a prison scandal in Brazil by, according to investigators, impregnating herself with a syringe smuggled from a Brazilian druglord as part of a plot to avoid extradition to Mexico; and allegedly helped mastermind a secret cult. So what's an award director to do? Even though Trevi was one of Mexico's most famous singers, she wasn't on the ballot. Her unexpected acquittal on Sept. 21 shocked even Trevi. Now that she was out, how could she get an award without any votes? Simple -- Medina made one up. He announced that Gloria would receive the first ever Soul of the People Award. , he sensed,	 ALEXANDER-BATTLE-SCENE (Undated) -- Last year, the Oxford University historian Robin Lane Fox, the author of a much-admired 1973 biography of Alexander the Great, found himself astride a horse, carrying a wooden lance, thundering through the desert dust with scores of mounted companions as Alexander's greatest conquest unfolded. The setting was an uninhabited stretch of Morocco -- far from the Persian village of Gaugamela in present-day Iraq, where the historic battle occurred in 331 B.C. And the messianic warrior Fox followed wasn't the 25-year-old Alexander but the actor Colin Farrell, who plays the lead in Oliver Stone's Alexander, which has its premiere on Nov. 24. Fox, after decades of researching often-incomplete texts about Alexander's time, was now empirically testing history. Yes, he sensed, you could charge with a lance without using stirrups. No, his body told him, you couldn't carry a shield in your other arm while riding. And what of the popular notion that Alexander guided his soldiers with battlefield commands? That, too, felt hollow in the noisy rattle of battle Historical films routinely reinterpret or simply trash history. Indeed, Stone is a pariah in some quarters for his conspiratorial assertions in J.F.K. and Nixon. But the filming of the Battle of Gaugamela appears to have been a more complex experience, one in which there was often no historical consensus, forcing Stone and his consultants to extrapolate their grand movie reality around an earnest synthesis of the authentic and the plausible, with at least a small dollop of the merely cool. By Bob Baker. </P> 	nyt_eng_200411.gz

, I noticed,	 The show peruses a scene whose wide stylistic range, persistent teenage infatuations and overall dexterousness are firmly entrenched characteristics of the marketplace. Last time, there were hardly enough Chelsea galleries to go around. Now there aren't enough artists. SCI-CANCER-GENETICS (Undated) -- To their own amazement, scientists are now finding that untangling the genetics of cancer is, if not within reach, within possibility. In fact, they say, what looked like an impenetrable shield protecting cancer cells turns out to be little more than a flimsy cloak. And those seemingly impervious cancer cells are very much poised to die. Preventing Cancer: The Promise of Genetics, part of a series.  SCI-EINSTEIN-QUANTUM-PHYSICS (Undated) -- Albert Einstein, in 1935, dreamed up a trick of synchronized atoms -- spooky action at a distance, as he called it -- as an example of the absurdity of quantum mechanics. Today that paper, written when Einstein was a relatively ancient 56 years old, is the most cited of Einstein's papers. But far from demolishing quantum theory, that paper wound up as the cornerstone for the new field of quantum information. Nary a week goes by that does not bring news of another feat of quantum trickery once only dreamed of in thought experiments: particles (or at least all their properties) being teleported across the room in a microscopic version of Star Trek beaming; electrical cat currents that circle a loop in opposite directions at the same time. At the University of California, Santa Barbara, researchers are planning an experiment in which a small mirror will be in two different places at once. By Dennis Overbye.  SCI-PSYCHOTHERAPY (Anaheim, Calif.) -- In mid-December, 9,000 psychologists, social workers and students, along with many of the world's most celebrated living therapists, attended a landmark meeting to consider the state of psychotherapy, its current challenges and its future. Although the participants agreed it was a time for bold action, psychotherapists are deeply divided over whether that action should be guided by the cool logic of science or a spirit of humanistic activism. The answer will determine not only what psychotherapy means, many experts said, but its place in the 21st century. By Benedict Carey.  SCI-GLOBAL-WARMING (Undated) -- Earth scientists with the longest frames of reference, particularly those whose specialties begin with the prefix paleo, often seem to be the least agitated about human-caused global warming. This has been true even in 2005, a year that saw the biggest summer retreat of Arctic sea ice ever measured, a new sign that warming seas are rising at an accelerating pace and global temperatures continuing a sharp climb that began around 1990 and appears unmatched in 2,000 years. But these backward-looking experts have seen it all before. In fact, the planet has nothing to worry about from global warming. A hot, steamy earth would be fine for most forms of life. Earth and its biological veneer are far more resilient than human societies, particularly those still mired in poverty or pushed to the margins of the livable. Only we humans have to be concerned, and species like polar bears that, like the poorest people, are pushed to an edge -- in the bear's case the tenuous ecosystem built around coastal sea ice. An essay by Andrew C. Revkin.  SCI-Q&amp;A (Undated) -- A science question answered: I never used to hear about peanut allergies, especially fatal ones. Is the number increasing? By C. Claiborne Ray.  SCI-NUKE-WASTE (Undated) -- Decades ago, when the future of nuclear power seemed boundless, scientists and engineers thought they had a ready solution to the problem of what to do with all the radioactive waste given off by power plants: reprocess it and put it back to work, either in those same plants or as material for atomic bombs. The idea never got off the ground in this country, in part because it proved too expensive. But now, as waste piles up at reactors around the country and other disposal options are vanishing, Congress is sending the Energy Department back to explore reprocessing once again. By Matthew L. Wald.  SCI-EVOLUTION-HUMOR (Undated) -- On Web sites, with games and in silly songs, scientists are advancing the idea that creationism and its doctrinal relative, intelligent design, are not just misguided -- they are laughably misguided. So with a majority of the public still in denial over evolution, scientists are turning to humor. Commentary, by Cornelia Dean.  SCI-WATCH (Undated) -- News and notes on science: Planting trees to absorb greenhouse gases may create more problems that it solves, researchers say. By Henry Fountain.  With  SCI-NAPOLEON-LICE (Undated) -- The 1812 invasion of Russia by Napoleon's Grand Army ranks as one of the worst military fiascoes of all time. Of half a million soldiers sent toward Moscow, only about 5 percent made it back. Now, researchers say that lice their disease-causing bacteria were part of the problem. A short, by Henry Fountain.  SCI-BIRTHING-BABIES (Undated) -- Reflecting on a holiday season as a medical student in 1955 when the babies would not stop coming, an aging physician reflects on the arrogance that at comes with helping to bring life into the world, then disappears with real responsibility. By Larry Zaroff.  SCI-DRUG-ABUSE (Undated) -- Howard Markel, M.D,. a doctor and drug counselor, writes of a new trend in drug abuse among juveniles: controlled prescription drugs, including potent opiate painkillers, tranquillizers and stimulants used to treat attention deficit disorders.  SCI-COLONOSCOPY-RISK (Undated) -- No one disputes that colonoscopies save lives. But recent research has prompted concern that in rare instances certain popular bowel-cleansing preparations that patients gulp down the day before a procedure can severely damage the kidneys. By Deborah Franklin.  SCI-REALLY (Undated) -- The claim: Holidays set off depression. The facts: .... By Anahad O'Connor.  SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) -- News and notes on health and medicine. By Nicholas Bakalar:  -- Depression: According to a large-scale study in Sweden, people who have been diagnosed with depression, especially younger patients between 25 and 50 years of age, are at increased risk of developing heart disease.  -- Pregnancy: The longer it takes to get pregnant, the more likely the result will be a boy.  -- Chocolate: Dark chocolate may stave off artery hardening in smokers, according to a small study.  -- Risk: Men with erectile dysfunction have a higher risk of heart attack, stroke and angina according to a new study.  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) -- The Personal Health column: New noninvasive tests give pregnant women a much better assessment of their risk of bearing a child with Down syndrome. By Jane E. Brody.  Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204. Unauthorized use of budgets and advisories constitutes a violation of our contract terms. All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051226.0040 type=advis > <HEADLINE> SPORTS-NYT-BUDGET </HEADLINE> <TEXT> Attn Sports Editors:  Sports stories from The New York Times News Service for Tuesday, Dec. 27.  FBN-RHODEN-COLUMN (Undated) -- Sports of The Times column on second-year quarterback Eli Manning, who is having a rocky second season with the Giants, despite the fact they are now a playoff team. Maybe it's time to give Manning a break, just in time for the January postseason. By William C. Rhoden.  OLY-SNOWBOARDING (Breckenridge, Colo.) -- Half-pipe snowboarding is the rare professional sport in which athletes perform to popular music and public address announcers narrate moves as they are being made. While competitors careen down the ramp, an on-site deejay spins hip-hop beats and an excitable announcer shouts the names of every different trick - Crippler! Stale Fish! Melon Poke! But there is one trick that needs no goofy name or hyperactive introduction. When the announcer relays it, his voice tends to drop by a decibel. Ten-eighty is all he needs to say. The 1080 is currently the most powerful move in snowboarding, a 1,080-degree spin that separates Olympic contenders from Olympic wannabes. Anybody who can make the requisite three revolutions in mid-air could wind up on the podium in Turin, Italy. Anybody who can't is probably going to need some more lift. By Lee Jenkins.  FBN-JETS-PATRIOTS (East Rutherford, N.J. -- New England Patriots at New YorkJets, 9 p.m. An essentially meaningless game for the Patriots and Jets, with one team having clinched the AFC East division and the other hopelessly out of contention. But the game is noteworthy for two reasons: it is ABC's last Monday night broadcast after a 35-year run and it is, presumably, Vinny Testaverde's last game in the NFL. By Karen Crouse.  With  TV-MONDAY-NIGHT-FOOTBALL (East Rutherford, N.J.) -- An On TV Sports column on ABC's final Monday-night broadcast. By Richard Sandomir.  FBC-RUTGERS (Scottsdale, Ariz.) -- After nearly 30 years without a bowl-game appearance, Rutgers is enjoying itself as it gets ready to play Arizona State in Tuesday's Insight Bowl in Phoenix.  FBC-CAPSULES (Undated) -- Capsule comparisons for Tuesday's two college football bowl games. By Fred Bierman.  BKN-HEAT (Miami) -- An hour after the Miami Heat's narrow victory over the visiting Los Angeles Lakers on Sunday night, when the special strobe lights and trimmings had been packed away for another year, Pat Riley looked as tired as he said he was. Shaquille O'Neal spoke even softer than usual. The Hall of Fame coach and the most dominant center in the league were each completely worn down. Riley by his 48-minute aerobic workout, a portion of his sweat forming from arguing at the referees, and O'Neal by the Lakers' centers Chris Mihm and Kwame Brown. By Liz Robbins.  For information and repeats call the News Service at (888) 346-9867 or (212) 556-1927. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051226.0041 type=advis > <HEADLINE> NYT-BUDGET </HEADLINE> <TEXT> FOR TUESDAY AMs  Here are today's top news stories from The New York Times News Service for AMs of Tuesday, Dec. 27.  For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  INTERNATIONAL (i code)  IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Developments in the worst day of violence since the Dec. 15 election, with at least 20 people dead in bombings and shootings around the country. Also, voting tallies among members of the Iraqi security forces show almost exclusive support for Shiite and Kurdish candidates, confirming the virtual absence of Sunnis in their ranks. By Richard A. Oppel Jr.  MIDEAST (Jerusalem) -- Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has a small hole in his heart that apparently contributed to his mild stroke last week, and he will undergo a catheterization procedure within three weeks to repair the problem, his doctors said today. Sharon, 77, suffered the stroke Dec. 18. Doctors said there was no permanent damage, and Sharon has returned to work. The prime minister's health problems have arisen as he seeks a third term in national elections that will take place on March 28. Opinion polls show his new centrist party, Kadima, remains heavily favored, despite his ailments. By Greg Myre.  RUSSIA-GAS (Moscow) -- The peak of the Russian holiday shopping was disrupted for a St. Petersburg retail chain Monday when two of its stores were struck by devices that emitted foul-smelling gas. At least 77 people were sickened by the odor, though none seriously, the authorities said. The police said the gas appeared to be a form of mercaptan, a group of malodorous compounds, often with an intense sulfuric smell, that includes a form commonly added to odorless natural gas to make fuel leaks detectable. The gas, while capable of producing an almost unbearable stink, is largely harmless, they said. The authorities ruled out terrorism. Instead, they attributed the attacks to the rough edges of Russian capitalism and gangsterism, saying the most likely motive was an effort to hurt the chain's sales on one of the most important shopping days of the year. By C.J. Chivers.  AUSTRIA-SCHWARZENEGGER (Dateline TK) -- Officials in Arnold Schwarzenegger's hometown of Graz, Austria, quietly remove his name from a soccer stadium overnight, complying with the California governor's demand in a bitter dispute over his death penalty stance. By Richard Bernstein.  JAPAN-HEIR (Tokyo) -- Faced with the harsh reality that neither of the current Japanese emperor's two sons is likely to produce a male heir, a government panel recommended recently that the American-imposed Imperial Household Law of 1947 be revised to allow a female line to hold the throne. The possibility has ignited a furious debate over the most delicate of subjects -- the imperial system and its significance to Japan -- and over topics as varied as the status of Japanese women, the merits of the concubine system and the purity of the imperial Y chromosome. By Norimitsu Onishi.  FINANCIAL (f code)  CHRISTMAS-RETURNS (Undated) -- The day after Christmas was once return day, with long lines at the counter bringing back the pink bunny slippers that you got from Aunt May. But tougher return rules and gift cards have changed that. Today, according to an industry survey, 14 percent of shoppers have something to return; five years ago, it was 33 percent and 10 years ago, it was 38 percent. (Byline TK)  With  HOLIDAY-SHOPPING(Undated) -- Results of the holiday shopping season. By Michael Barbaro.  MICH-ECON (Detroit) -- The state of Michigan is taking it on the chin as GM and Ford disintegrate. It ranks dead last on the University of Michigan's listing of states with economic momentum; it has the third-worst unemployment rate in the country; it is 49th in personal income growth; and if you want to buy a big, fancy executive house in the Detroit suburbs right now you can pretty much name your price. That's the good news. The bad news is that the state is far from bottoming out, with job cuts at GM, Ford and bankrupt Delphi still to come. No wonder that the state's governor, Jennifer Granholm, is looking everywhere she can for jobs -- even to Toyota, who she is trying to lure to the state to build an engine plant. By Micheline Maynard.  PENTAGON-WEAPONS (Undated) -- A look at the Pentagon's new policies stressing fewer but more flexible and precise weapons and how defense contractors are reacting. By Leslie Wayne.  GAZPROM (Moscow) -- Last winter, the Kremlin-backed candidate in Ukraine's contested presidential election lost to Viktor A. Yushchenko, the pro-Western leader of the Orange Revolution. This winter, Russia is demanding a five-fold increase in the price of gas supplied to Ukraine, a change widely seen as payback for Moscow's embarrassment a year ago. At the center of this geopolitical game is Gazprom, Russia's natural gas monopoly, the country's largest company, producer of one-third of the world's natural gas, and a corporation aspiring to join the ranks of energy majors such as Exxon Mobile and BP, with the scope and bulk to operate worldwide. Still, the conflict with Ukraine - putting Gazprom in opposition to a pro-Western government in Eastern Europe -- could not have come at a better time for the company. By Andrew E. Kramer.  EU-CARTELS (Paris) -- Across Europe, formerly docile cartel authorities are cracking down on collusion in economically weighty sectors like telecommunications, construction and banking. The drive includes tougher investigations at both the national level and Europewide as well as fines that are nearing 1 billion euros. By James Kanter.  ESTONIA-PORT (Sillamae, Estonia) -- In the early 1960s, the Kremlin ordered the Soviet military to blow up the port of Sillamae to prevent enemy ships from infiltrating this sleepy industrial town of 18,500 where uranium was enriched to build nuclear bombs during the Cold War. Now, Tiit Vahi, a former Estonian prime minister and a leader of the country's revolution against Soviet rule, wants to lure the ships back. His aim is no less than transforming a place once nicknamed Uranium Lake into a bustling commercial port that will allow new EU member Estonia to serve as a bridge between east and west and shake up European trade. By Dan Bilefsky.  Itineraries (aka Business Travel)  BIZ-TRAVEL-OUTLOOK (Undaetd) -- A look at the year ahead -- and how much more unpleasant business travel is going to become. By Chritsopher Elliott.  BIZ-TRAVEL-ROAD (Undated) -- The weekly Business Travel column: A look at what to expect at the checkpoint next year, including more registered-travel options, and more random pat-downs. By Joe Sharkey.  COMMENTARY (k code)  No staff-written Op-Ed columns. Both John Tierney and Nicholas D. Kristof are on vacation. CULTURE AND ENTERTAINMENT (e code)  RECORDING-INDUSTRY (Los Angeles) -- Even as the recording industry staggers through another year of declining sales over all, there are new signs that a democratization of music made possible by the Internet is shifting the industry's balance of power. Exploiting online message boards, music blogs and social networks, independent music companies are making big advances at the expense of the four global music conglomerates, whose established business model of blockbuster hits promoted through radio airplay now looks increasingly outdated. By Jeff Leeds.  MOORE-DANCE (New York) -- Profile of Rachel Moore, concentrating on what she has done to turn American Ballet Theater around financially and at the box office. By Roslyn Sulcas.  AMAZON-BLOGS (Undated) -- Amazon has recruited authors to blog for its site, greeting readers who click on their books and offering to answer questions for book groups. Among those who've signed up for Amazon Connect, as the program is known, are Anita Diamant (author of the best-selling Red Tent) and Jodi Picoult. By Edward Wyatt.  LAZY-SUNDAY-RAP (New York) -- On the Lazy-Sunday rap by Saturday Night Live performers Andy Samberg and Chris Parnell that wowed viewers last week and has become a phenomenon on the web. By Dave Itzkoff.  DVD-RELEASES (Undated) -- The weekly DVD column. By Dave Kehr.  SASSOON-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) -- Charles McGrath reviews Siegfried Sassoon: A Life by Max Egremont (Farrar, Straus, Giroux). FOREIGN  With story BC-INDONESIA-GOLD-NYT  The closest most people will ever get to remote Papua, or the operations of Freeport-McMoRan in Indonesia, is a computer tour using Google Earth to swoop down over the rain forests and glacier-capped mountains where the American company mines the world's largest gold reserve.  Sometime over the Christmas holidays, the authorities of Graz, a classically pretty town in Austria, took down the sign that for the past seven years has identified the local 15,000 seat sports arena as the Arnold Schwarzenegger Stadium, and as they did so, a rare combination of local hero worship, European indignation at the death penalty, and provincial Austrian politics came to a climax. When Schwarzenegger, now governor of California, declined to commute the death penalty of Stanley Tookie Williams, the former Los Angeles gang leader who was executed in California two weeks ago, the reaction in Graz, where the death penalty is seen as a medieval atrocity, was swift and angry.  We plan BESTSELLERS--Weekly 0101 -- Various files of Besteller Lists  To their own amazement, scientists are now finding that untangling the genetics of cancer is, if not within reach, within possibility. In fact, they say, what looked like an impenetrable shield protecting cancer cells turns out to be little more than a flimsy cloak. And those seemingly impervious cancer cells are very much poised to die.  Decades ago, when the future of nuclear power seemed boundless, scientists and engineers thought they had a ready solution to the problem of what to do with all the radioactive waste given off by power plants: reprocess it and put it back to work, either in those same plants or as material for atomic bombs. The idea never got off the ground in this country, in part because it proved too expensive. But now, as waste piles up at reactors around the country and other disposal options are vanishing, Congress is sending the Energy Department back to explore reprocessing once again. MINN-RECRUIT (Duluth, Minn.) -- As those thinking of becoming soldiers arrive on the slushy doorstep of the Army recruiting station here, they cannot miss the message posted in bold black letters on the storefront right next door. Remember the Fallen Heroes, the sign reads, and then it ticks off numbers -- the number of American troops killed in Iraq, the number wounded, the number of days gone by since this war began. The sign, put up by a former soldier, has stirred intense, though always polite, debate in this city along the edge of Lake Superior. In a way, many of the nation's complicated, vast arguments about war are playing out on a single block here, around a simple piece of wood. In this Northeastern Minnesota Army station, the seven military recruiters, six of whom have themselves served in Iraq, want the sign taken away. But Scott Cameron, a local man who was wounded during the Vietnam War, says his sign should remain. A journal by Monica Davey.  With photo.  NEW-ORLEANS-SUICIDES (New Orleans) -- Mental health professionals say this city appears to be experiencing a sharp increase in suicides in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, and interviews and statistics suggest that the rate has shot up to several times the national and local averages. By Adam Nossiter.  With photo.  TEXAS-CONSERVE (Liberty Hill, Texas) -- Young cedar trees in the Texas hill country are obstructive, brambly knots of vegetation. Older ones guzzle scarce moisture. When they are really mature, the golden-cheeked warbler, a songbird in danger of extinction, sometimes move in. Then in the early 1990s, the Interior Department set out to conserve cedar by buying -- or condemning -- cedar-covered land to protect the warbler. There were protests on the capitol steps in Austin. The effort stalled. More than decade later, in a cultural and political turnabout, people like Kerry Russell, a lawyer, rancher and lifelong resident of the area, have largely bought into a conservation program called Safe Harbor that combines federal and state incentives with flexibility for landowners, who can participate by committing land to conservation purposes forever, or for as little as 10 years. By Felicity Barringer.  With photo.  (Editors: Budgets and advisories are internal documents not for publication or redistribution outside of client news organizations. Unauthorized use of budgets and advisories constitutes a violation of our contract terms. All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20051226.0060 type=advis > <HEADLINE> GRAPHICS-UPDATE-NYT </HEADLINE> <TEXT> Here are the New York Times News Service Macintosh graphics scheduled for AMs of Tuesday, Dec. 27, 2005. FOREIGN  With story BC-INDONESIA-GOLD-NYT  The closest most people will ever get to remote Papua, or the operations of Freeport-McMoRan in Indonesia, is a computer tour using Google Earth to swoop down over the rain forests and glacier-capped mountains where the American company mines the world's largest gold reserve.  Sometime over the Christmas holidays, the authorities of Graz, a classically pretty town in Austria, took down the sign that for the past seven years has identified the local 15,000 seat sports arena as the Arnold Schwarzenegger Stadium, and as they did so, a rare combination of local hero worship, European indignation at the death penalty, and provincial Austrian politics came to a climax. When Schwarzenegger, now governor of California, declined to commute the death penalty of Stanley Tookie Williams, the former Los Angeles gang leader who was executed in California two weeks ago, the reaction in Graz, where the death penalty is seen as a medieval atrocity, was swift and angry.  Ghana, once the way station for millions of Africans who were enslaved on plantations in the United States, Latin America and the Caribbean, has embarked on a new campaign to entice descendants of the slaves to come back.  Cameron Parish in Louisiana, where generations of Cajuns have hunted ducks and pulled up redfish, lost 400 people to Hurricane Audrey in 1957. Last fall, when Hurricane Rita destroyed thousands of structures and flattened the coastline, some state officials had enough. Now Louisiana planners are proposing an idea that would have been unimaginable here a few months ago: moving an entire string of seaside towns and villages -- and the thousands of long-time residents who live in them -- 15 or 20 miles inland to higher and presumably safer ground. In fact, they say, what looked like an impenetrable shield protecting cancer cells turns out to be little more than a flimsy cloak. And those seemingly impervious cancer cells are very much poised to die. The idea never got off the ground in this country, in part because it proved too expensive. But now, as waste piles up at reactors around the country and other disposal options are vanishing, Congress is sending the Energy Department back to explore reprocessing once again. It ranks dead last on the University of Michigan's listing of states with economic momentum; it has the third-worst unemployment rate in the country; it is 49th in personal income growth; and if you want to buy a big, fancy executive house in the Detroit suburbs right now you can pretty much name your price. That's the good news. The bad news is that the state is far from bottoming out, with job cuts at G.M., Ford and bankrupt Delphi still to come.  Half-pipe snowboarding is the rare professional sport in which athletes perform to popular music and public address announcers narrate moves as they are being made. While competitors careen down the ramp, an on-site deejay spins hip-hop beats and an excitable announcer shouts the names of every different trick -- Crippler! Stale Fish! Melon Poke! The titles can sound like they came out of comic books. , he said,	 As for aerospace, he said the Pentagon would be looking for aircraft with longer ranges, and, therefore, does not need ships or nearby bases for them to land. , he noted,	 Those who speak of the potential benefits of warming, he noted, forget that a thawing, greening Arctic, for example, will not suddenly transform from spongy tundra to wheat-friendly farmland. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz
, he said,	 -- Lots more technology. Just as we have invested in our people to help reduce the risk that explosives will be taken aboard a plane, we are also investing in technology for this purpose, Edmund S. Hawley, the head of the security agency, said recently. By late next fall, he said, more than 350 trace-portal machines, which emit puffs of air to detect explosives on people, will be in use at airports. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz

The night supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Mitch Keller; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: mikell@nytimes.com. The late supervisor is Ray Krueger; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: krueger@nytimes.com.  TOP  Lede story (1-col. hed):  IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- Voting results released on Monday from the recent parliamentary election suggest that in contrast to the remarkable surge in Sunni Arab participation in the political process, the Sunnis still have comparatively little representation in the Iraqi security forces. The voting results are a sign of how complete the reversal of fortunes has been for the Sunnis, who ran the security forces under Saddam Hussein. By Richard A. Oppel Jr.  (Scheduled to move by 9:30 p.m. ET in i news file.)  Top left:  5-col. stand-alone photo on the 1-year anniversary of the Indonesian tsunami.  FOLD  STORMS-RELOCATE (Grand Chenier, La.) -- Cameron Parish, where generations of Cajuns have hunted ducks and pulled up redfish, lost 400 people to Hurricane Audrey in 1957. This fall, when Hurricane Rita destroyed thousands of structures and flattened the coastline, some state officials had had enough. Now Louisiana planners are proposing an idea that would have been unimaginable here a few months ago: moving an entire string of seaside towns and villages -- and the thousands of longtime residents who live in them -- 15 or 20 miles inland to higher and presumably safer ground. By Jere Longman.  With photos NYT 18-21.  (Story has moved in a news file.)  INDONESIA-GOLD (Jakarta, Indonesia) -- A look at the relationship between Indonesia's military and FreePort McMoran, the American company that mines the world's biggest gold reserve in Indonesia. By Jane Perlez and Raymond Bonner.  With map.  (Eds: This 7,000-word story is scheduled to move by 10 p.m. ET in i news file. An abridged version will also move.)  BOTTOM  GHANA-SLAVES (Cape Coast, Ghana) -- Ghana, once the way station for millions of Africans who were enslaved on plantations in the United States, Latin America and the Caribbean, has embarked on a new campaign to entice descendants of the slaves to come back. Taking Israel as its model, Ghana hopes to persuade the descendants of African slaves to think of Africa as their homeland, to visit Ghana, invest in it, send their children to be educated there and even retire there. By Lydia Polgreen.  SCI-CANCER-GENETICS (Undated) -- To their own amazement, scientists are now finding that untangling the genetics of cancer is, if not within reach, within possibility. In fact, they say, what looked like an impenetrable shield protecting cancer cells turns out to be little more than a flimsy cloak. And those seemingly impervious cancer cells are very much poised to die. By Gina Kolata.  (With photo and graphic.)  Preventing Cancer: The Promise of Genetics, part of a series.  (Story has moved in a news file.)  CHRISTMAS-RETURNS (Undated) -- The day after Christmas was once return day, with long lines at the counter as people brought back the pink bunny slippers they got from Aunt May. But tougher return rules and gift cards have changed that. Today, according to an industry survey, only 14 percent of shoppers have something to return; five years ago, it was 33 percent, and 10 years ago it was 38 percent. By Melanie Warner.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in f news file.)  HOLIDAY-SHOPPING (Undated) -- Results of the holiday shopping season. By Michael Barbaro.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in f news file.)  AUSTRIA-SCHWARZENEGGER (Berlin) -- For years, the quaint Austrian town of Graz trumpeted its special relationship with its outsize native son, Arnold Schwarzenegger. Most conspicuously, the local sports stadium was named after him. But early on Monday, under cover of darkness, Schwarzenegger's name was removed from the arena in a sort of uncontested divorce between Schwarzenegger and the town council, which had been horrified that Schwarzenegger rejected pleas to spare the life of Stanley Tookie Williams, who was executed two weeks ago. By Richard Bernstein.  (Story has moved in i news file.)  RECORDING-INDUSTRY (Los Angeles) -- Even as the recording industry staggers through another year of declining sales overall, there are new signs that a democratization of music made possible by the Internet is shifting the industry's balance of power. Exploiting online message boards, music blogs and social networks, independent music companies are making big advances at the expense of the four global music conglomerates, whose established business model of blockbuster hits promoted through radio airplay now looks increasingly outdated. By Jeff Leeds.  (Story has moved in e news file.)  NJ-POLICE-ACCIDENT (Jersey City, N.J.) - The fog was thick, and icy raindrops pelted their windshield. As Officers Shawn Carson and Robert Nguygen headed back to Jersey City, they had no idea that the road underneath them was about to run out. A tugboat had slipped into the harbor and the Lincioln Highway Bridge, an old-fashioned elevator bridge over the Hackensack River, had been raised. By Jeffrey Gettleman. , he argues,	 Elsewhere Gaddis has endorsed the writing of a new Cold War history -- one in which ideas, ideologies and morality are going to be central, rather than nuclear strategy and military brinkmanship. From the outset, he argues, the United States and the Soviet Union saw the Cold War not simply as a struggle for military superiority. The world would observe, and judge, two competing and contrasting social systems. For Gaddis, innumerable private perceptions and moral decisions did as much to dissolve the Cold War consensus as international treaties or macroecomonic trends. Characteristically, he locates the beginning of the end for Soviet communism with the dramatic moment when Pope John Paul II arrived at Warsaw airport on June 2, 1979, and kissed the ground. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz

, it seems,	 Auster stops just short of sentimentality. If The Brooklyn Follies has a weakness, it's one familiar to longtime readers: Because Auster is such a careful craftsman, almost everything happens for a reason. If a doctor gets tapped for emergency surgery at the moment he's supposed to pick up his mother at the airport, for example, you know mama is toast. It is giving away little to reveal that the book ends 46 minutes before the first plane crashed into the North Tower on Sept. 11, 2001. , he demonstrated,	 One of his best-known ideas is precommitment. One party in a conflict, he demonstrated, can often strengthen its strategic position by cutting off some of its options to make its threats more credible. An army that burns its bridges, making retreat impossible, is a classic military example. Others involve strong diplomatic commitments. By passing a law saying the United States will defend Taiwan if it is attacked, for example, Congress gives future administrations less flexibility in dealing with a crisis, but the threat makes an attack less likely. In the early 1980s, Schelling applied similar analysis to individuals' internal struggles, seeking to develop what he called strategic egonomics, consciously coping with one's own behavior, especially one's conscious behavior. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz

, she says,	 On July 30, 1960, Larsen (The White) sat in a taxi outside an Iowa convent and smoked one last cigarette before going inside to begin the process of becoming a nun. She was 19. She and other postulants were welcomed, then assigned beds, places at the table, seats in chapel. It seemed, she says, like summer camp. Five years later, she decided not to take her final vows, but her time in the convent had transformed her into a woman who was strong enough to leave it. This lovely and affectionate memoir reflects the allure of religious life in an era when girls read Kathryn Hulme's novel The Nun's Story and saw themselves in it. Writing in short sections with headings (Black Becomes Us, Custody of the Eyes, A Grapefruit Incident), Larsen creates a vivid picture of those years, from the clothes she wore to her longing for cigarettes (she gave the last of hers to the cabbie) to the comforting presence of her fellow postulants. , he said,	 Five-month-old Noor al Zahra of Iraq may leave the hospital today after doctors drained fluid from around her brain on Friday. Dr. Roger Hudgins, chief nuerosurgeon at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, inserted a flexible tube, or shunt, to drain fluid from her head to her abdomen, where it will be absorbed. This is the operation we've been hoping to avoid, he said. The surgery does not change her long-term prognosis - Hudgins expects her to grow up healthy but paralyzed from the waist down - but he said it does delay her scheduled return to Iraq for at least two months. Hudgins said shunts like Noor's clog in 30 to 40 percent of cases. If that happens with Noor, he said, doctors would schedule a second operation to clear it. Doctors may also operate if they detect a buildup of fluid in her brain, as opposed to adjacent to her brain, which is what triggered Friday's surgery. Noor, her father and grandmother have been in metro Atlanta since Dec. 31, brought here from a slum near Baghdad after Georgia-based National Guard soldiers with the 48th Brigade Combat Team encountered the baby while raiding a house. Noor suffers from a severe form of spina bifida in which her spine did not fully form. Doctors in Iraq told her family they could not treat Noor. Members of a unit based in Gainesville made connections that led to Childspring International, a Christian charity in Atlanta that brings sick children from abroad to the United States for medical treatment. Childspring brought Noor to Georgia and matched the baby and her father and grandmother with a host family. Hudgins operated on Jan. 9 to repair Noor's back. He had expected to insert a shunt shortly after that surgery, but did not find a fluid buildup until a few days ago. Helen Shepard, a Childspring spokeswoman, said Noor's father and grandmother were encouraged when doctors said initially that she would not need a shunt and that they are grateful for all the help they have received. It's been an emotional week for the family, she said. Hudgins said he expects to evaluate Noor again on March 21, one of several visits during which doctors will perform a brain scan to check for signs of a fluid accumulation. Noor continues to wear a pink cast, put on to protect her left foot after surgery that will permit her to wear shoes. Doctors expect her to wear a splint for two months after the cast is removed, which could happen soon. When she returns to Iraq, Noor will need access to a neurosurgeon in case the shunt clogs - it's inside her body, but headaches, vomiting and sleepiness could signal a problem, Hudgins said. In addition, she will need to visit a urologist occasionally to ensure proper bladder function, which can be a problem in some spina bifida cases but has not been so far with Noor. </P> 	nyt_eng_200603.gz

, he said,	 Authorities said Sullivan had always been a prime suspect in Lita Sullivan's death. They tried to make a federal case against him in 1992 for plotting the killing through interstate telephone calls. The federal case was dismissed midtrial. In 1994 the McClintons won a $4 million civil judgment against Sullivan for the wrongful death of their daughter. Civil court cases have a lower standard of proof than criminal cases. But authorities didn't get a real break in the case until 1998, when Harwood's ex-?girlfriend, Trahan, came forward after a television show about the killing aired. After she recounted what she knew, authorities went to Harwood's home in Albemarle, N.C. When he opened his door, he said, I've been waiting for you guys a long time, according to testimony from the GBI agent involved in the arrest. By that time Sullivan was living in Costa Rica. Around the time of his indictment, he asked a local couple to accompany him as he drove, in their car, 12 hours to Panama. He left his dog, Coco, with the woman's mother. Sullivan gave the couple enough money for their return trip and boarded a flight to Venezuela. Then he flew to Thailand. He never returned to Costa Rica for his car or his dog, the man and woman testified through translators. In Thailand, Sullivan married his fourth wife and bought an oceanfront condo in an upscale resort community. Recognized from the TV show America's Most Wanted by people in Thailand, Sullivan was arrested in July 2002. He was extradited to Fulton County in 2004. Bond was denied, and he has been in jail since then.
